paper_title: In-plane polar domains enhanced energy storage

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: IP-PNR design using La/Si co-doping in BaTiO3 (LSBT) thin films.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Proposes that engineering an in-plane polar-domain/polar-nanoregion architecture will drive higher energy storage performance in BaTiO3-based thin films.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: IP-PNR design will increase energy storage density and efficiency (Wr and η) and/or breakdown strength (Eb)
hypotheses.notes: Central design principle claimed to yield enhanced Wr, η, and Eb via IP-PNR architecture; used as the guiding hypothesis for the work.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Experimental results (Wr=203.7 J/cm3, η≈80%, Eb=6.15 MV/cm for BTLS2) support the effectiveness of the IP-PNR design.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The IP-PNR design mechanism comprises two critical steps: (1) Controlled gradient strain engineering to disrupt long-range ferroelectric ordering, creating an out-of-plane polarization gradient that induces relaxor behavior, followed by (2) deliberate in-plane strain engineering via doping to reconfigure nonpolar domains surrounding PNRs into in-plane-oriented polar domains.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Proposes a mechanistic sequence by which domain structures are transformed to promote relaxor behavior and in-plane polarization, enabling enhanced energy storage.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: If gradient strain engineering is applied followed by in-plane doping, IP-PNR architecture will form and enhance energy storage performance
hypotheses.notes: Articulates a two-step mechanism linking strain engineering and doping to IP-PNR formation and performance gains.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Phase-field simulations and experimental observations align with this two-step mechanism (IP-PNR formation and enhanced Pm with maintained Pr).

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: La/Si co-doping in BaTiO3 leads to large-sized in-plane polar T-domains along with a minor fraction of nanoscale R-domains and out-of-plane T-domains, yielding P–E loops with maintained Pr but significantly enhanced Pm.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Doping with La/Si is reported to reconfigure domain topology toward in-plane orientation while preserving remanent polarization and increasing maximum polarization.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: La/Si co-doping will increase Pm and maintain or reduce Pr by promoting in-plane domains
hypotheses.notes: Links chemical doping to a specific domain topology and polarization outcomes observed experimentally.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: STEM/SHG and P–E measurements show enhanced Pm with preserved Pr in LS-doped films.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: BTLS2 thin films demonstrate superior energy storage performance at equivalent electric fields compared with BTLS0, BTLS1, BTLS3 and BTLS4 samples.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Optimal LS doping level yields higher Wr and Eb, indicating improved energy storage performance.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: BTLS2 will outperform other BTLS samples at the same field
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Directly compares different LS doping levels (BTLS1–BTLS4) against BTLS0
hypotheses.notes: BTLS2 shows highest Wr and Eb; supports the role of LS concentration in performance optimization.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: BTLS2 achieves Wr=203.7 J/cm3 and Eb=6.15 MV/cm with high η (~80%).

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: LS doping increases breakdown field Eb, with BTLS2 achieving a maximum Eb of 6.15 MV/cm in this series.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Synthesis and measurements indicate that La/Si co-doping widens the bandgap and reduces defect-assisted leakage, increasing Eb; optimal level BTLS2 yields the maximum Eb reported.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increasing LS doping up to an optimal level will increase Eb, peaking at BTLS2
hypotheses.notes: Direct link between LS content and Eb with an observed optimum.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Weibull analysis shows maximum Eb at BTLS2 (6.15 MV/cm).

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The IP-PNR architecture increases ΔP (Pm − Pr) and Eb, thereby yielding high energy storage density Wr.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: IP-PNR domain arrangement promotes larger reversible polarization and higher breakdown strength, enhancing energy storage density.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: IP-PNR architecture increases ΔP and Eb, leading to higher Wr
hypotheses.notes: Core mechanism linking domain structure to energy storage performance.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: BTLS2 shows increased ΔP and Eb with delayed saturation, yielding higher Wr.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: BTLS2 achieves Wr = 203.7 J/cm3 and η ≈ 80% at an electric field of 6.15 MV/cm.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Empirical result reported for the optimized LS-doped film under the specified field.
hypotheses.notes: Key performance claim for the optimized LS-doped BaTiO3 thin film.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Wr = 203.7 J/cm3 and η ≈ 80% at 6.15 MV/cm reported for BTLS2.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The addition of LS doping suppresses the dielectric loss tangent over a wide temperature and frequency range, contributing to quasi-linear dielectric behavior.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: LS doping reduces energy dissipation and stabilizes dielectric response, enabling high-temperature stability.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: LS doping will reduce tan δ across a broad T and f range
hypotheses.notes: Link between composition and loss/tolerance to temperature variations.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Dielectric measurements show reduced loss tangent and lower temperature sensitivity in LS-doped films.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: BTLS2 exhibits superior fatigue performance (>1×10^9 cycles) with only small degradation in Wr and η at high field cycling.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: IP-PNR domain architecture reduces defect migration and provides robust cycling stability.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: BTLS2 will sustain very high cycle counts with minimal degradation
hypotheses.notes: Fatigue resistance is a key reliability metric for energy storage dielectrics and is claimed for BTLS2.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: BTLS2 > 1×10^9 cycles with small Wr/η degradation reported.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: An optimal film thickness exists around 230 nm for maximizing Wr and Eb in BTLS films.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Thickness-dependent properties indicate a peak performance near ~230 nm.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Wr and Eb are maximized around ~230 nm thickness
hypotheses.notes: Empirical optimization of film thickness.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Optimal thickness around 230 nm reported in the study.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: La occupies the A site and Si occupies both A and B sites in BTLS2 thin films.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: EELS mapping indicates the occupancy of La and Si in specific lattice sites, consistent with reported structural distortions.
hypotheses.notes: Direct site occupancy observed via EELS mapping; informs lattice distortion and domain formation.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: EELS mapping shows La on A-site and Si on A- and B-sites; uniform occupancy across film.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Phase-field simulations predict that undoped BTLS0 exhibits nanoscale polar nanoregions while LS-doped BTLS2 develops predominant in-plane T-domains with minor nanoscale R-domains and out-of-plane T-domains, consistent with experimental observations.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Computational predictions of domain architecture align with the observed experimental domain distributions.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Simulations will predict domain configurations that match experiments for BTLS0 and BTLS2
hypotheses.notes: Bridges computational predictions with experimental domain architectures.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Phase-field predictions of domain structures align with STEM/SHG results for BTLS0 and BTLS2.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Oxygen octahedral tilting induced by ionic radius mismatch between A- and B-site occupants drives the formation of in-plane polar domains.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: DFT/STEM/XAS analyses indicate that octahedral tilting correlates with in-plane polarization orientation.
variables_identified: ionic radii mismatch (A vs B sites)
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Radius mismatch leads to octahedral tilting that promotes in-plane polarization
hypotheses.notes: Mechanistic explanation for IP-PNR formation based on structural distortions.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: XAS/STEM/DFT show tilted octahedra and lateral displacement associated with in-plane polarization.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The monoclinic distortion (Pm) observed in BTLS2 is driven by oxygen octahedral tilting and lateral B-site cation displacement.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Reciprocal space mapping and STEM analyses indicate Pm symmetry linked to octahedral tilt and cation displacement.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: tilting and cation displacement promote Pm monoclinic distortion
hypotheses.notes: Links structural distortion to observed symmetry (Pm) in BTLS2.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: RSM and HAADF-STEM analyses corroborate monoclinic distortion driven by tilting/displacements.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The IP-PNR paradigm is a generalizable design strategy for achieving high-energy-density, lead-free dielectric materials.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors suggest broad applicability beyond the BTLS system, pointing to potential generalization.
hypotheses.notes: Future-oriented claim about generalizability; not experimentally tested in other systems within this paper.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Second-harmonic generation (SHG) intensity is proportional to the square of the in-plane polarization (I_SHG ∝ Pin-plane^2), and SHG mapping reveals enhanced in-plane polarization in BTLS2 (IP-PNR) relative to BTLS0 (PNR).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: SHG intensity is used as a proxy for in-plane polarization strength to corroborate domain orientation.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: BTLS2 will show higher in-plane polarization signals in SHG mapping than BTLS0
hypotheses.notes: SHG used as experimental validation of in-plane polarization strength.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: SHG mappings show enhanced in-plane polarization in BTLS2.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: DFT calculations show that LS doping widens the bandgap and increases the effective mass, reducing carrier mobility, which contributes to the high Eb of BTLS2.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Electronic structure calculations provide a microscopic mechanism for enhanced breakdown strength via reduced carrier mobility.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: LS doping widens bandgap and increases effective mass, reducing mobility and increasing Eb
hypotheses.notes: Provides a microscopic rationale for high Eb observed with LS doping.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: DFT indicates wider bandgap and reduced mobility in LS-doped BTLS2.

processing_notes: All hypotheses identified are based on explicit statements, design rationale, and testable predictions reported in the paper. Duplicates were removed; each hypothesis appears once with its rationale and supporting evidence.

paper_title: Origin of Enhanced Thermal Resistance Near Nanoscale Hotspots: Insights from Full-Dispersion-Resolved Phonon Transport in Silicon

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The analysis demonstrates that the increase in TR near NHs is not caused by the long MFP itself but by the low specific heat of long-MFP phonons that do not scatter directly with optical modes.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Posits a causal mechanism: the low specific heat of long-MFP phonons drives higher thermal resistance near nanoscale hotspots, not the mere existence of long MFPs.
variables_identified: thermal resistance near nanoscale hotspots (TR NH)
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Lower specific heat of long-MFP phonons increases TR near NHs
hypotheses.notes: Central claimed mechanism stated explicitly in the abstract.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: the key result is that, for LF modes, the TR at x* = 0 increases substantially under qa = 20%, relative to qa = 0%.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Explicitly ties the energy partition to a change in spectral thermal resistance for low-frequency modes.
variables_identified: qa (fraction of energy to acoustic modes)
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increasing qa increases TR for LF modes near NH
hypotheses.notes: Direct result reported in Fig. 5 related to qa variation for LF modes.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: LF modes show enhanced thermal resistance at x* = 0 under qa = 20%.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Asserts a causal link between qa and increased TR for low-frequency modes near the hotspot.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: LF modes under qa = 20% exhibit higher TR near NH than qa = 0%
hypotheses.notes: Describes a specific observed effect for LF modes in the results.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: For decades, the enhanced thermal resistance observed near nanoscale hotspots has been attributed to long mean free path phonons failing to couple efficiently to the hotspot because their mean free paths far exceed its size. The present analysis shows, however, that the true origin lies in the low specific heat of long-mean free path phonons that do not scatter directly with optical modes.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Replaces a long-standing belief with a mechanistic explanation grounded in modal specific heat and scattering pathways.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Lower Cp of long-MFP phonons increases TR near NH
hypotheses.notes: Directly quoted hypothesis moving beyond conventional MFP-centric explanations.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: This approach evaluates the ratio of the spectral heat flux to the modal temperature difference, with the assumption that each phonon mode can be assigned an equilibrium temperature.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: States a methodological premise about spectral analysis and modal temperature assignment.
variables_identified: modal temperature assignment (equilibrium temperature per mode)
hypotheses.notes: Methodological premise used to define spectral thermal resistance Rω.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Assuming one-dimensional transport along the Si layer (a validation for this, will be discussed later, Fig. 4.)
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: States an assumption about transport geometry to enable modeling.
hypotheses.notes: Assumption explicitly stated and later validated in the study.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: these phonons heat readily when energized, which steepens the temperature gradient by scattering with other acoustic phonon modes near the hotspot and thereby increases the thermal resistance at the nanoscale hotspots.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Gives a mechanism for why LF phonons contribute to increased TR when energy is injected.
variables_identified: scattering with other acoustic phonon modes
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Energizing LF phonons increases the local temperature gradient and TR near NH
hypotheses.notes: Mechanistic explanation for LF-mode contribution to TR.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: HF modes show nearly identical results for both qa values, with slightly lower resistance at x* = 1 under qa = 20%: (a) and (b) for L = 41 nm, (c) and (d) for L = 78 nm, (e) and (f) for L = 177 nm
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Claims insensitivity of HF modes to qa variation, implying different transport behavior than LF modes.
hypotheses.notes: Direct quote from figure caption describing HF-mode qa independence.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The TA modes emerging from the NH cannot satisfy energy and momentum conservation simultaneously, so direct TA–TA scattering is negligible. In contrast, several LA modes scatter strongly with OM, notably LA3 (66.7%), LA4 (52.2%), and LA6 (57.1%), where the percentages indicate the fraction of their total scattering rate that involves OM.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Describes specific inter-branch scattering dynamics and their impact on energy transfer near NH.
variables_identified: fraction of scattering rate involving OM
hypotheses.predicted_direction: TA direct scattering is negligible, LA–OM scattering is significant, shaping TR near NH
hypotheses.notes: Mechanistic detail about interbranch scattering pathways near NH.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: LF modes directly acquire one-fifth of the injected energy, and their TR increases accordingly with qa; LF modes show enhanced thermal resistance at x* = 0 for qa = 20%.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Specifies energy partition and its consequence for LF-mode TR.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: LF modes with qa = 20% exhibit higher TR near NH than qa = 0%
hypotheses.notes: Direct reference to energy partition and its effect on LF-mode TR.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The enhanced thermal resistance observed near nanoscale hotspots cannot be explained by Fourier diffusion; nonlocal phonon transport is essential, as Fourier analysis underpredicts the TR.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Contrasts FPDM-based nonlocal transport with Fourier diffusion, asserting nonlocality as the key driver of TR.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Nonlocal transport yields higher TR than Fourier diffusion predicts
hypotheses.notes: Directly cites mismatch with Fourier analysis as evidence for nonlocal transport mechanisms.

processing_notes: The set includes explicit, explicit-like (through abstract/conclusion statements) and implicit hypotheses identified across the paper. Each item is categorized along the full taxonomy and linked to text cues (quotes or close paraphrase). Some items reflect methodological assumptions (e.g., one-dimensional transport, spectral TR measure) that function as testable propositions within the FPDM framework. Duplicates were avoided by combining closely related claims into single hypotheses where appropriate, while keeping distinct mechanistic or causal claims separate.

paper_title: Real-time dynamics with bead-Fourier path integrals. II. Bead-Fourier RPMD

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: BF-RPMD will produce results on par with standard RPMD, with at worst twofold and up to eightfold reduction in the number of beads by including two to three Fourier components.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors state BF-RPMD is able to produce results on par with standard RPMD and can achieve a substantial reduction in required beads by adding a small number of Fourier components.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: BF-RPMD results will match RPMD while using fewer beads when 2–3 Fourier components are included
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Directly compares BF-RPMD vs RPMD in terms of accuracy and bead-count requirements as a function of kmax
hypotheses.notes: Explicit claim in the introduction about BF-RPMD matching RPMD's accuracy with bead-reduction via Fourier components

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: BF-RPMD is vastly superior to BF-CMD for non-linear time correlation functions.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The paper states that BF-RPMD’s performance for nonlinear operators is vastly greater than BF-CMD, indicating a clear comparative advantage.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Direct comparison of BF-RPMD vs BF-CMD for nonlinear TCFs
hypotheses.notes: Conclusion explicitly states the superior performance of BF-RPMD over BF-CMD for nonlinear operators

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: BF-RPMD effectiveness is sensitive to both the system and the form of the operators being studied.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors explicitly note system- and operator-dependence of BF-RPMD performance.
hypotheses.notes: A general, condition-dependent claim about method applicability

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The continuous estimator ABF,cont yields exact zero-time limit results for the Kubo-transformed CF across BF-RPMD methods and bead counts (for A = x in the harmonic oscillator).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The results show the continuous estimator reproduces the exact zero-time limit for C̃_AA(t) across methods and beads.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Using ABF,cont yields exact zero-time limit for the Kubo-transformed CF
hypotheses.notes: Directly reported observation in the Harmonic oscillator results

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Bead estimator overestimates the zero-time limit for small numbers of beads.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The results show bead-estimated zero-time limits are overestimated when n is small, in contrast to the continuous estimator.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Bead estimator overestimates zero-time limit for small n
hypotheses.notes: Observational claim tied to estimator type and bead count

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Thermostatting Fourier components during BF-RPMD (Methods 1-B and 2-B) reduces coupling of Fourier modes to the external potential, restoring harmonic-like CF behavior.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The paper notes that introduction of the thermostat returns CFs to simple harmonic motion and is necessary to avoid coupling artefacts.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Thermostatting reduces spurious couplings and recovers harmonic CF behavior
hypotheses.specific_type_details: BF-RPMD with thermostat (Methods 1-B and 2-B)
hypotheses.notes: Thermostatting effects discussed with respect to CFs and mode coupling

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: For the mildly anharmonic oscillator at β = 1, BF-RPMD with 2 beads converges for linear operator A = x across Methods 1-B and 2-B.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The results show that, at β = 1, 2 beads suffice for convergence of the linear operator CF across the relevant BF-RPMD methods.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: 2 beads suffice to converge for linear A at β = 1
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Convergence as a function of beads for linear operator at high temperature
hypotheses.notes: Directly supported by high-temperature convergence results

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: For the quartic oscillator at β = 8, BF-RPMD converges with 16 beads and 2 Fourier components for A = x and A = x^3 using Method 2-B.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Table VII and Table VIII report converged parameters (n, kmax, estimator) at β = 8 for A = x and A = x^3 with 16 beads and 2 Fourier components using Method 2-B.
variables_identified: Estimator = Cont. or Bead depending on row
hypotheses.predicted_direction: 16 beads and 2 Fourier components suffice to converge for these operators
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Convergence parameters reported in Tables VII and VIII for β = 8
hypotheses.notes: Observed convergence parameters support a specific bead/ Fourier-component configuration at low temperature

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: BF-RPMD is a computationally simpler and potentially more scalable approach than BF-CMD for large-scale atomistic simulations, and the authors plan to implement BF-RPMD (and BF-PIMD) into a software package to enable this.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors argue that BF-RPMD would be simpler to implement for large-scale simulations and outline plans to integrate BF-RPMD into a software package (DL_POLY Quantum).
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Plan to integrate BF-RPMD into DL_POLY Quantum
hypotheses.notes: Describes anticipated advantages and future software integration

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: A fully thermostatted BF-RPMD method will further improve accuracy or quality of dynamical properties (e.g., vibrational spectra) by avoiding artefacts from internal BF modes.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors propose exploring a fully thermostatted BF-RPMD as future work to improve dynamical properties.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Fully thermostatted BF-RPMD reduces artefacts and improves spectra
hypotheses.notes: Foreseen extension; not yet demonstrated in this paper

processing_notes: This output identifies explicit and implicit hypotheses embedded in the paper. Each hypothesis is classified using a multi-axis taxonomy (epistemic type, structural type, predictive type, functional type, temporal type, and specific hypothesis type) and is supplemented with justification, involved variables, and a confidence assessment. Some items are explicit claims in the text (e.g., Bead-Fourier RPMD can match RPMD with bead reductions), while others are implicit or operational assumptions (e.g., estimator behaviors, thermostating effects). Entries have been deduplicated to avoid repetition across sections.

paper_title: Orbitally-Resolved Mechanical Properties of Solids from Maximally Localized Wannier Functions

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Eelec can be partitioned into orbitally-resolved contributions using maximally localized Wannier functions (MLWFs), i.e., Eelec = ∑_α E_α0.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Because Etot is invariant under unitary rotations of the electronic subspace and E(I−I)_ext is orbital-independent, expressing Eelec in the MLWF basis yields a rigorous orbitally-resolved decomposition: Eelec = (1/Nk) ∑_α R E_α0, with E_α0 defined as ⟨w_αR|H_elec|w_αR⟩ minus a common ∆v contribution.
hypotheses.notes: Foundational methodological claim enabling orbitally resolved energy partitioning in MLWF basis.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The anomalous elastic response of PbTiO3 under applied stress is driven by changes in the apical-oxygen (Oap) bonding environment, in particular the Oap 2s/2p MLWFs, whose internal-stress contributions change significantly with stress.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The paper identifies the key role of Oap orbitals and shows that only the Oap (2s, 2p) MLWF internal stresses vary nonlinearly with applied stress, correlating with the c-axis anomaly; two zero-crossings imply a barrier between metastable configurations.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: As applied stress increases, Oap MLWF internal-stress changes drive the c-axis anomaly (elongation/two-step response).
hypotheses.notes: Mechanistic hypothesis linking orbital bonding changes to macroscopic elastic anomaly.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: In BaTiO3, the energy lowering associated with freezing in the cubic Γ−4 phonon is dominated by changes in Oap (2s, 2p) MLWF contributions, consistent with cross-gap hybridization between O-p and Ti-d states driving the transition.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Extension of the MLWF-energy-partitioning approach shows that Oap MLWFs contribute most to energy lowering during the Γ−4 phonon distortion, aligning with a cross-gap hybridization mechanism.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Oap MLWF contributions dominate energy lowering as the Γ−4 mode is frozen in
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Transfer of energy-partitioning insights to BaTiO3 ferroelectric transition
hypotheses.notes: Demonstrates applicability of orbitally resolved energy partitioning to a different perovskite and a different property (ferroelectric distortion).

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Precise reproduction of PbTiO3's elastic anomaly requires both electronic (Eelec) and ion–ion (E(I−I)_ext) internal-stress contributions; neither alone suffices.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The paper emphasizes that both electronic and ion-ion contributions are required to quantitatively reproduce the observed anomaly in the c-axis response.
hypotheses.notes: Highlights the necessity of synchronizing electronic and ionic energies to capture the anomaly.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Etot can be decomposed as Etot = ∑_α E_α0 + ∑_A E(I−I)_ext,A, i.e., a sum of orbitally resolved electronic contributions and ionically resolved ion–ion contributions.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Derived directly from the MLWF formulation, with ϵ_αR and ∆v(r) leading to Eα0 and E(I−I)_ext,A, such that Etot = Eelec + E(I−I)_ext = ∑_α Eα0 + ∑_A E(I−I)_ext,A.
hypotheses.notes: Foundational energy-partitioning equation enabling orbitally and atomically resolved analyses.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Oap-2s MLWFs experience a loss of covalency with Ti as the c-axis increases (hybridization decreases and charge is transferred back to Ti and Oap), contributing to the elastic anomaly.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The text describes a decrease in Ti–Oap covalency, loss of Ti–Oap d-character hybridization, and a transfer of charge as the c-axis lengthens, which aligns with the anomalous elastic response.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: increasing c-axis reduces Oap-2s Ti-d covalency and shifts charge onto Ti/Oap
hypotheses.notes: Mechanistic explanation linking bonding environment to the elastic anomaly.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The Oap-2s MLWF internal stress shows two zero-crossings as the c-axis parameter changes, implying an energy landscape with a barrier between two (meta-)stable configurations (an isostructural transition).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The observed two zero-point crossings (A and C) in the Oap-2s internal-stress plot indicate a potential barrier between metastable configurations, consistent with an isostructural transition interpretation.
hypotheses.notes: Interprets the energy landscape topology from orbital-stress signals.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Across perovskites in the P4mm group, the location of the elastic anomaly correlates (roughly linearly) with the strain that minimizes the total Oap MLWF internal stress, with the A-site cation controlling this location.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Fig. 3 shows a roughly linear relation between anomaly location and the predicted strain that minimizes Oap internal stress, and the text attributes the control to the A-site cation.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Transfer of correlation across perovskites (PbTiO3, BaTiO3, SnTiO3, CaTiO3, PbZrO3, etc.)
hypotheses.notes: Suggests a generalizable link between orbital-stress biology and anomaly position modulated by A-site chemistry.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The Oap-2s MLWF internal stress responds to applied stress by effectively pushing against the unit-cell walls along the c-axis, guiding the bond environment toward a new favorable configuration (a qualitative picture of the anomaly).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The narrative describes Oap states as pushing outward against the walls of the unit cell along the c-axis, driving toward a different bonding environment as stress is applied.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: increase in applied stress leads to Oap-driven expansion toward a new bonding environment
hypotheses.notes: Connects orbital energetics to a qualitative mechanical response under stress.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The orbitally resolved MLWF energy partitioning provides chemically interpretable contributions assignable to atoms and bonds, enabling direct linkages between microscopic orbital features and macroscopic mechanical properties.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Because MLWFs are localized and can be assigned to atoms or bonds, the energy partitioning yields chemically meaningful insights about structure–property relationships.
hypotheses.notes: Central methodological claim about interpretability of orbital-energy contributions.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The energy-partitioning framework can be extended to properties beyond elastic constants (i.e., any property expressible as an energy derivative), enabling atomic-scale design of materials with tailored mechanical behavior.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors argue that the approach is applicable to any property given by an energy derivative and demonstrate extensions to other properties (e.g., BaTiO3 ferroelectric transition).
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Extension to properties beyond mechanics (e.g., ferroelectric transitions in BaTiO3)
hypotheses.notes: Proposes general applicability of the method beyond the tested mechanical properties.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: MLWF-based orbitally resolved energy partitioning yields more chemically interpretable insights than a band-energy partitioning approach, facilitating mechanistic understanding of materials properties.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The MLWF-based, orbital-resolved partitioning is explicitly designed to be chemically interpretable and orthonormal/compositional, unlike generic band-energy decompositions.
hypotheses.notes: Contingent claim about interpretability advantages; not exhaustively tested in the paper.

processing_notes: This analysis identifies 9 distinct hypotheses (methodological decompositions, mechanistic mechanisms in PbTiO3, transferability to BaTiO3, and generalization to other properties) embedded across the Introduction, Theory/Methods, Results, and Discussion sections. Each item has been labeled for epistemic type, structure, predictive direction, and applicability, with justification grounded in the text. Some items are closely linked (e.g., orbital contributions driving the anomaly; extension to BaTiO3), but they are treated as separate hypotheses to avoid duplication and to reflect their distinct claims and testability.

paper_title: Evidence for easy-plane XY ferromagnetism in heavy-fermion quantum-critical CeRh6Ge4

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: CeRh6Ge4 undergoes a ferromagnetic transition at TC = 2.51 K with a uniform, small ordered moment ≈ 0.26 μB per Ce, evolving below TC.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The paper reports a ferromagnetic order parameter evolution below TC with a small ordered moment of ≈ 0.26 μB/Ce.
hypotheses.notes: Direct claim about FM order and its small moment at ambient pressure.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The ordered moment is confined to the ab-plane (m ∥ ab) with XY-type easy-plane in-plane isotropy.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Zeeman-perturbed NQR and NMR analyses indicate the internal field lies in the ab-plane and the moment orientation has no preferential in-plane direction.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Moment lies in the ab-plane with no preferred in-plane direction
hypotheses.notes: Key structural conclusion about magnetic anisotropy and moment direction.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The ordered moment shows magnetic stiffness against out-of-plane radiofrequency fields, consistent with an XY-type easy-plane magnetism.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: NMR/NQR data reveal suppression of transverse fluctuations and a need for out-of-plane fluctuations (hc⊥) to enhance signals, implying in-plane stiffness.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Out-of-plane fluctuations are suppressed; m stays in ab-plane
hypotheses.notes: Connects spectral features to magnetic anisotropy; supports XY character.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: In the paramagnetic state, 1/T1 is predominantly caused by fluctuating 4f-local moments (local-moment fluctuations) rather than itinerant Kondo fluctuations.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Nearly T-independent 1/T1 and absence of Korringa behavior point to localized 4f moment fluctuations dominating the relaxation.
hypotheses.notes: Distinguishes local-moment vs itinerant relaxation channels in PM state.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Above TC (PM state), 1/T1 is temperature-independent up to ~50 K, indicating local-moment fluctuations dominate in that regime.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The data show a temperature-independent 1/T1 behavior from ~4 K up to ~50 K in Ge(2).
hypotheses.notes: Interpreted as evidence for local-moment-dominated fluctuations in PM state.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: H_int at Ge(1) is exactly in-plane and parallel to the ordered moment (H_int ∥ ab ∥ m).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Exact diagonalization fits to Ge(1) lines across TC yield H_int lying in the ab-plane and parallel to m.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: H_int ∥ ab and ∥ m
hypotheses.notes: Links hyperfine coupling to moment direction; supports m ∥ ab.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Ge(2) internal field lies within the ab-plane and exhibits an isotropic angular distribution of H_int within that plane.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: NMR analysis shows Ge(2) fields requiring H_int in-plane with an isotropic distribution to reproduce the spectrum.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: H_int lies in ab-plane with isotropic in-plane distribution
hypotheses.notes: Ge(2) site shows anisotropy in V_zz but in-plane distribution is isotropic.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: There is a linear relation between the internal local field at Ge(1) and the bulk magnetization M below TC, enabling extraction of the in-plane hyperfine coupling A_Ge(1)FM.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Ge(1) data show M vs H_int with a linear trend below TC; this yields A_Ge(1)FM.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: H_int ∝ M
hypotheses.notes: Connects local-field measurements to bulk magnetization; yields coupling constant.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Internal fields at Ge sites are dominated by transferred hyperfine fields rather than direct dipolar fields.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Dipolar-field calculations yield fields an order of magnitude/six times smaller than observed hyperfine fields, indicating transferred hyperfine coupling dominates.
hypotheses.notes: Distinguishes coupling mechanism for internal fields; supports hyperfine-transfer picture.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Ge(2) internal field and spectrum are consistent with an in-plane (ab) orientation with an isotropic distribution, supporting XY-like order.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Best-fit simulations to the Ge(2) spectrum require in-plane H_int with an isotropic distribution within ab-plane.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: H_int lies in ab-plane with isotropic in-plane distribution
hypotheses.notes: Ge(2) spectral analysis supports XY-like in-plane order.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The Knight shift–susceptibility relation K vs χ_ab shows a kink at T* ≈ 25 K, suggesting an interplay of Kondo screening and CEF effects.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: A kink in the K–χ plot at T* is observed and discussed as arising from Kondo/CEF interplay.
hypotheses.notes: Links spectral shift anomaly to competing many-body effects (Kondo/CEF).

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: There is evidence for a uniform ferromagnetic order with no significant magnetic inhomogeneity across the FM transition at ambient pressure.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The intensity and linewidth of the NQR signal do not show notable changes across TC in the PM-to-ordered-state change, implying uniform order.
hypotheses.notes: Supports uniform order and excludes strong inhomogeneity at TC.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The FM transition in CeRh6Ge4 at ambient pressure is continuous and persists toward the pressure-tuned QCP without an intervening first-order transition.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The introduction discusses a continuous FM transition at ambient pressure and its persistence toward PC without a first-order interruption, consistent with theoretical frameworks.
hypotheses.notes: Relates to broader FM QCP frameworks; not a direct experimental test in this work but stated as context.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The shift anomaly seen in the Knight shift (K) around T* ≈ 25 K reflects a complex interplay of Kondo coherence and crystalline electric field (CEF) effects (or both).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The paper discusses a kink in K–χ and attributes it to possible Kondo coherence and/or CEF mixing, indicating interplay between these energy scales.
hypotheses.notes: Links spectral anomaly to competing energy scales in 4f systems.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The phase-separation-like feature observed near TC in the Ge(2) spectrum indicates a weakly first-order character of the FM transition.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: A transient spectral feature near 1.9–2.4 K (Ge(2)) suggests possible phase separation; authors interpret as a sign of weakly first-order nature.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: weakly first-order FM transition with phase separation
hypotheses.notes: Represents a cautious interpretation of spectral evidence for weakly first-order behavior.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Internal Ge(1) and Ge(2) spectral features are dominated by transferred hyperfine fields, not by direct Ce dipolar moments.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Dipolar-field estimates are far too small to account for observed hyperfine fields; transferred hyperfine fields explain the data.
hypotheses.notes: Supports the mechanism for hyperfine fields in this compound.

processing_notes: The paper presents a microscopic NQR/NMR study of CeRh6Ge4 at ambient pressure, arguing for easy-plane (XY-type) ferromagnetism with a small in-plane moment, uniform order parameter, and local-moment fluctuations in the PM state. The hypotheses above capture explicit claims (FM order, moment direction, XY anisotropy) and well-supported inferences (internal-field geometry, hyperfine mechanism, Kondo/CEF interplay) as testable propositions. Some items are interpretive in nature and rely on spectral modeling (Ge sites, H_int alignments). All hypotheses listed are unique; duplicates across sections were merged and de-duplicated. Confidence scores reflect the strength and directness of the supporting evidence in the text.

paper_title: Oxygen-vacancy-induced Raman softening in the catalyst Fe$_2$(MoO$_4$)$_3$

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Oxygen vacancies are the origin of the experimentally observed Raman reduction during the catalytic process in iron molybdate Fe2(MoO4)3.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors explicitly state that oxygen vacancies are the origin of the Raman reduction observed during catalysis.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Oxygen vacancies will decrease Raman intensity relative to the vacancy-free material
hypotheses.notes: Explicit causal claim about vacancy-caused Raman intensity reduction; used as a central mechanistic hypothesis in the study

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Oxygen-dominated phonon modes play the dominant role in the reduction of Raman intensity in Fe2(MoO4)3.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors, via an effective frozen-phonon approach, show that freezing oxygen-related vibrations yields the largest impact on Raman intensity reductions.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Oxygen-dominated phonon modes cause a decrease in Raman intensity
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Mode-resolved contributions to Raman intensity; role of O vibrations
hypotheses.notes: Key mechanistic claim linking specific vibrational character to the observed Raman change

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Oxygen diffusion from the bulk to the surface should occur without significant alteration of the local symmetry, consistent with the absence of measurable peak shifts or broadening in the experimental Raman spectra.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The experimental Raman spectra show no peak shifts or broadening during catalysis, implying symmetry is preserved during diffusion.
hypotheses.notes: Accounts for the lack of observable spectral shifts as support for diffusion without symmetry distortion

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The monoclinic Fe2(MoO4)3 and the high-temperature orthorhombic Fe2(MoO4)3 polymorphs have structurally nearly identical crystal structures and phonon dispersions, leading to similar Raman responses.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: symmetry-mode analysis and phonon calculations show very small differences between the two polymorphs, with nearly identical phononic characteristics and similar Raman spectra.
hypotheses.notes: Supports the claim that Raman changes are not driven by a phase transition between these polymorphs

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Freezing the phonon modes of selected atoms demonstrates that oxygen vacancies dominate the Raman-intensity reduction.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors freeze specific atomic phonon modes (notably oxygen) and observe the largest reduction in Raman intensity, indicating oxygen-vibration contributions dominate.
variables_identified: frozen phonon modes of selected atoms (e.g., O)
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Freezing oxygen phonon modes will reproduce the Raman-intensity reduction (dominant contribution by O vibrations)
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Mode-resolved contribution testing via a frozen-phonon approach
hypotheses.notes: Methodologically links mode contributions to the observed Raman change; supports a vacancy-phonon mechanism

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: A pentagonal FeO5 unit remains stable after introduction of an oxygen vacancy, suggesting iron sites may actively facilitate oxygen diffusion during the catalytic process.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Structural relaxation around an O vacancy yields a stable FeO5 motif, indicating a possible diffusion pathway mediated by iron sites.
hypotheses.notes: Connects local structural changes to diffusion mechanisms; empirical validation via spectroscopy suggested (Mössbauer, etc.)

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Calculated Raman spectrum for orthorhombic Fe2(MoO4)3 shows a dominant peak near 789 cm−1 that originates from asymmetric MoO4 stretching vibrations (oxygen-dominated), in agreement with the experimental observation.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The calculated spectrum reproduces the experimental Raman feature around 789 cm−1 and links it to asymmetric MoO4 stretching with significant oxygen involvement.
hypotheses.notes: Bridges theory and experiment; validates mode attribution for the major Raman feature

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The dominant Raman peak near 789 cm−1 originates from asymmetric MoO4 stretching modes (with oxygen-dominated vibrations) and a smaller contribution from Mo modes.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Mode analysis shows asymmetric MoO4 stretching dominates around 789 cm−1, with Mo contributions being smaller elsewhere in the same region.
hypotheses.notes: Mode assignment for the key Raman feature; supports interpretation of spectral data

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Oxygen vacancies cause a reduction in Raman intensity without inducing measurable peak shifts or broadening, i.e., they do not introduce significant local-symmetry distortions detectable by Raman spectroscopy.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The absence of peak shifts/broadening in experiments, despite Raman-intensity reductions, suggests the local symmetry is preserved even with vacancies.
hypotheses.notes: Consistent with experimental observations and supports a symmetry-preserving vacancy mechanism

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The effective frozen-phonon approach is a reasonable means to explain the observed Raman reduction due to oxygen vacancies in Fe2(MoO4)3.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The approach isolates phonon contributions and reproduces qualitative Raman-reduction trends consistent with vacancy effects, lending validity to the method.
hypotheses.notes: Methodological validation claim for the computational approach used

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The absence of measurable peak shifts or broadening indicates that oxygen vacancies do not induce large distortions of the local symmetry in Fe2(MoO4)3 during catalysis.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Spectral data show no distortive signatures; this is used to argue symmetry-preserving vacancy behavior.
hypotheses.notes: Supports a symmetry-preserving vacancy scenario compatible with experiments

processing_notes: All hypotheses were identified by extracting explicit claims and implicit assumptions across the paper (Introduction, Results, Discussion). Duplicates were merged to a single hypothesis per idea. Each item includes the exact or near-quoted text that motivates the hypothesis, with classification grounded in the paper’s content (DFT results, frozen-phonon analysis, and interpretation of Raman data). Confidence scores reflect how directly the text supports the stated hypothesis. No experimental validation of these hypotheses is provided beyond computational analysis and comparison to reported Raman data.

paper_title: Spinon Mediation of Witness-Spin Dynamics and Ground State in Herbertsmithite

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: A Z2 quantum spin liquid (QSL) spinon‑mediated model of witness‑spin interactions accounts for the observed witness‑spin dynamics in ZnCu3(OH)6Cl2, predicting: (i) slowing and intensification of witness‑spin fluctuations, (ii) a transition to a spinon‑mediated phase signified by a spin‑noise power spectrum S_M(ω, T) that is scale‑invariant with S_M(ω, T) ∝ ω^α, (iii) a sharp cusp in the DC magnetic susceptibility χ(T), and (iv) the appearance of an Edwards–Anderson order parameter.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Proposes a concrete microscopic mechanism (spinon‑mediated couplings inside a Z2 QSL) that would drive the observed spin‑noise evolution, susceptibility cusp, and spin‑glass ordering; the paper tests this mechanism against multiple concurrent observables.
variables_identified: spin-noise power spectral density S_M(ω, T)
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Spinon‑mediated witness‑spin interactions slow and intensify fluctuations; the PSD becomes scale‑invariant with α, χ(T) develops a cusp, and a nonzero Edwards–Anderson order parameter appears below the transition.
hypotheses.notes: Central hypothesis; links a Z2 QSL mechanism to a constellation of experimentally observed signatures.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: When spinon‑mediated, all witness‑spin interactions are purely antiferromagnetic (AF).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Directly states a property of the inferred interaction mechanism used in the model.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: AF (antiferromagnetic) coupling between witness‑spins
hypotheses.notes: A qualitative prediction of the sign of the mediated interaction that constrains the model.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The spinon‑mediated witness‑spin interaction energy scale J_89 is of the same order as the Curie–Weiss temperature, i.e. |θ+| ≈ J_89 ≈ 1.1–1.2 K.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Links the model‑estimated interaction energy scale to a directly measured thermodynamic scale (CW temperature).
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increase in J_89 should reflect a CW scale ~1 K; observed value is ~1.1 K.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Energy scale matching the Curie–Weiss temperature
hypotheses.notes: Quantitative consistency between the spinon‑mediated coupling and a key thermodynamic scale supports the proposed mechanism.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The Z2 QSL spinon‑mediated model provides a closer quantitative match to the full set of experimental observations than a U(1) QSL spinon‑mediated model.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The paper compares both QSL scenarios and finds the Z2 variant aligns more closely with the data across multiple observables.
hypotheses.notes: A comparative hypothesis about model validity across the observed phenomenology.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The witness‑spin noise spectra S_M(ω, T) are scale‑invariant, with a power spectrum S_M(ω, T) ∝ ω^−α, and the power‑index α transitions to α ≈ 1 at the transition temperature T* ≈ 260 mK.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Directly describes observed functional form and its temperature‑dependent evolution.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: α increases toward 1 as T approaches T* from above (transition to α ≈ 1).
hypotheses.notes: Key experimental signature used to diagnose the spinon‑mediated regime and its transition.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: There is a sharp transition to a witness‑spin glass below T* ≈ 260 mK, evidenced by (i) an Edwards–Anderson spin‑glass order parameter emerging, (ii) a rapid diminution of witness‑spin noise, and (iii) ultra‑slow relaxation (−ln τ) of the flux after a thermal quench and in a small applied field.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Directly reports a transition point and hallmark glassy signatures observed experimentally.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Below T*, witness‑spins freeze into a spin‑glass state with nonzero q_EA and suppressed noise.
hypotheses.notes: Direct experimental signature of a spinon‑mediated witness‑spin glass implied by the theory.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Monte Carlo simulations of spinon‑mediated witness‑spin dynamics in ZnCu3(OH)6Cl2 exhibit a transition at T* ≈ 150 mK, with a power‑law exponent α → 1 and the emergence of a witness‑spin glass order parameter, consistent with the spinon‑mediated QSL scenario.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Connects the MC model predictions to the experimental phenomenology, lending support to the proposed mechanism.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Transition temperature in simulations lies around T* ≈ 150 mK with α ≈ 1 below it.
hypotheses.notes: Shows qualitative and semi‑quantitative agreement with observed spinon‑mediated dynamics; highlights model limitations (MC timescales, finite size).

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Alternative mechanisms proposed in the literature (nearest‑neighbor exchange, next‑nearest‑neighbor exchange, direct dipolar coupling, spin‑wave mediation, random singlets) cannot account for the full range of experimental observations and are ruled out by the data.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The paper systematically discusses and rejects these alternatives based on consistency with DC χ, INS structure factor, and spin‑noise phenomenology.
hypotheses.notes: A theory‑selection claim: only spinon‑mediated QSL explanations remain compatible with all data.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The low‑energy neutron scattering structure factor S(Q, ω) predicted by the witness‑spin/spinon‑mediated model is not inconsistent with the experimentally observed diffuse low‑energy INS pattern in ZnCu3(OH)6Cl2.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Connects a predicted structure factor from the model to INS data; the authors compare shapes and find qualitative agreement.
hypotheses.notes: Supports, but does not uniquely prove, the spinon‑mediated mechanism via INS signatures.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The witness‑spin approach (spin‑noise spectroscopy of Cu/Zn impurity spins) can be generalized to study quantum spin liquids in other materials (e.g., Zn‑barlowite) and can serve as a quantum portal to the QSL state.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors argue that witness‑spin noise techniques are generalizable and view impurity spins as a diagnostic resource.
hypotheses.notes: Forward‑looking generalization beyond the studied material; a prospective hypothesis guiding future work.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The Z2 spinon‑mediated witness‑spin model implies a finite spinon gap Δ ≈ 30 K (2Δ ≈ 60 K) in the kagome QSL, consistent with prior spectroscopic constraints and enabling a consistent energy‑scale picture for the observed low‑temperature dynamics.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Uses the mean‑field Z2 QSL solution to fix a spinon gap that enters the predicted interaction strengths and dynamic responses.
hypotheses.notes: An internal consistency assumption of the Z2 QSL framework used to generate quantitative predictions.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The observed transition to a spin‑glass state at T* ≈ 260 mK is intrinsic to the ZnCu3(OH)6Cl2 material and not an artifact of measurement fields (≤ a few μT) or sample‑specific disorder alone.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Supported by consistency of T* across multiple samples and very low applied fields; argues against extrinsic causes.
hypotheses.notes: Supports intrinsic spinon‑mediated physics rather than field‑driven or sample‑dependent artifact explanations.

processing_notes: Identified explicit, implicit, and model‑driven hypotheses embedded in the paper. Duplicates were merged and each hypothesis is linked to its supporting arguments (spinon mediation in Z2 QSL, comparisons with U(1) QSL, and the witness‑spin experimental observable set). Some items are forward‑looking or methodological (generalization, model exclusion) and are labeled accordingly.

paper_title: Universal scaling of shear thickening suspensions under acoustic perturbation

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Acoustic perturbations induce an additional interparticle repulsive stress σ*_a(Ua), which adds to the existing interparticle repulsion to form a total repulsive barrier σ*_total = σ*_0 + σ*_a(Ua).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Explicitly states that acoustic perturbations generate an extra interparticle repulsion that combines with the pre-existing repulsion to set the total barrier
hypotheses.predicted_direction: σ*_total increases with increasing acoustic perturbation through σ*_a(Ua)
hypotheses.notes: Explicitly introduced as the mechanism by which acoustics affect the frictional contacts within the universal scaling framework

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The acoustic contribution to the interparticle repulsive stress σ*_a(Ua) is approximately equal to the acoustic energy density Ua.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Dimensional/physical argument and experimental observation reported in the paper
hypotheses.predicted_direction: σ*_a(Ua) ∝ Ua (σ*_a scales with Ua)
hypotheses.notes: Supporting assumption used to quantify acoustics’ effect within the scaling framework

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The viscosity in acoustics-free suspensions can be described by a universal crossover scaling form η(φ, σ) = (φ0 − φ)^−2 F( x ), with x = [C(φ) e^{−σ*_0/σ}] / (φ0 − φ).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Based on the Wyart–Cates framework leading to a data collapse onto a single curve F(x) across φ and σ
hypotheses.notes: Central modeling claim: a single scaling function F(x) governs η(φ, σ) in acoustics-free conditions; data collapse supports this

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Near the critical value xc = 1, the scaling function diverges as F(x) ∼ (xc − x)^−δ with δ ≈ 0.9.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Empirical fit to the collapsed data showing a power-law divergence as x → xc
hypotheses.predicted_direction: F(x) grows without bound as x approaches xc from below
hypotheses.notes: Captures critical-like divergence in the high-stress/frictional regime within the scaling framework

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: There are two jam points in the system: a frictionless jamming critical point and a frictional jamming critical point, and the crossover scaling function F captures the transition between them.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Stated as a foundational premise of the universal scaling framework used to describe thickening and jamming
hypotheses.notes: Key premise for the two-regime (frictionless vs frictional) control of viscosity in the Wyart–Cates–type scaling

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The anisotropy factor C(φ) is non-monotonic in volume fraction φ.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Empirical observation reported from Fig. 2c and prior work
hypotheses.notes: Captures a material-dependent correction to scaling; non-monotonic behavior discussed

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Acoustic perturbations can be incorporated into the universal scaling framework by introducing a scaling variable xa = [C(φ) e^{−(σ*_0+σ*_a(Ua)) / σ}] /(φ0 − φ), such that η collapses onto the universal curve F(xa) across φ, σ, and Ua.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Directly tested by data collapse showing successful unification when xa is used
hypotheses.notes: Demonstrates that acoustics enter the scaling framework through an additive interparticle repulsion term in the scaled variable

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The acoustic contribution to the interparticle repulsive stress σ*_a(Ua) can be captured by σ*_a(Ua) ≈ Ua, enabling a simple, dimensionally consistent incorporation of acoustics into the scaling form.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Dimensional analysis and agreement with data collapse across Ua
hypotheses.predicted_direction: σ*_a(Ua) increases with Ua
hypotheses.notes: Serves as a practical link between measured Ua and the model parameter σ*_a

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Equation 4 provides a complete description of the rheology with or without acoustics, and can be used to predict η(φ, σ, Ua) given a small set of measurements (φ0, C(φ), σ*_0, and σ*_a(Ua)).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors state that this is a complete theory and demonstrate predictions that agree with data
hypotheses.predicted_direction: For a given Ua, the predicted η follows from the fitted F(xa); increasing Ua changes σ*_a(Ua) and thus η via Equation 4
hypotheses.notes: Highlights the predictive power and practical utility of the scaling framework with acoustics

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The dethickening under acoustic perturbations arises because the acoustic field induces a stronger interparticle repulsion, causing some particles to switch from frictional contact to a lubricated interaction, thereby facilitating flow and lowering the viscosity.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Mechanistic explanation connected to the increased σ*_a(Ua) and the friction-to-lubrication transition in contacts
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increasing Ua increases σ*_a, promoting lubrication and decreasing η
hypotheses.notes: Provides a concrete mechanism linking acoustic forcing to the observed dethickening within the scaling framework

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The mechanism of dethickening under acoustic perturbations can plausibly be attributed to microstreaming, i.e., the creation of vortical flows near particle surfaces that generate interparticle repulsion, with the effect controlled by a Stokes-number-like parameter Ω = (2π f) R^2 ρ_s / η_s.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Argued as a plausible mechanism consistent with known microstreaming physics and the experimental regime
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Higher Ua (via f, R, ρ_s, η_s) enhances microstreaming and interparticle repulsion
hypotheses.notes: Presents a plausible physical mechanism; would require targeted experiments to confirm

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Vibrations at lower frequencies (10–50 Hz) unjam dense suspensions by supplying an effective interparticle repulsive stress roughly equal to the vibration energy density, a connection that the authors relate to their acoustic perturbation framework.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Cites prior work showing a similar unjamming mechanism via an effective repulsion proportional to vibration energy density
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Higher vibration energy density promotes unjamming via increased effective repulsion
hypotheses.notes: Links acoustic perturbations to a broader vibrational unjamming picture; not directly tested in this work but used to motivate a common effective-repulsion interpretation

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Orthogonal shear perturbations may be explained by the same effective repulsion mechanism that describes acoustically driven dethickening, suggesting a unifying framework for different mechanical perturbations.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Speculative extension proposed by the authors to unify perturbation modalities under a single effective repulsion concept
hypotheses.notes: Speculative future direction mentioned in discussion; not a tested hypothesis in this work

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The scaling framework's universality (i.e., the function F(x)) extends across different materials and suspensions, and acoustics can be folded into it with a simple additive repulsion term σ*_a(Ua).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Posited as a general feature of the scaling approach and tested by collapsing data from a specific system; the authors argue for broad applicability
hypotheses.notes: Claims broad applicability of the universal scaling framework beyond the specific experimental system

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The scaling framework can be used practically to predict the acoustic energy density Ua required to achieve a target viscosity, enabling design of tunable-viscosity materials (e.g., fluid metamaterials).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Authors discuss explicit predictive use of Equation 4 to achieve a desired η by choosing Ua
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increasing Ua to reach η_target (or decreasing Ua) as dictated by Equation 4 and fitted F
hypotheses.notes: Practical implication of the scaling framework for material design

processing_notes: Identified hypotheses (explicit or implicit) by traversing the paper's Introduction, Methods, Results, and Discussion. Distinguished mechanism-level hypotheses (e.g., σ*_a ∝ Ua, σ*_total = σ*_0 + σ*_a) from modeling/principled-hypotheses (e.g., existence of two jam points, universal scaling F(x), data-collapse claims) and from speculative/generalization ideas (e.g., universality across materials, applicability to orthogonal perturbations). Each hypothesis includes the exact text where possible, axes of classification, involved variables, and a conservative confidence score. All items are unique (no duplicates across sections). If any item relied on a value estimate (δ, xc), the value is stated with the paper's reported uncertainty.

paper_title: RKKY interaction in Weyl semimetal nanowires

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: the azimuthal coupling, Jϕϕ term arises exclusively from Fermi arc states with identical spin polarization, the couplings Jµν (µ, ν = z, r) are governed by Fermi arc states with opposite spin polarizations.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Implies that the Jϕϕ term is generated solely by Fermi-arc surface states with identical spin polarization, whereas Jµν (µ, ν ∈ {z, r}) originate from FA states with opposite spin polarizations.
hypotheses.notes: Explicit claim about the distinct microscopic origin of two sets of RKKY couplings.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: The paper states that Jϕϕ arises exclusively from FA states with identical spin polarization, while Jµν (µ,ν = z,r) are governed by FA states with opposite spin polarizations.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The RKKY correlation matrix elements obey the symmetry relations Jzz = Jrr, Jrz = −Jrz, Jrϕ = −Jϕr, Jzϕ = Jϕz.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: States a symmetry pattern observed in the calculated/numerical results, relating pairs of coupling components.
hypotheses.notes: Symmetry relations among RKKY components are numerically observed and discussed.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Equations and Fig. 3 show Jzz = Jrr, Jrz = −Jrz, Jrϕ = −Jϕr, Jzϕ = Jϕz.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: For the Fermi arc surface states the correlation Jϕz = Jzϕ = Jrϕ = Jϕr = 0 becomes exactly zero.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Attri butes vanishing of all off-diagonal components to surface-state mediation alone, i.e., FA-only scenario.
hypotheses.notes: FA-only contribution yields vanishing off-diagonal couplings; nonzero off-diagonal terms require bulk contributions.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Section IV.B shows Jϕz = Jzϕ = Jrϕ = Jϕr = 0 when only FA surface states are included.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: the RKKY coupling Jϕϕ is predominately antiferromagnetic, ferromagnetic for small and large δz respectively.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Predicts the sign of Jϕϕ as a function of impurity separation along z, with a dominant AFM regime and FM regions at the ends.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: antiferromagnetic for most δz; ferromagnetic for small δz and large δz
hypotheses.notes: Direct prediction of the sign of Jϕϕ as a function of δz; confirmed by results.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Fig. 3 shows Jϕϕ is predominantly AFM; FM regions appear at small and large δz.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: the pure Fermi-arc surface-state contributions to the RKKY coupling decay as 1/(δz)^2 with impurity separation along z.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Stipulates a 2D-like decay characteristic of FA surface-state mediation.
variables_identified: RKKY coupling via FA surface states
hypotheses.notes: Decay law for FA-only contributions stated in the discussion.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Section V: ‘the coupling follows a 1/(δz)^2 dependence’ for FA surface-state contributions.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: when low-energy bulk states are included, the decay of the RKKY coupling with δz slows to 1/(δz)^η with η < 2, particularly for small cylinder radii.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Bulk-state contributions soften the decay, leading to longer-range correlations than FA-only.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: slower decay (η < 2) than FA-only (η = 2)
hypotheses.notes: Bulk contributions extend the range of RKKY interactions; decay exponent is reduced below 2.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Discussion in Section IV and VI indicates slower decay when bulk states are included; small R favors bulk contribution.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: the RKKY Hamiltonian in the WSM nanowire contains anisotropic Heisenberg exchange, Dzyaloshinskii–Moriya (DM) interaction, and a symmetric off-diagonal exchange term.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Explicit form of the effective spin Hamiltonian HEF includes these components, as derived.
hypotheses.notes: The form of the effective Hamiltonian is presented explicitly (Eq. 17).
hypotheses.evaluation_details: HEF includes Jαα S1α S2α, D terms, and Γr(S1z S2ϕ + S1ϕ S2z) as shown in Eq. (17).

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: the selection rules for chirality ξ in the low-energy cylindrical basis imply that Jzz and Jrz are nonzero only when ξ′ = ¯ξ, while Jφφ is nonzero only when ξ′ = ξ.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Stated in Appendix A and equations (18)-(20), these relations arise from the spinor structure of FA states and the cylindrical geometry.
hypotheses.notes: Selection rules connect χiralities to which RKKY components survive.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Eq. (18)-(20) show (1−ξξ′) vs (1+ξξ′) factors governing Jzz/Jφφ behaviors with ξ′ vs ξ.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: the radius R of the nanowire controls the localization of the surface states and the size of the gap in the low-energy flat bands, with the gap being inversely proportional to R.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Boundary-induced finite-size effects set a gap whose magnitude scales with inverse radius; localization of FA states also depends on R.
hypotheses.notes: Finite-radius effects control FA localization and gap size.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Section II and Fig. 2 discuss the inverse R dependence of the gap and localization of FA states.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: the Fermi-arc surface states are polarized along the ϕ̂ direction, with ⟨σz⟩ = ⟨σr⟩ = 0, and arcs with kz = ±1.44 carry exactly opposite spin polarization.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Based on the spin-density plots and the stated spin-momentum locking of FA surface states.
hypotheses.notes: FA state spin texture shown in Fig. 2; spin polarization along ϕ̂ with zero z and r components.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Fig. 2 demonstrates spin densities and ϕ̂ polarization; kz = ±1.44 give opposite spins.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: WSM nanowires are a versatile platform for engineering and simulating a broad class of spin models.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Outlook stated in the summary about potential applications and tunability of spin interactions.
hypotheses.notes: Forward-looking claim about utility as a platform for spin-model engineering.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Outlook in V. SUMMARY AND OUTLOOK discusses potential experiments and applications.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: an external tuning of the Fermi energy can modulate the sign and magnitude of the RKKY couplings by shifting contributions from Fermi-arc surface states and bulk states.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The text discusses energy scales and the dependence of oscillation frequencies on εF, implying tunability of couplings.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: sign and magnitude of RKKY terms can be tuned by εF
hypotheses.notes: εF moves the system between FA-dominated and bulk-contributed regimes, affecting oscillations and signs.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Discussion in Sec. IV and V notes εF as a control parameter for RKKY terms.

processing_notes: A comprehensive extraction of hypotheses was performed by scanning explicit formal claims (e.g., origin of Jϕϕ vs Jμν, symmetry relations, FA-only vs bulk contributions, decay laws with δz, and selection rules) and implicit inferences (e.g., designation of FA contributions as length-scale dependent, the role of radius in localization, and the speculative applicability of WSM nanowires as spin-model platforms). The classification favors distinguishing explicit mechanism/properties (causal/descriptive) from measured/derived results (confirmatory) and from forward-looking claims (exploratory). Some statements imply multiple related hypotheses; where appropriate, related sub-hypotheses were separated to avoid duplication.

paper_title: Scaling of Magnetic Domain Walls in Perpendicular Magnetic Anisotropy Systems

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Δ = C√A [Ku − μ0 Ms^2 (Nz − Nx cos^2 φ)/2]
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Proposes a unified functional relationship between material parameters (A, Ku, Ms, Nx, Nz, φ) and the domain-wall width Δ, derived analytically and tested against micromagnetic simulations.
variables_identified: DMI D (indirectly via φ and Δ in the analysis)
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Δ increases with A and Ms, decreases with Ku; Δ depends on DMI through φ and Δ via K_eff
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Unified DW width expression for Bloch and Néel walls (Eq. 9) with C depending on the width definition
hypotheses.notes: Eq. (9) is presented as the unified DW width formula; supported by micromagnetic simulations showing good agreement (relative errors < ~4%).
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Analytical derivation (Eq. 9) matched by OOMMF simulations across A, Ku, Ms variations; three DW width definitions yield the same scaling form with different C constants.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The Dzyaloshinskii–Moriya interaction (DMI) has little influence on the domain-wall width but strongly affects the domain-wall type.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: In the reported parameter ranges, varying D changes φ (wall type) with only a weak effect on Δ, indicating width is largely DMI-insensitive while wall chirality/type is DMI-determined.
variables_identified: material parameters A, Ku, Ms, Nx, Nz
hypotheses.specific_type_details: DMI controls wall type (Bloch → mixed → Néel) with Δ following Eq. (9)
hypotheses.notes: Fig. 5b shows Δ vs D with little variation; wall-type evolution with D consistent with Eq. (2) and the Bloch→Néel transition
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Width remains nearly constant across a wide D range; φ changes from 90° (Bloch) toward 0° (Néel).

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The domain wall is Bloch at zero DMI and transitions to Néel upon increasing DMI, passing through mixed configurations.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: DMI introduces chirality that energetically favors Néel character as |D| increases; this is predicted by the energy minimization and shown in simulations.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: As D increases from zero, the wall type changes from Bloch (φ ≈ 90°) to mixed (0° < φ < 90°) and finally to Néel (φ ≈ 0°)
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Corresponds to Eq. (2) and Fig. 5a
hypotheses.notes: Consistent with the DMI-driven Bloch→Néel transition and the predicted critical behavior
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Fig. 5a shows φ(D) with a transition around the Dc threshold; Eq. (2) captures φ as a function of D within the tested range

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Dc = (2 μ0 Ms^2 Nx Δ)/π
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Derives a critical DMI strength at which the wall becomes energetically Néel, linking D to material properties and Δ.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: If |D| > Dc, wall becomes Néel
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Eq. (2) implied; explicit expression Dc = 2 μ0 Ms^2 Nx Δ / π
hypotheses.notes: Dc sets the Bloch→Néel transition threshold in the D–parameter space
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Dc derived from energy minimization; transition observed and consistent with the predicted threshold

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Δ can be written in a unified form with three width definitions: Δ1 = π√(A/K_eff), Δ2 = 2.63√(A/K_eff), Δ3 = 2√(A/K_eff); thus Δ = C√A [Ku − μ0 Ms^2 (Nz − Nx cos^2 φ)/2] with C = π, 2.63, or 2 respectively.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors derive three mathematical definitions of DW width and show they all collapse to a single scaling form with a constant C depending on the definition.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: The three width definitions yield different C constants but share the same Δ ∝ √A / √K_eff scaling
hypotheses.notes: Consistent with Eq. (9) and Figs. 1–2 showing agreement across definitions
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Three width definitions produce the same scaling with A and K_eff; their differences are captured by C

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Nx must be modeled as t ln2/π∆0 − t^2/(18∆0^2) to accurately describe the DW width; Nx = 0 or Nx = t/(t+∆0) yield larger errors
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The paper compares three Nx prescriptions and shows the best agreement with the simulation data when Nx is modeled with the t ln2/π∆0 − t^2/(18∆0^2) form.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Using the best Nx model reduces width prediction error; incorrect Nx choices degrade accuracy
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Nx expression Eq. (6)
hypotheses.notes: Fig. 6 shows that the Nx = tln2/π∆0 − t^2/(18∆0^2) fit yields the smallest errors
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Compared fits with Nx = 0, Nx = t/(t+∆0), and Nx = tln2/π∆0 − t^2/(18∆0^2); the latter fits best

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Ignoring the in-plane demagnetizing factor (Nx = 0) leads to deviations in Δ up to about 7.5% across most cases; incorporating Nx improves accuracy
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Demagnetization factors alter the effective anisotropy; neglecting Nx introduces meaningful error in Δ
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Nx choice affects Δ accuracy
hypotheses.notes: Fig. 6c shows larger errors when Nx is ignored
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Relative errors with Nx ≈ 0 are higher; Nxln2 prescription yields best agreement

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The domain-wall width Δ increases with the exchange stiffness A and with Ms, and decreases with Ku (holding other parameters fixed)
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: From Eq. (9), Δ ∝ √A/√K_eff with K_eff depending on Ku and Ms; thus Δ grows with A and Ms and shrinks with Ku
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Δ increases with A and Ms; Δ decreases with Ku
hypotheses.notes: Fig. 2–4 show Δ grows with A and Ms and decreases with Ku; alignment with the analytical prediction
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Systematic variation of A, Ku, Ms in micromagnetic simulations matches the predicted trends

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The DMI has only a weak effect on the DW width even as it drives a Bloch→Néel transition, consistent with Δ following the predicted K_eff-based scaling
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Although D modifies wall type, the width Δ remains largely governed by A, Ku, Ms, Nx, and Nz via K_eff; simulations show small Δ variation with D
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Dx effect on width is weak; strong effect on wall type
hypotheses.notes: Figure 5b supports weak D-dependence of Δ; wall-type evolution documented in Fig. 5a
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Wide D range shows Δ variation is small; width scaling remains with Eq. (9)

processing_notes: Identified hypotheses are drawn from explicit equations (notably Eq. 9) and key qualitative/quantitative claims in the Abstract, Introduction, Results, and Discussion.
