Hypotheses include (i) the DW width scaling law (Eq. 9) for Bloch and Néel walls; (ii) the limited influence of DMI on width versus strong influence on wall type; (iii) the Bloch-to-Néel transition with a critical Dc and its dependence on material parameters; (iv) the correct modeling of Nx to accurately predict Δ; (v) the relationships showing Δ increasing with A and Ms and decreasing with Ku; and (vi) the equivalence of width definitions under a single scaling form. Where applicable, exact textual quotes were used to anchor the hypothesis text, and evaluation_status reflects the paper’s reported support (mostly 'supported'), with details in evaluation_details. No attempt was made to introduce external hypotheses beyond what the paper itself tests.

paper_title: On the discovery of meteoritic mineral Zolenskyite; The artificial origin should not be overlooked

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Zolenskyite is monoclinic Cr3S4-type structure (I2/m Cr3S4) rather than monoclinic C2/m CrNb2Se4 - Cr3S4 type structure reported by Ma and Rubin (2022).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The author presents an alternative crystal-structure interpretation (monoclinic I2/m Cr3S4) derived from supplementary X-ray data, arguing it is in agreement with prior literature and differs from the initial report.
variables_identified: Zolenskyite structure type (I2/m Cr3S4 vs C2/m CrNb2Se4-Cr3S4)
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Structural re-interpretation / crystal-structure indexing
hypotheses.notes: Proposes a re-interpretation of the crystal structure for Zolenskyite; testable by independent indexing and refinement.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Does the sequence (temperature, pressure, duration) = (1000 °C, 6.5 GPa, 1 h) or (520 °C, 5.5 GPa, 7 days) occur during collisions on the parent body as Ma and Rubin (2022) stated above?
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Laboratory syntheses show monoclinic FeCr2S4 can form from cubic FeCr2S4 under high pressure and temperature with quenching, implying a geologic analog might exist if similar P–T–D conditions occur during shock metamorphism.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: If the specified high-P, moderate-T sequences occur during collisions, cubic FeCr2S4 could transform into monoclinic FeCr2S4 (Zolenskyite).
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Extrapolating laboratory P–T–D conditions to natural collision environments
hypotheses.notes: Explicit discussion of genome-like P–T sequences required for natural genesis; open issue about their occurrence in nature.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The natural composition of Zolenskyite deviates from the ideal FeCr2S4 composition due to minor and trace metals.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Ma and Rubin report a natural composition Fe0.99Mn0.04Ca0.01Cr1.99S3.98 versus the ideal FeCr2S4, highlighting the relevance of minor/trace elements for real meteoritic minerals.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Real vs ideal mineral composition
hypotheses.notes: Addresses the open issue of real vs ideal compositions in meteoritic minerals.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: An artificial origin (technosignature) for Zolenskyite is plausible and should be considered in meteoritic mineral genesis.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The paper argues for open debate about artificial origin, citing discussions of non-terrestrial artifacts and technosignatures as a framework for evaluating unusual meteoritic minerals.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Technosignatures framework
hypotheses.notes: Proposes considering artificial origin as a possibility; not a test of a direct causal mechanism.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Experiments show Daubréelite can transform into Zolenskyite at high pressures and moderate temperatures, suggesting a possible genesis mechanism for Zolenskyite via shock processing.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Ma and Rubin (2022) describe experiments where Daubréelite transforms to Zolenskyite under high P and moderate T, implying a plausible laboratory-analog genesis pathway.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Daubréelite will transform into Zolenskyite under the specified high-P, moderate-T conditions.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Transfer lab transformation to natural genesis context
hypotheses.notes: Directly ties to proposed genesis via shock/metamorphism scenarios; testable by replication and comparison with meteoritic material.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Under high pressure (>10 GPa), the spinel FeCr2S4 transforms to monoclinic FeCr2S4 and exhibits metallic behavior with suppression of iron magnetic moment (Mott-like transition).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Reported in the literature that FeCr2S4 spinel under >10 GPa undergoes a transition to monoclinic FeCr2S4 with metallic behavior and reduced Fe magnetic moment, indicating a pressure-induced electronic/magnetic transformation.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increasing pressure beyond ~10 GPa induces monoclinic structure and metallic behavior with diminished Fe moment.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Pressure-induced phase and electronic/magnetic transition
hypotheses.notes: Supports the rationale for studying magnetic and transport properties of monoclinic FeCr2S4 as analogs for meteoritic minerals.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Quenching is required to obtain monoclinic Cr3S4-type FeCr2S4; slow cooling yields hexagonal NiAs-type FeCr2S4.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Historical syntheses show a spinel-to-defect NiAs transformation with specific temperature/pressure; monoclinic Cr3S4 is obtained with quenching, whereas annealing promotes the hexagonal NiAs-type.
variables_identified: crystal structure (monoclinic Cr3S4 vs hexagonal NiAs-type)
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Quenching leads to monoclinic Cr3S4-type; annealing leads to hexagonal NiAs-type structure.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Synthesis method controls crystal structure
hypotheses.notes: Grounded in historical phase-transition work; testable by controlled cooling experiments.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Investigations of the magnetic and electronic properties of monoclinic FeCr2S4 under variable temperature/pressure will reveal metallic behavior and changes in Fe Mössbauer signature consistent with a Mott-like transition.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Existing studies show monoclinic FeCr2S4 under high pressure exhibits metallic behavior and loss of Fe magnetic moment; Mössbauer results support a Mott transition, motivating further MS studies under variable T.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increasing pressure (and appropriate temperature) will yield metallic conduction and reduced Fe moment.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Magnetic and transport properties under variable T/P
hypotheses.notes: Proposed as an experimental program to characterize solid-state properties relevant to meteoritic minerals.

processing_notes: This paper presents several explicit and implicit hypotheses surrounding the structure, genesis, composition, and potential artificial origin of Zolenskyite, as well as related meteoritic sulfides (Heideite/Brezinaite). I identified eight distinct hypotheses (H1–H8) by extracting testable claims from the Introduction, open issues, and implications sections, including structural re-interpretations, natural vs ideal composition, laboratory-to-geologic extrapolations, and the provocative discussion of artificial origins. Each hypothesis was categorized along the provided taxonomy with justification, identified variables, predicted directions (where applicable), and a confidence score reflecting how clearly the hypothesis is stated or implied in the text. If you want, I can condense or expand any hypothesis with more precise quotations from the text or add alternative formulations (e.g., more explicit null hypotheses) for statistical framing.

paper_title: Localization Transition on Random Graphs with Chiral and Bogoliubov-de Gennes Symmetry Classes

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: "For the chiral RRG with diagonal disorder, the Anderson transition does not drastically differ from that in the RRG."
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Compares the localization transition between two graph ensembles (chiral RRG vs. standard RRG) and asserts similar critical behavior.
hypotheses.notes: Directly stated in the text; used to contrast the chiral case with the GOE/RRG baseline. Evidence cited via fractal dimension and LSD (Fig. 1c, 1d–e).
hypotheses.evaluation_details: The discussion around Fig. 1(c) and related panels indicates the transition does not drastically differ from standard RRG; conclusion labeled as a result in the text.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: "Zero modes in chiral RRG with |N−M|>0 are unstable to diagonal disorder within E∈(−W/2, W/2); when |N−M| is large, disordered zero modes dominate the average IPR, leading to a smoother localization transition than in the non-chiral RRG with the same mean degree."
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Zeros modes influence IPR and alter the sharpness of the localization transition; larger |N−M| enhances this effect.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increasing |N−M| and/or diagonal disorder strengthens zero-mode dominance, producing a smoother localization transition compared to the baseline RRG.
hypotheses.notes: Derived from the chiral RRG analysis; discussed in association with Fig. 1(d)–(e) and textual description of zero modes.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Zero-mode dominance and smoother transition are explicitly described in the text as N−M grows, with corresponding fractal-dimension behavior.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: "The ensembles BdG-RRG with symmetry-conserving diagonal disorder in the delocalized phase have a smaller fractal dimension compared to the usual RRG."
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Order parameter (fractal dimension) is reduced in BdG-RRG with symmetry-conserving diagonal disorder relative to standard RRG, in the delocalized regime.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: D2 is smaller for BdG-RRG with diagonal disorder than for usual RRG
hypotheses.notes: Quoted directly from the discussion in the BdG results; supported by Fig. 1(c) and related text.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Figure 1(c) shows the comparison; text states the BdG-RRG with symmetry-conserving diagonal disorder has a smaller D2 than ordinary RRG.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: "The gap is sustained with transition and remains at infinite disorder; also, it has a smaller average fractal dimension. When opposite spins have different on-site energies, the gap survives in small disorder but soon vanishes. In that range, an increase of the fractal dimension is connected to an increase of degeneracy. Symmetry breaking leads to the behavior of the fractal dimension becoming coincident with RRG."
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Symmetry-preserving diagonal disorder stabilizes the BdG gap and keeps fractal dimension small; breaking spin symmetry eventually closes the gap and pushes D2 toward RRG-like behavior.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: (a) Under symmetry-conserving diagonal disorder: gap persists and D2 remains small; (b) with spin-symmetry breaking: gap eventually vanishes and D2 increases, approaching RRG behavior as symmetry breaking strengthens
hypotheses.notes: Direct quotes describe both the gap stability under symmetry-preserving disorder and the evolution under symmetry breaking; supported by Fig. 2 and surrounding discussion.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Text explicitly discusses gap persistence vs symmetry breaking and associated fractal-dimension changes.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: "The BdG spectral density ρBdG(λ) for HBdG+A follows BdG Kesten-McKay (with a gap) and is given by ρBdG(λ) = (1/2)(dν/dλ) ρ_KM(ν) with ν^2 = λ^2 − ∆0^2."
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Provides a formal prediction for the density of states in BdG+A ensembles, including the gap structure, derived from the Kesten–McKay framework.
hypotheses.notes: Eq. (26) provides the explicit BdG-Kesten–McKay density with a gap; Eq. (25) gives the KM distribution for ν. The paper tests these against numerics.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Figure 2(a)-(b) and the accompanying text compare numerical DOS with Eq. (26).

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: "The level spacing distribution (LSD) differs from the Wigner–Dyson expectation for GOE in the BdG ensembles; a similar distribution can be met for two unconnected clusters, each of them being an Erdős–Rényi graph."
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Spectral statistics in BdG ensembles deviate from GOE; the observed LSD resembles that of two disconnected ER clusters (A and −A).
hypotheses.notes: Describes observed departure from GOE and the two-cluster interpretation; discussed in Fig. 2(c).
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Text explains LSD deviations and offers two-cluster interpretation as a qualitative description of the observed statistics.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: "The fractal dimension D2 is large when the models have an equal mean node degree."
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Empirical observation relating fractal dimension to mean degree parity/equality.
hypotheses.notes: Statement about a trend observed across ensembles; used to interpret Fig. 1(c)-(e).
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Text states that D2 is larger when mean degrees are equal; supported by the comparative panels.

processing_notes: The paper discusses explicit claims about how localization properties depend on symmetry class, graph structure (chiral BdG vs. RRG), and disorder type. Hypotheses were extracted from Introduction, Results/Discussion. Each hypothesis is classified for epistemic nature, structure, and testable predictions. Evidence cited from figures and equations (e.g., Fig. 1, Fig. 2, Eq. 25–26) supports evaluation statuses where appropriate.

paper_title: Polymer Topology and the Depletion Interaction

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: At given radius of gyration, ideal ring polymers are stronger depletants than ideal linear polymers.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Implies that polymer topology (ring vs linear) causally affects the strength of depletion interactions at equal Rg.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Ring polymers produce stronger depletion forces/energies than linear polymers at the same Rg
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Direct comparison of depletion strength between ring and linear polymers at equal Rg
hypotheses.notes: Quoted in the summary/conclusion: ring polymers are stronger depletants at equal Rg; supported by theory and MD results
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Theory states this explicitly (i); MD and scaling analyses corroborate the stronger depletion for rings at fixed Rg

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: If ideal linear and ring polymers have the same hydrodynamic radius, linear polymers induce a stronger interaction between non-adsorbing colloids.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Under equal RH, topology continues to influence depletion but the direction of the effect reverses, implying a causal link between topology and depletion strength given RH equality.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Linear polymers produce stronger depletion forces/energies than ring polymers at equal RH
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Comparison of topology at equal RH
hypotheses.notes: The paper explicitly states this reversal: with RH held constant, linear polymers are stronger depletants
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Replaced h/Rg with h/RH in theory; MD results show linear polymers dominate at equal RH

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The strength of depletion interaction is controlled by the thickness of the depletion layer, ξ.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Proposes a direct causal link between the depletion-layer thickness and the magnitude of depletion forces/energies
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Larger ξ leads to stronger depletion attraction
hypotheses.specific_type_details: ξ is the thickness that governs the strength of the depletion interaction
hypotheses.notes: ξ is introduced as the key size scale controlling depletion strength
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Theoretical framework and results show depletion strength scales with ξ; MD supports the ξ-based interpretation

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: 2ξ = ⟨∆⟩, i.e., the depletion layer thickness is equal to twice the average polymer extension along the confinement direction (⟨∆⟩).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Presents a quantitative identity linking a geometric property of confinement to a measurable polymer conformation
variables_identified: ∆ (polymer extension in the direction perpendicular to the walls)
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Identity 2ξ = ⟨∆⟩ provides a practical route to compute ξ from bulk simulations
hypotheses.notes: Equation 12 in the paper establishes the identity; MD results support it within finite-size effects
hypotheses.evaluation_details: MD simulations show ⟨∆⟩ ≈ 2ξ; discrepancy decays with chain length n^(-1/2)

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: When the distance h is scaled by the depletant-specific thickness ξ, the ratio of partition functions, the depletion force, and the depletion energy induced by linear and ring polymers become nearly identical, and the energy profile essentially matches the result for spherical, hard micelles.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Proposes a universal scaling behavior controlled by a single length scale ξ across different depletants
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Scaled depletion curves for linear and ring polymers collapse to resemble the micelle case
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Scaling h by ξ yields near-identical curves across depletants
hypotheses.notes: The text states that after scaling by ξ, the results become nearly identical and align with the micelle case
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Figure 3 and accompanying discussion show the collapse when distances are scaled by ξ

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Molecular Dynamics simulations reproduce the theoretical confinement results within finite-size effects, validating the theoretical model for both linear and ring polymers and micelles.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Provides empirical (simulation-based) support for the theoretical predictions under finite-size constraints
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Agreement improves with increasing chain length (~n^(-1/2) discrepancy reduction)
hypotheses.notes: The authors report good agreement between MD and theory within finite-size limitations
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Overlap between MD data and theoretical curves; finite-size effects reduce with longer chains

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The model assumes ideal, non-interacting polymers that are repelled by colloids (no adsorption), operating in a dilute solution and a theta-solvent.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: States the key modeling assumptions that underlie the theoretical treatment
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Assumptions used to derive analytical results
hypotheses.notes: Explicitly stated in the methods: ideal gas treatment, no adsorption, Theta solvent
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Assumptions form the basis of the model; deviations (good solvent, adsorption) would require reanalysis

processing_notes: The paper presents several explicit and implicit hypotheses about how polymer topology (ring vs linear) and size (Rg and RH) affect depletion interactions between colloids. It introduces the depletion-thickness ξ as the central length scale that governs the strength and range of depletion forces, and shows (theoretically and via MD) that (i) rings are stronger depletants than linear polymers at fixed Rg, (ii) at equal RH linear polymers are stronger, (iii) the depletion strength is controlled by ξ with 2ξ = ⟨∆⟩, and (iv) scaling h by ξ collapses results across depletants. An explicit assumption is that polymers behave as ideal, non-adsorbing chains in a dilute, thetar solvent, which underpins the derivations and simulations. Each hypothesis is listed once, with justification and without duplication.

paper_title: Metalorganic Chemical Vapor Deposition of AlScN Thin Films and AlScN/AlN/GaN Heterostructures

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: AlScN/AlN/GaN heterostructures grown on GaN templates exhibited the formation of a two-dimensional electron gas (2DEG) channel at the AlScN/AlN–GaN interface.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: States that the specific heterostructure at the AlScN/AlN–GaN interface leads to the formation of a 2DEG channel, i.e., a cause–effect claim linking the interface design to an emergent electronic state.
hypotheses.notes: Explicit causal claim about emergent 2DEG at the interface; testable via electrical measurements associated with HEMT structures

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Variation in AlScN/AlN barrier thickness within the heterostructures showed that thicker barriers yield higher sheet charge densities from both Hall and capacitance-voltage (C-V) measurements.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Proposes a causal relationship between barrier thickness and the measured 2DEG sheet charge density.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increasing barrier thickness increases sheet charge density
hypotheses.notes: Tests the effect of barrier thickness on 2DEG density across multiple samples using two measurement modalities

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: With an AlScN/AlN barrier thickness of ~30 nm, sheet charge density of 5.22x10^12 cm^-2 was extracted from C-V.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Reports a specific measured value at a given barrier thickness; serves as a numeric benchmark for barrier-2DEG relation.
hypotheses.notes: Provides a concrete numeric result tying barrier thickness to 2DEG density via C-V data

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: By controlling the Sc bubbler temperature and adjusting the Al molar flow rate, up to 13% Sc incorporation was achieved with lattice parameters closely matched to GaN.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Shows that deliberate manipulation of growth inputs enables targeted Sc incorporation and lattice matching to GaN.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Higher Sc bubbler temperature and optimized Al flow increase Sc incorporation toward ~13%
hypotheses.notes: Links process parameters to composition and lattice-matching outcome; testable via compositional analysis (XPS/XRD)

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The 2DEG carrier density increases with AlScN/AlN barrier thickness in the AlScN/GaN heterostructures, as indicated by CV and Hall measurements.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: States barrier-thickness-driven changes in 2DEG density, supported by CV and Hall data across D, E, F samples.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Thicker barrier yields higher 2DEG carrier density
hypotheses.notes: Consistent trend observed with two measurement techniques; supports barrier-engineered 2DEG density control

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The Sc concentration remains relatively uniform across the top layer of Sample D (AlScN/AlN/GaN heterostructure), with a uniform Al distribution and no significant diffusion into GaN.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: STEM-EDS analysis indicates uniform Sc distribution across the AlScN layer and minimal diffusion into GaN.
hypotheses.notes: Based on cross-sectional STEM imaging and EDS mappings; supports uniform incorporation within the film

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Extended growth duration (2.5 h) results in an interfacial AlGaN layer, indicating diffusion/alloy formation at the AlScN/AlN–GaN interface.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Longer growth time correlates with formation of an interfacial AlGaN layer, suggesting alloying/diffusion at the interface.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increased growth duration promotes interfacial AlGaN formation
hypotheses.notes: STEM observations link processing time to interfacial chemistry changes

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The bandgap energies of AlScN films decrease with increasing Sc incorporation (e.g., 5.87 eV at 6% Sc and 5.66 eV at 13% Sc; rate ≈ 39 meV per at.% Sc).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Directly ties composition (Sc content) to a measurable electronic property (bandgap).
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increasing Sc content reduces bandgap
hypotheses.notes: XPS-based bandgap estimation; aligns with theoretical expectations for low Sc regimes

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: AlScN with Sc composition in the ~9–14% range forms lattice-matched structures to GaN, enabling thicker epitaxial layers while providing a significant band-offset.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Cites literature indicating a lattice-match window for AlScN/GaN that enables thicker layers and band-offset.
hypotheses.notes: Background knowledge cited to motivate composition selection and thickness considerations

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The AlScN/AlN/GaN heterostructures developed by MOCVD can form a high-quality 2DEG channel suitable for GaN HEMT device applications.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Asserts device-relevant potential based on observed 2DEG formation and heterostructure quality.
hypotheses.notes: Concludes potential for high-performance GaN HEMT devices based on observed 2DEG behavior

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: To accurately determine 2DEG density and channel mobility, full HEMT device fabrication with a highly resistive GaN buffer layer will be necessary.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: States a procedural prerequisite for precise electrical characterization of the 2DEG channel in this material system.
hypotheses.notes: Stated as a plan for future validation of 2DEG properties in a device structure

processing_notes: All hypotheses were extracted from statements across the abstract, introduction, results, and conclusion. Duplicates were avoided by collapsing semantically equivalent claims (e.g., barrier-thickness–2DEG density relationships) into a single hypothesis where appropriate. Each hypothesis is tagged with a clear epistemic type, a simple/complex structural type (most are simple with two variables), a directional/non-directional predictive type (where the text implies a direction of change, it is noted), and a concrete set of variables. Some items reflect explicit measurements or observations and are labeled as descriptive or confirmatory where appropriate. If a hypothesis is primarily an inference or plan for future work (e.g., device fabrication to assess 2DEG properties), it is labeled as descriptive/confirmatory with notes indicating its experimental nature.

paper_title: Modelling of magnetic vortex microdisc dynamics under varying magnetic field in biological viscoelastic environments

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: "Rotating fields typically induce oscillatory dynamics and that the transition to asynchronous motion occurs at a critical frequency determined by viscosity and stiffness."
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Claims a cause-effect relation between rotating magnetic field and the regime of particle motion (oscillatory vs. asynchronous), with the transition governed by rheological properties (viscosity and stiffness).
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Rotating magnetic fields will induce oscillatory motion; increasing frequency beyond a rheology-dependent threshold causes a transition to asynchronous motion
hypotheses.notes: Directly stated in the abstract/introduction as a key qualitative prediction checked by simulations.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: "Eq. 23 shows that α(t) reaches a stationary regime after a characteristic time 1/A. This characteristic time comprises two contributions, that act in parallel: the relaxation of the elastic stress in the viscoelastic material following particle’s movement, and the friction of the surrounding material that slows down the particle rotation induced by the magnetic torques (Eq. 24). Once the steady state is reached, the oscillation of the microdisc forced by the magnetic field is a phase-shifted oscillation at the forcing frequency, whose amplitude decreases when the frequency is increased (Eqs 26–28)."
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Links the magnetic forcing to the dynamic response (stationary regime, phase shift, and frequency-dependent amplitude) through energy/friction relaxation arguments.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: α(t) will reach a stationary, phase-shifted sinusoid whose amplitude decreases with increasing ω
hypotheses.notes: Represents a concrete, testable prediction about the oscillatory response under oscillating field.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: "Eq. 27 reveals that the coupled magnetic and mechanical constraints act as a low-band filter, with a cut-off frequency, ωc:"
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Posits that rheological and magnetic couplings impose a frequency-dependent attenuation/phase effect, effectively filtering the response beyond a threshold ωc.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: System behaves as a low-pass filter: increasing ω reduces α0 and increases Φ beyond ωc
hypotheses.notes: Identifies a mechanistic frequency-filtering effect due to magnetic-elastic-viscous coupling.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: "ωc ranges between 2 and 7 · 10^4 s−1, which, in terms of frequencies, spans the interval [13 Hz – 450 kHz]."
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Quantifies the predicted cut-off frequency range given model parameters; a testable numerical prediction.
hypotheses.notes: Specific numerical prediction for the model's frequency response.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: "the amplitude of oscillations are attenuated by the viscous torque in a frequency dependent manner" and "the amplitude of oscillations as function of 1/nω"
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Asserts that viscous resistance modulates oscillation amplitude, with a specific dependence on the adimensional parameter 1/(nω).
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increasing ω or n (viscosity) lowers α0; α0 is governed by 1/(nω)
hypotheses.notes: Directly ties oscillation amplitude to rheology and forcing frequency; testable in simulations/experiments.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: "In a predominantly viscous environment (g = 0), two regimes of motion are observed, either synchronous or asynchronous with the magnetic field (Fig. 8a)."
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: States a systematic relationship between the rheological regime (viscosity-dominated) and motion regime (synchronous vs asynchronous).
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Lower viscosity yields synchronous motion; higher viscosity yields asynchronous motion
hypotheses.notes: Describes regime change as function of viscosity in the pure-viscous limit.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: "t1 ≃ 1/(gω) + π/(2ω)" (First flipping time in predominantly elastic environment) and "fel = 2f (Eq. 33)"
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Proposes explicit scaling laws for flipping times and a universal flipping frequency independent of stiffness in the elastic-dominated limit.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increasing g or ω reduces t1; fel = 2f irrespective of stiffness
hypotheses.notes: Concrete, testable scaling relations in the elastic-dominated regime.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: "fel = 2f (Eq. 33) that is independent of the stiffness of the material."
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Asserts a robust, stiffness-independent relation for magnetisation flip frequency under rotating fields.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Magnetisation flips at twice the forcing frequency, independent of E
hypotheses.notes: Direct consequence of rotating-field dynamics in the elastic/viscoelastic regimes.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: "In a viscoelastic environment where viscous and elastic resistances are comparable, the frequency of oscillation f_vis varies non-monotonically with forcing frequency; at low forcing frequency the oscillation frequency is near double the forcing frequency; at large frequency the oscillation frequency is near double the forcing frequency; at intermediate frequency it is reduced."
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Predicts non-monotonic coupling between viscous/elastic resistance and observable oscillation frequency in the mixed regime.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Oscillation frequency tracks forcing frequency in a non-monotonic way with distinct regimes (near 2f at extremes; reduced near intermediate frequencies)
hypotheses.notes: Characterises complex dynamical response in the viscoelastic (mixed) regime.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: "Pvis = dEvis/dt = ηR^3 Δα f^2" and "this energy is of the order of a few fW (2 fW for a frequency of 10 Hz)."
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Claims a quantitative estimate of viscous dissipation in the Hz regime, supporting the claim that heat generation is negligible.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Pvis scales with f^2 and is numerically small (a few fW) at Hz frequencies
hypotheses.notes: Energy dissipation is argued to be negligible heat source in the studied regime.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: "The energy stored in the surrounding environment due to elasticity, Eel ≃ γ Δα^2 = ER^3 Δα^2, is of order 0.1 fJ; this could perturb cellular processes mechanically without heating."
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Proposes a non-thermal mechanical energy transfer to the environment that could influence biomolecular structures.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Elastic energy transfer to the surrounding medium can perturb cellular processes without significant heating
hypotheses.notes: Connects mechanical energy to potential biological effects without thermal contributions.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: "cellular alterations following magnetic stimulation with such particles are to be attributed to mechanical origin and not to thermal dissipation."
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Summarizes the authors' interpretation comparing mechanical vs. thermal contributions to cellular effects.
hypotheses.notes: Direct interpretation of mechanobiology implications from the energy analysis.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: "A 2D model captures first-order influence of rheology on vortex microdisc dynamics and provides a framework for anticipating effects of viscosity and stiffness on actuation; however, extending to 3D is necessary to fully describe disc reorientation."
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: States a limitation and scope of the modeling approach, implying a directional improvement if extended to 3D.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: 2D model suffices for first-order predictions; 3D extension is needed for full accuracy
hypotheses.notes: Explicitly discusses model scope and limitations, implying a plan for future work.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: "Rotating and oscillating fields can be used interchangeably to actuate particles in the asynchronous regime."
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: States a practical equivalence between actuation modalities under certain rheological conditions (asynchronous regime).
hypotheses.predicted_direction: In asynchronous regime, rotating and oscillating fields give comparable mechanical actuation outcomes
hypotheses.notes: Offers a practical implication for experimental design.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: "the amplitude Δα of the oscillation is between 0.2-0.5 rad (for intermediate viscoelastic parameters)."
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Provides a quantitative expectation for the observable oscillation amplitude under a parameter regime.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Δα lies in the 0.2–0.5 rad range for intermediate viscoelastic parameters
hypotheses.notes: Gives a tangible bound on motion that could be tested experimentally or in simulations.

processing_notes: A comprehensive collection of explicit and implicit hypotheses embedded in the modeling framework (oscillatory vs asynchronous dynamics under rotating fields, oscillating-field response, elastic/viscous regime transitions, flip-time scalings, energy dissipation vs. mechanical work, and limitations/experimental implications). Each hypothesis is tied to specific equations or claims in the text (e.g., Eq. 23, 24, 26–28, 29, 32–33, 33, figures 6–10, and related discussion).

paper_title: Bond-resolved STM with density-based methods

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: BRSTM images can be accurately reproduced by combining the Full-Density-Based Model (FDBM) for the CO-tip force with Chen’s derivative rule for tunneling, applied to the complete molecule–substrate system, yielding BRSTM images that match experimental data for PTCDA/Ag(111) and TOAT/Cu(111).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Claims a systematic relationship between the integrated BRSTM simulation framework (FDBM+Chen) and the accuracy of the resulting BRSTM images across systems, supported by direct experimental-theory comparisons.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Using the BRSTM framework (FDBM+Chen with full molecule–substrate wavefunctions) will reproduce BRSTM features observed experimentally across the studied systems and tip–sample distances.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Integration of FDBM inputs with Chen-based tunneling for s- and p-like CO orbitals in a single framework
hypotheses.notes: Core validation hypothesis: the proposed framework faithfully reproduces experimental BRSTM contrasts for PTCDA/Ag(111) and TOAT/Cu(111).
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Figure comparisons show strong agreement between simulated BRSTM images and experiments; PP-STM limitations highlighted for TOAT/Cu(111).

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The substrate (e.g., Ag(111) for PTCDA and Cu(111) for TOAT) significantly modifies BRSTM contrasts by altering molecular orbital occupancy and by altering CO-tip deflection due to tip–sample interactions.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The paper documents substrate-induced changes (e.g., LUMO partial occupancy on Ag(111); altered pDOS) that translate into different BRSTM contrasts and CO deflection patterns.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: BRSTM contrasts and CO-deflection maps will differ with substrate, reflecting changes in orbital occupancy and tip–sample interactions.
hypotheses.notes: Supported by pDOS analysis (Figure 3), force/relaxation maps (Figure 4–5), and BRSTM comparisons (Figures 6–9).
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Substrate inclusion changes LUMO occupancy and CO relaxation, altering BRSTM images vs. non-substrate cases.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Including both σ and π tunneling channels through Chen's derivative rule is necessary, and a 1:1 mix of s- and p-wave contributions best reproduces BRSTM images for PTCDA/Ag(111) in the 280–350 pm height range.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Chen-based s- and p-type tunneling contributions must be combined to reproduce BRSTM contrast; a 1:1 weighting yielded the best agreement with experiment in the studied distance range.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: A 1:1 s:p mix will produce BRSTM features (central lobes and side structures) that closely match experimental BRSTM for 280–350 pm; deviations from 1:1 degrade the match.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Weights chosen based on prior work and matched to experimental data (Fig. 6–7).
hypotheses.notes: Demonstrates channel-requirement and weighting on BRSTM accuracy.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Figure 6 shows s and p channels; Figure 7 shows the 1:1 mixed image aligns with experimental BRSTM.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: CO deflection (tip relaxation) is essential to BRSTM and governs submolecular contrast; relaxed images exhibit sharper, bond-resolved features not present in static images, especially at short tip–sample distances.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The CO deflection feeds the BRSTM signal; static (no deflection) maps omit key features that appear when CO relaxes in response to Pauli repulsion.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Relaxed BRSTM images will show bond-resolved edges and central-lobe sharpening absent in static maps, with stronger effects at closer distances.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: CO modeled as a torsion-spring lever controlling θ; comparison between static vs. relaxed maps (Fig. 4–6).
hypotheses.notes: Directly tested by comparing static and relaxed BRSTM results.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Relaxed BRSTM images (right column in Fig. 5) show enhanced central lobes and bond-edge features absent in static maps.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Including the substrate in the DFT description is essential to obtain accurate CO-deflection maps and BRSTM images; neglecting substrate yields differences in contrast (e.g., oxygens) and weaker bonding-feature definition.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: DFT calculations with substrate yield different charge densities and electrostatic potentials, which drive the SR/ES/CO-relaxation terms used in BRSTM simulations.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Substrate inclusion will produce CO-deflection patterns and BRSTM contrasts that are more faithful to experiment than calculations without substrate.
hypotheses.notes: Shown via comparisons of force maps with and without substrate (Figure 4) and pDOS changes (Figure 3).
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Substrate affects static forces and CO deflection maps; inclusion is essential for accurate BRSTM predictions.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: LUMO occupancy changes induced by adsorption on a metal substrate (PTCDA/Ag(111)) significantly affect BRSTM contrasts via both σ and π tunneling channels, accounting for A vs B molecular-image differences.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Partial occupation of LUMO upon adsorption alters the sample wavefunction and thus the tunneling channels contributing to BRSTM.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: BRSTM contrasts will reflect LUMO occupancy differences; A and B molecules show distinct BRSTM patterns due to differential LUMO occupation.
hypotheses.notes: Supported by pDOS analysis and discussion of A/B differences (Figure 3).
hypotheses.evaluation_details: LUMO occupancy shifts the BRSTM signal via both σ and π channels.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: TOAT/Cu(111) BRSTM contrast can be accurately described only when substrate effects and adsorption geometry are included in the calculations; previous PP-STM approaches failed to reproduce the observed BRSTM contrast.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: TOAT/Cu(111) BRSTM predictions match experiment only when the molecule–substrate interaction and geometry are included; PP-STM lacking substrate treatment could not reproduce contrasts.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Including substrate and adsorption distortions will yield BRSTM images in agreement with experiment; neglecting substrate leads to mismatch.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Comparison against PP-STM approaches and inclusion of substrate in DFT and in tunneling calculation (Figure 8–9).
hypotheses.notes: Directly addresses TOAT/Cu(111) as a challenging test case.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Figure 8 shows improved pDOS and BRSTM with substrate; Figure 9 shows better agreement with experiment when substrate is included.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The BRSTM modeling framework is generalizable to other molecular adsorbates and substrates beyond PTCDA/Ag(111) and TOAT/Cu(111).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The framework is built on ab initio inputs (DFT densities, potentials) and a modular combination of HRAFM and Chen tunneling, suggesting applicability to other systems.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: The same framework will produce BRSTM predictions for other adsorbates/substrates, given appropriate DFT inputs.
hypotheses.notes: Authors mention potential for training ML models and broader applicability; not exhaustively tested.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Generalization claimed but not experimentally validated within this work.

processing_notes: The set includes explicit and implicit hypotheses spanning method validation, substrate effects, channel contributions, CO deflection, and generalization. Duplicates were avoided by ensuring each hypothesis has a distinct focal claim (e.g., framework validity vs. substrate effects vs. channel weighting vs. CO deflection vs. TOAT/TOAT vs. generalization).

paper_title: Efficient and accurate tensor network algorithm for Anderson impurity problems

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The central idea of our method is to approximate the hybridization function in the influence functional (IF) as a summation of n exponential functions. The contribution of each exponential function can be written as a GMPS with bond dimension 2, using the standard WII algorithm [64], which is a first-order approximation. Then the IF can be constructed as a GMPS by multiplying 2n such small GMPSs for imaginary-time evolution, or 8n for real-time evolution.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Describes a methodological capability: building the IF as a GMPS via a sum of exponentials and multiplying small GMPSs to form the full IF.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Construction of IF as GMPS via n exponential-function components; imaginary vs. real-time evolution
hypotheses.notes: States a procedural capability of the proposed method; serves as the basis for subsequent complexity and efficiency claims

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Crucially, we are able to prove that the WI I (White–Imam) approximation in this case is exact, due to the special properties of Grassmann algebra.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Claims an exactness property of the WI approximation when applied to the GMPS construction with Grassmann variables
hypotheses.notes: Theoremic claim tied to the algebraic structure; supported by Appendix A in the paper

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: This method gives a worst-case scaling of the bond dimension χ as 2^{2n} for imaginary-time evolution and 2^{8n} for real-time evolution.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: States the theoretical (worst-case) growth of computational resources as a function of n and evolution type
variables_identified: n (number of exponentials in the BSF decomposition)
hypotheses.predicted_direction: χ grows exponentially with n; different growth rates for imaginary-time vs real-time
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Worst-case χ ∝ 2^{2n} (imaginary-time) and χ ∝ 2^{8n} (real-time)
hypotheses.notes: Key complexity result guiding expectations for scaling with n

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: If the hybridization function is decomposed into n exponentials, the number of GMPS multiplications needed to form the IF scales as 2n for imaginary-time evolution and 8n for real-time evolution.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Describes the construction steps and resource count in the GMPS-based IF assembly
hypotheses.predicted_direction: doubling (or eightfold) number of multiplications with respect to n depending on time domain
hypotheses.specific_type_details: IMAGINARY: 2n GMPSs; REAL: 8n GMPSs
hypotheses.notes: Connects the exponential-decomposition to the practical cost of constructing the IF

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The GMPSs with site tensors in Eq.(23) are the exact exponentials of the GMPSs with site tensors in Eq.(22) (Theorem 1).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: States a formal equality between two GMPS representations; proven in the Appendix
hypotheses.notes: Formal theorem establishing exactness of the time-evolution construction

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The eTTI-IF method is more efficient and accurate than the partial IF method and the TTI-IF method, achieving at least an order of magnitude speedup in the tested regimes.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Based on numerical experiments comparing runtime and accuracy across methods
hypotheses.predicted_direction: eTTI-IF is faster and at least as accurate as the alternatives
hypotheses.specific_type_details: eTTI-IF outperforms partial IF and TTI-IF by at least an order of magnitude in the reported tests
hypotheses.notes: Key empirical claim of efficiency and accuracy advantage

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The number of exponentials n required to reach a fixed tolerance ς scales approximately as n ∝ 1/ log(ς) for the tested semi-circular and Lorentzian BSFs.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Empirically observed in Fig. 3(a) for fixed t
hypotheses.predicted_direction: n grows roughly inversely with log(ς)
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Prony + least-squares fitting to achieve target ς
hypotheses.notes: Describes a numerical behavior observed in the error-tolerance trade-off

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: For a fixed total evolution time t, the number of exponentials n remains approximately constant as t varies within the tested range (i.e., n is almost time-independent in the demonstrated regime).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Directly supported by Fig. 3(b) showing n vs t
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Observed behavior for fixed ς in the chosen BSFs
hypotheses.notes: Empirical stability of n with respect to t in the reported regime

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The maximum error of the imaginary-time Green's function G>(t) calculated with the eTTI-IF method remains on the order of 10^{-2} and stays nearly constant over the time interval considered.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Reported in Fig. 3(c) or 3(d) as the maximum error versus t
hypotheses.notes: Demonstrates robustness of accuracy over time for eTTI-IF

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Across the tested BSFs, the eTTI-IF results are closest to the partial IF results, whereas the TTI-IF results converge toward the eTTI-IF results as the parameter m increases.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Observation from comparing plots (Fig. 2 and Fig. 4) showing relative closeness of results
hypotheses.specific_type_details: eTTI closest to partial IF; TTI results approach eTTI with larger m
hypotheses.notes: Empirical method-comparison claim based on plotted results

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: For multi-orbital AIM, the eTTI-IF method can still be used to accelerate the step of building the GMPS for the IF of each flavor, though the dominant cost may shift from GMPS construction to calculating the augmented density tensor (ADT) or observables.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Stated in the discussion as a possible extension and practical caveat
variables_identified: GMPS for the IF of each flavor
hypotheses.specific_type_details: eTTI-IF applicable to multi-orbital AIM with potential cost shift
hypotheses.notes: Notes generalizability to more complex impurity problems with a caveat on cost distribution

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The method can be extended to nonadditive baths by representing the nonadditive coupling via an MPO for the operator path, such that I'[X X†] = I[U] I[V], enabling straightforward MPO–MPO multiplication to assemble the full IF.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Describes a proposed generalization to nonadditive baths and an explicit factorization strategy
hypotheses.predicted_direction: the IF for nonadditive baths can be constructed as a product of simpler MPOs
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Nonadditive bath treatment via MPO factorization
hypotheses.notes: Extends the GTEMPO/GMPS framework to a broader class of baths with an explicit construction strategy

processing_notes: The paper presents a methodological framework (eTTI-IF) for building the Feynman-Vernon IF as a Grassmann MPS via a decomposition of the hybridization function into n exponentials. Key explicit hypotheses include (i) exactness of the WI(W)I approximation within this GMPS construction (Theorem 1), (ii) worst-case bond-dimension scaling χ ∼ 2^{2n} (imaginary-time) and χ ∼ 2^{8n} (real-time), (iii) efficiency and accuracy gains of eTTI-IF over partial IF and TTI-IF as demonstrated by numerical results, and (iv) empirical scalings of n with respect to tolerance ς and time t. The hypotheses also cover generalizations to multi-orbital AIM and nonadditive baths, and the transferability of the method when extending the construction to MPO representations. All hypotheses are treated as not yet experimentally/evaluatively confirmed in this work and are marked as not_evaluated.

paper_title: Ambient-Stable Transfer-Free Graphdiyne Wafers with Superhigh Hole Mobility at Room Temperature

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: We developed a synthetic methodology for the in situ growth of two-dimensional GDY films on silicon wafer surfaces via space-confined synthesis strategy in supercritical CO2.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Describes the method used to enable in situ growth on Si wafers rather than asserting a causal mechanism for a property.
variables_identified: space-confined synthesis strategy in supercritical CO2
in situ growth of GDY on silicon wafer
hypotheses.predicted_direction: In situ growth of two-dimensional GDY on silicon wafers is achieved
hypotheses.specific_type_details: space-confined strategy in scCO2 to enable epitaxial growth on Si
hypotheses.notes: Stated methodology for achieving wafer-scale in situ growth; tests are presented later in the paper.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: In situ growth on Si via scCO2 is demonstrated with a 1×1 cm HsGDY film and characterization (Raman, XPS, SEM/TEM) in the main text and SI.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The transfer-free HsGDY wafer developed in this work does not require a spin-coated PMMA layer for transfer to silicon substrates, thereby avoiding residual PMMA contamination and enhancing the carrier mobility of HsGDY.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Removes transfer-induced contamination, which is argued to degrade mobility in GDY films.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Transfer-free fabrication increases hole mobility compared with transferred GDY
hypotheses.specific_type_details: PMMA-free, transferless process to avoid residue
hypotheses.notes: Supports the mobility improvement attributed to removal of transfer-related contamination.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: The manuscript notes no PMMA transfer and attributes high mobility to the absence of transfer-induced contamination.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The transfer-free HsGDY FET demonstrates a hole mobility of up to 3.8×10^3 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 at room temperature.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Reports an observed quantitative mobility value as measured in the device.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Higher mobility in transfer-free GDY FETs
hypotheses.notes: Direct experimental mobility value for comparison with other p-type 2D semiconductors.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Mobility measured as 3.8×10^3 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 for three independent 6-layer devices; referenced in main text and SI.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: As the HsGDY film thickness decreases from 22 nm to 2.2 nm, the hole mobility increases from 7.3×10^2 to 3.8×10^3 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Shows a thickness-dependent mobility trend in the fabricated FETs.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Thinner films yield higher hole mobility
hypotheses.notes: Directly supported by Fig. 4e and related discussion in the results.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Mobility increases as thickness decreases across multiple HsGDY FETs with different thicknesses.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Oxygen vacancies in HsGDY create dangling bonds that act as electron acceptors, generating mobile holes and yielding p-type conductivity.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Link between structural defects (oxygen vacancies) and p-type conduction via hole generation.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Presence of oxygen vacancies leads to p-type conduction via hole generation
hypotheses.notes: Mechanistic explanation supported by EPR and chemical state analyses.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: EPR shows g-value 2.002; discussion links oxygen vacancies to hole conduction.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The HsGDY FET maintains constant performance after being left in ambient air without encapsulation for 60 days.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Observed ambient stability over an extended period.
hypotheses.notes: Demonstrates ambient stability without encapsulation.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Fig. 4b shows stable transfer characteristics after 60 days in air.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The transfer-free HsGDY wafer can be integrated into standard photolithography workflows, enabling the fabrication of HsGDY FETs with precisely defined Hall bar geometries.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Demonstrates compatibility with standard lithography to pattern devices.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Photolithography enables precise Hall-bar FET geometries on HsGDY wafers
hypotheses.notes: System-level fabrication demonstration shown in Fig. 3 and related text.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Hall-bar FETs patterned directly on transfer-free HsGDY wafers using standard lithography processes.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: By precisely modulating the concentration of triethynylbenzene (TEB), HsGDY wafers with varying layer numbers can be successfully fabricated.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Links monomer concentration to film thickness/layer number.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increasing monomer concentration yields thicker/more layers
hypotheses.notes: Supported by synthesis description and supplementary figures showing thickness variation with monomer concentration.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Supplementary figures S3–S4 and text describe controllable layer numbers via monomer concentration.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: HsGDY mobility is higher than that of many other p-type 2D semiconductors, as summarized in the literature table (e.g., 3800 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 for HsGDY vs BP, Te, Ge, etc.).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Positions HsGDY in a comparative context relative to other p-type 2D materials.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: HsGDY mobility is higher than many other p-type 2D materials
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Comparison against BP, Te, Ge, MoS2, etc., in SI Table S2
hypotheses.notes: Supports the claim of superior p-type mobility in HsGDY by literature comparison.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Table S2 lists HsGDY mobility as 3800 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 vs other materials.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Copper foil provides Cu ions that migrate to the silicon surface, catalyzing the coupling of GDY monomers and enabling direct epitaxial growth on the substrate.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Proposes a mechanistic role for copper ions in activating GDY polymerization on Si.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Cu ions catalyze GDY polymerization to enable direct epitaxial growth on Si
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Space-confined scCO2 growth with Cu as catalyst source
hypotheses.notes: Describes the proposed mechanism for in situ growth on Si via copper ion involvement.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Text explains Cu ions migrate from Cu foil to Si surface to catalyze GDY coupling and epitaxial growth.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The thinnest HsGDY film grown on the silicon wafer has a thickness of approximately 2.2 nm.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Empirically measured thickness via AFM for the thinnest wafer.
hypotheses.notes: Direct measurement reported in the results.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: AFM shows a thinnest film of ~2.2 nm (Fig. 2d).

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The gate leakage current density of the SiO2 dielectric layer in the HsGDY FET is below 10^-3 A cm^-2 at ±30 V.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Device reliability/performance under bias is reported.
hypotheses.notes: Statement reported in the device characterization.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Fig. S6 shows leakage current below 10^-3 A cm^-2 at ±30 V.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: HsGDY exhibits a symmetric EPR signal with a g-value of 2.002, characteristic of oxygen vacancies.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Direct spectroscopic indication of oxygen vacancies supporting the proposed defect chemistry.
hypotheses.notes: EPR measurement presented in Fig. S10 and related discussion.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: EPR shows g = 2.002, associated with oxygen vacancies.

processing_notes: All hypotheses were extracted from explicit statements, experimental results, and mechanistic explanations spread across the abstract, main text, figures, and supporting information. Duplication was avoided by consolidating closely related claims (e.g., mobility values and thickness trends) into distinct hypotheses with separate testable predicates. Each hypothesis is classified along the full taxonomy with requested metadata, and assigned a confidence score reflecting alignment with reported data.

paper_title: The spin Hall conductivity in the hole-doped bilayer Haldane-Hubbard model with odd-parity ALM

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Here we propose a new AA-stacking bilayer HH model to realize the compensated odd-parity spin splitting in momentum space and the T-even traverse spin conductivity simultaneously, where the two layers are connected by the time reversal transformation.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Claims that constructing the bilayer model will realize both compensated odd-parity spin splitting in momentum space and a T-even traverse spin conductivity.
variables_identified: compensated odd-parity spin splitting in momentum space
hypotheses.notes: Design-level hypothesis asserting that the bilayer construction yields both the odd-parity spin splitting and the T-even spin Hall effect.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Vanishing layer-dependent electric potential VL gives rise to odd-parity ALM protected by the combined symmetry TMxy with T and Mxy being the time reversal and mirror reflection perpendicular to z axis, and the T-even traverse spin conductivity simultaneously.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Argues that set VL = 0 enforces a symmetry (TMxy) that protects odd-parity altermagnetism and enables a T-even traverse spin conductivity.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: VL = 0 leads to odd-parity ALM and T-even traverse spin conductivity
hypotheses.notes: Central symmetry-protection argument for the bilayer system.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Ek↑ ≠ Ek↓ signaling the breakdown of the odd-parity ALM in the hole-doped single-layer Haldane-Hubbard model with nonzero sublattice potentials.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Reports an energy-dispersion inequivalence between spin species under sublattice potentials, signaling breaking of the odd-parity ALM symmetry at half-filling in the single layer.
hypotheses.notes: Diagnostic diagnostic of symmetry breaking in the single-layer case; used to motivate the bilayer construction.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: As the system deviates from half-filling, i.e., with hole doping δ ≠ 0, the [C2||PE¯] symmetry no longer holds, which leads to nonzero net magnetization and the traverse spin current via nonvanishing Berry curvature.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Links deviation from half-filling to symmetry breaking, net magnetization, and a Berry-curvature–driven traverse spin current.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increasing δ away from half-filling induces nonzero magnetization and traverse spin current
hypotheses.notes: Describes mechanism by which doping induces magnetization and spin transport in the single-layer/bilayer context.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The spin current is of odd parity with respect to time reversal T, i.e., it changes sign under T.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: States a symmetry property of the spin current (T-odd behavior consistent with odd-parity ALM contexts).
hypotheses.notes: Describes the symmetry character of the spin current rather than a causal cause-effect claim.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: In the bilayer model, the up- and down-spin traverse conductivities propagate in opposite directions in the lower and upper layers, respectively, which gives rise to the substantial spin Hall conductivity.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Argues that layer-resolved spin transport with opposite directions between layers yields a pronounced spin Hall response.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Opposite-layer spin traverse currents produce a measurable spin Hall effect
hypotheses.notes: Layer-resolved transport mechanism driving the spin Hall effect in the bilayer system.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The spin Hall conductivity σSpin Hall arising from nonzero Berry curvatures is insusceptible to nonzero VL’s.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Claims invariance of the net spin Hall response to layer potential VL, despite VL affecting spin-polarized Hall components.
hypotheses.notes: Invariance claim for the net spin Hall response under VL perturbations.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The spin Hall conductivity σSpin Hall exhibits nonmonotonic behavior with hole doping δ: it first surges away from half-filling, peaks near δ ≈ 0.01, and then decreases with further hole doping.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Predicts a characteristic δ-dependence pattern of the spin Hall response observed in the calculations.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: σSpin Hall increases away from half-filling, peaks near δ ≈ 0.01, then decreases
hypotheses.notes: Explicit δ-dependence pattern reported in the results.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The proposed bilayer HH model can be extended to other stacked multi-layer systems to realize compensated odd-parity spin splitting and the spin Hall effect, i.e., a general framework for stacked systems.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Claims generalizability of the bilayer construction to broader multi-layer systems under appropriate symmetry conditions.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Generalization to other stacking arrangements yields similar odd-parity spin splitting and spin Hall behavior
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Generalization to other symmetry settings/multilayer stacks
hypotheses.notes: Extends the framework beyond the specific AA-stacking bilayer case.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: In the bilayer AA-stacking setting with vanishing VL, the energy dispersion obeys the symmetry-derived relation E(kx, ky)σ = E(−kx, −ky)−σ, i.e., E(k) for spin σ maps to E(−k) for spin −σ.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: States a symmetry-imposed constraint on the dispersion due to TMxy, used to argue compensated spin splitting in the bilayer.
hypotheses.notes: Describes a dispersion symmetry consequence of the bilayer TMxy symmetry.

processing_notes: Identified explicit and implicit hypotheses by mapping statements about model construction, symmetry protections, and predicted transport phenomena to the comprehensive hypothesis taxonomy. Duplicates were merged; each hypothesis is tied to the corresponding mechanism or prediction discussed in the text. All hypotheses are labeled with epistemic type, structure, variables, directionality, and a default not_evaluated status for evaluation.

paper_title: Two-Dimensional Altermagnetism in Epitaxial CrSb Ultrathin Films

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: 1 UC CrSb film exhibits ferrimagnetic ordering due to interfacial asymmetry, and altermagnetism is absent in this thickness.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Interfacial asymmetry breaks specific spin-space-group operations that connect opposite Cr sublattices, which disrupts the conditions required for altermagnetism, yielding ferrimagnetism and no altermagnetic spin splitting in 1 UC CrSb.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: 1 UC CrSb will be ferrimagnetic and will not exhibit altermagnetic spin splitting
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Thickness-dependent magnetic state at 1 UC
hypotheses.notes: Links interfacial symmetry breaking to the absence of altermagnetism at the thinnest limit

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: At a thickness of 7/4 UC CrSb, the film transitions to an altermagnetic state with zero net magnetization and momentum-dependent spin splitting.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Restoration of key spin-space-group symmetries at this thickness enables altermagnetic order while canceling net magnetization, leading to momentum-dependent spin splitting.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: CrSb becomes altermagnetic with zero net magnetization and spin splitting at 7/4 UC
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Phase transition at 7/4 UC
hypotheses.notes: Direct thickness-driven transition supported by STS/ARPES/DFT findings

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: There exists a critical thickness threshold of 7/4 UC for the ferrimagnetic-to-altermagnetic transition in CrSb ultrathin films.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The study reports a thickness-dependent transition with a reported critical thickness of 7/4 UC.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Threshold thickness value
hypotheses.notes: Thick- vs thin-film boundary identified as a sharp transition

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Interfacial Cr-terminated layers break spin-space-group operations, inducing local moment imbalance between Cr sites and enabling ferrimagnetism in 1 UC CrSb.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Cr-terminated interfacial layer perturbs crystal-field environments and breaks SSGs that couple opposite Cr sublattices, producing a net moment.
variables_identified: local moment imbalance Cr1 vs Cr2
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Cr-terminated interface yields ferrimagnetic order in 1 UC CrSb
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Interfacial symmetry breaking as mechanism
hypotheses.notes: Connects interface chemistry to magnetic state at the monolayer limit

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Restoration of spin-space-group symmetries [C2||C6Zt] and [C2||MZ] with increasing CrSb thickness is responsible for the onset of altermagnetism (zero net magnetization and momentum-dependent spin splitting).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The protected SSG operations are required for altermagnetic spin splitting with compensation; their restoration at higher thickness enables altermagnetism.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Restoration of SSGs yields altermagnetism with zero net magnetization
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Symmetry-protected altermagnetism
hypotheses.notes: Links symmetry restoration to the magnetic and electronic signature of altermagnetism

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The Kondo resonance peak (P1) observed in 1 UC CrSb STS data indicates a local uncompensated moment; its disappearance at 7/4 UC CrSb implies moment compensation and the onset of altermagnetism.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Kondo resonance reflects a local moment; its suppression corresponds to net moment cancellation and magnetic compensation at thicker films.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: P1 present in 1 UC and absent in 7/4 UC
hypotheses.specific_type_details: STS signature of local moment
hypotheses.notes: STS signal tracks the presence/absence of local moments with thickness

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: ARPES data show altermagnetic spin splitting along Γ-M for 7/4 UC CrSb, while 1 UC CrSb lacks such splitting; this thickness-dependent evolution supports the altermagnetic state at and above 7/4 UC.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Momentum-space spin splitting appears where altermagnetic order is protected by symmetry; its absence at 1 UC and appearance at 7/4 UC matches the proposed transition.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Altermagnetic spin splitting appears along Γ-M as thickness reaches 7/4 UC
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Thickness-dependent ARPES signature
hypotheses.notes: Direct spectroscopic evidence of altermagnetic band structure evolution with thickness

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Density functional theory (DFT) predicts a ferrimagnetic ground state for 1 UC CrSb and a nearly vanishing net moment for 7/4 UC CrSb, consistent with experimental observations of ferrimagnetism at 1 UC and altermagnetic compensation at 7/4 UC.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: DFT energy comparisons favor ferrimagnetic order at 1 UC and near-zero moment at 7/4 UC, aligning with STS/ARPES data.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: 1 UC ferrimagnetic, 7/4 UC nearly compensated
hypotheses.specific_type_details: DFT ground-state predictions vs thickness
hypotheses.notes: Theory supports experimental phase boundary and magnetic compensation

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Peaks P1 and P2 in STS spectra originate predominantly from Cr 3d states, with Sb 5p states contributing negligibly near the Fermi energy.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: PDOS analysis assigns P1/P2 features to Cr 3d orbitals; Sb 5p states lie well below the Fermi level.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Spectral origin of STS features
hypotheses.notes: Links STS signatures to Cr-dominated electronic states

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: An approximate bulk CrSb band structure at kz = 0.7π/c without spin-orbit coupling can reproduce the 7/4 UC CrSb altermagnetic spin-splitting pattern observed in ARPES, validating the employed modeling approach.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Comparison between ARPES and a simplified bulk model reproduces the altermagnetic splitting without SOC in the relevant kz slice.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Modeling assumption for ARPES data
hypotheses.notes: Assumes kz-specific bulk-like behavior to capture altermagnetic features

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: CrSb surface termination (Cr-terminated at 7/4 UC vs Sb-terminated at 1 UC) governs symmetry; this termination difference is a key factor enabling altermagnetism at 7/4 UC.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Surface termination alters local symmetry and the connectivity of spin sublattices, enabling altermagnetic order at thicker films.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Cr-terminated 7/4 UC yields altermagnetism; Sb-terminated 1 UC does not
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Termination-dependent symmetry
hypotheses.notes: Termination influences symmetry-breaking/restoration and the magnetic state

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The CrSb/Bi2Te3 heterostructure demonstrates two-dimensional altermagnetism on a non-magnetic substrate platform, illustrating the potential for integrating stray-field-free spin order into nanoscale spintronic devices.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Demonstrating 2D altermagnetism in this heterostructure suggests compatibility with device architectures and proximity effects.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Generalization to device contexts
hypotheses.notes: Forward-looking claim about integration into devices

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Cr1 and Cr2 sites in CrSb ultrathin films exhibit different orbital splittings due to their distinct coordination environments (Cr1: C3v, Cr2: Oh), leading to an enhanced local moment on Cr1 and contributing to thickness-dependent magnetism.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Crystal-field environments produce different orbital energies, giving Cr1 a larger local moment and influencing the magnetic state as thickness changes.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Cr1 carries a larger moment than Cr2, contributing to ferrimagnetism at 1 UC
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Site-specific orbital physics
hypotheses.notes: Explains the origin of the local moment imbalance in 1 UC

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Bi2Te3 valence band and Dirac surface state experience electron doping from the CrSb overlayer, shifting Bi2Te3 Dirac point by approximately 0.25 eV away from the Fermi level.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Spectroscopic data show an energy shift of the Dirac point consistent with electron transfer from CrSb to Bi2Te3.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Dirac point shifts upward by ~0.25 eV with CrSb overlayer
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Interfacial charge transfer
hypotheses.notes: Accounts for substrate band structure modification due to overlayer

processing_notes: The set above consolidates explicit thickness-dependent claims, interfacial symmetry-breaking mechanisms, ARPES/ST S measurements, and DFT validation into discrete hypotheses. Duplicates across sections (e.g., ferrimagnetism at 1 UC, altermagnetism at ≥7/4 UC, and symmetry restoration) have been merged into single hypotheses per distinct claim. All hypotheses are labeled as not yet evaluated, with justification drawn from the paper's results and discussions.

paper_title: Near-room-temperature antiferromagnetism in Janus Fe$X$F ($X$ = O, S) monolayers

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The FeF2 monolayer is an antiferromagnetic semiconductor with a low Néel temperature TN of 18 K.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Describes the ground-state magnetic order and a characteristic transition temperature of FeF2, a directly testable property.
hypotheses.notes: Explicitly states the AFM ground state and TN as properties of FeF2.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: FeF2 monolayer exhibits a wide direct band gap of 3.37 eV at the Γ point.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Describes a electronic structure property (direct gap magnitude and location) of FeF2.
hypotheses.notes: Describes electronic structure consistent with the FeF2 ground state.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Janus FeXF (X = O, S) monolayers exhibit enhanced magnetic moment and direct exchange coupling.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Claims a change in magnetic moment and a direct exchange mechanism due to Janus substitution.
hypotheses.notes: Based on the reported Janus design outcomes; suggests qualitative enhancement in moments and exchange.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: For FeOF and FeSF monolayers, the Néel temperature TN is enhanced to 207 K and 248 K respectively, higher than FeF2.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Comparative statement across FeF2 and its Janus derivatives about AFM stability.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: TN FeOF < TN FeSF < TN FeF2? (observed values show TN FeOF = 207 K, TN FeSF = 248 K, both higher than 18 K for FeF2)
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Comparison of TN across FeF2 and Janus FeXF monolayers
hypotheses.notes: Explicit comparative claim about TN elevation due to Janus substitution.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Under biaxial compression, the FeSF monolayer achieves TN = 274 K at −2% strain (and remains AFM semiconducting with a stable easy axis).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Predicts strain-induced enhancement of AFM order (TN) in FeSF and its retention of semiconducting nature.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: TN increases under compression to 274 K at −2% strain
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Effect of strain on TN for FeSF vs unstressed state
hypotheses.notes: Direct, testable prediction about strain-engineered TN.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Under biaxial strain, the FeOF and FeSF monolayers maintain semiconducting behavior and the direction of their easy magnetization axis stays stable within ±5% strain.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Claims robustness of electronic and magnetic anisotropy properties under strain.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Stability under strain across FeOF and FeSF
hypotheses.notes: States robustness of electronic/magnetic properties under strain.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The enhanced antiferromagnetism in both FeXF monolayers primarily stems from the strengthened direct AFM coupling J1.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Argues that the dominant mechanism for TN enhancement is the direct Fe–Fe AFM exchange (J1).
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Stronger J1 leads to higher TN
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Direct exchange (J1) dominates AFM stabilization in FeOF/FeSF
hypotheses.notes: Connects structural/chemical changes to magnetic ordering via J1.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: In FeOF monolayer, the J1, J2, J3 exchange constants are such that J1 is strongly negative and dominates AFM coupling; in FeSF, J1 is negative and larger in magnitude with sizable J3 and J2 contributions, reinforcing AFM order.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Describes the quantified exchange interactions as reported in the study.
hypotheses.notes: Supports the mechanism via quantitative exchange parameters.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The Néel temperature TN is proportional to the magnitude of the AFM exchange J1 (TN ∝ |J1|) for FeOF and FeSF monolayers.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: States a direct, causal relation between J1 magnitude and TN.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: TN increases with larger |J1|
hypotheses.specific_type_details: TN ∝ |J1| for FeOF and FeSF
hypotheses.notes: Articulates a proposed scaling relationship for TN based on J1.
