hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Authors attribute unreliability to MFT due to interstitial XC-field contributions causing partitioning ambiguities, especially in multisublattice systems.
variables_identified: interstitial contributions to the exchange–correlation field
hypotheses.predicted_direction: MFT cannot reliably determine spin-spiral energies or exchange parameters in multisublattice systems
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Interstitial XC field contributions; multisublattice ambiguity; MFT not suitable
hypotheses.notes: Direct claim about limitations of MFT in VASP for multisublattice magnets.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Across all three materials, our SC dispersions closely follow the TDDFT spectra in both shape and magnitude, confirming the reliability of the SC spin-spiral approach for capturing low-energy spin-wave excitations.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: SC dispersions echo the TDDFT spectra in shape and magnitude; this validates the SC method for low-energy magnons.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: SC vs TDDFT comparison for Fe, Co, Ni
hypotheses.notes: Validation of SC approach against TDDFT for low-energy magnons.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The spin-wave stiffness constants D extracted from the SC dispersion increase from Fe to Ni (Fe: 220 meVÅ^2, Co: 544 meVÅ^2, Ni: 757 meVÅ^2), and the Fe and Co values are in good agreement with experimental data and prior theoretical estimates, while the Ni value substantially overshoots the experimental range, indicating a breakdown of the Heisenberg mapping in the weak-moment, itinerant regime.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Reported D values show trend and agreement/disagreement with experiments.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: D_Fe and D_Co are close to experiment; D_Ni deviates by overshooting
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Comparison of D with experimental values; Ni deviation noted; Heisenberg mapping breakdown discussed
hypotheses.notes: Tests the validity of Heisenberg mapping and SC predictions for D.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: In multisublattice Mn-based full Heuslers, the MFT within VASP substantially overestimates the spin-spiral energies—by up to approximately 800% in our tests—compared with fully SC spin-spiral calculations.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Direct comparison shows MFT energy overestimation relative to SC by large percentages in multisublattice Heuslers.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: MFT overestimates spin-spiral energies relative to SC (up to ~800%) in multisublattice Heuslers
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Comparison of MFT vs SC energies in multisublattice Mn-based Heuslers
hypotheses.notes: Highlights limitation of MFT in complex magnetic structures.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The SC spin-spiral exchange parameters Jij for Mn-based full Heusler compounds Cu2MnAl, Ni2MnSn, Pd2MnSn, and Ni2MnGa are in excellent agreement with previous theoretical studies (Galanakis et al., Sasioğlu et al.), validating the accuracy of the SC approach for Mn-based Heuslers.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: SC Jij closely matches literature; supported by multiple comparisons.
variables_identified: previous theoretical Jij (Galanakis et al., Sasioğlu et al.)
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Comparison of Jij against literature values for Mn-based Heuslers
hypotheses.notes: Demonstrates transferability/accuracy of SC approach in these compounds.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Within Mn-based full Heuslers Cu2MnAl and Pd2MnSn, the RPA Curie temperatures are in excellent agreement with experimental data and previous MFT-based studies, while Ni-containing compounds require a full multi-sublattice RPA treatment; MFA values for Ni-based compounds remain within about 10% of experimental values.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: RPA results for Cu2MnAl and Pd2MnSn align with experiment and literature; Ni-based need multi-sublattice RPA; MFA approximations approximate experimental values.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: RPA Tc closer to experimental than MFA for Cu2MnAl and Pd2MnSn; Ni-based compounds require multi-sublattice RPA; MFA remains within ~10% of experimental values
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Tc predictions via MFA and RPA compared to experiment and prior studies
hypotheses.notes: Assesses finite-temperature predictions and method-specific applicability.

processing_notes: The paper explicitly tests two spin-spiral implementations (self-consistent SC and magnetic force theorem MFT) and reports on their accuracy across three elemental ferromagnets (Fe, Co, Ni) as well as Mn-based full Heusler compounds. Eight distinct, testable hypotheses were identified, spanning method validity (SC vs MFT), reliability of exchange parameters Jij, magnon dispersions, spin-wave stiffness D, and Curie temperatures via MFA/RPA, with explicit references to literature comparisons and experimental data. Each hypothesis has been classified along the taxonomy axes and anchored to explicit text in the paper. Duplication was avoided by treating each distinct claim (method accuracy, method limitations, cross-method comparisons, and finite-temperature predictions) as separate hypotheses. Where quotes were available, exact phrasing from the text was used. If a claim is later nuanced or qualified in the discussion, it is reflected in the justification and notes.

paper_title: Low-field all-optical detection of superconductivity using NV nanodiamonds

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: A microwave-free all-optical near-zero-field cross-relaxation magnetometry scheme using NV centers in nanodiamonds can detect the Meissner effect and measure the penetration field in a superconductor.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Proposes a relationship between the measurement technique (microwave-free NV-ND cross-relaxation magnetometry) and observable superconducting phenomena (Meissner effect and penetration field).
variables_identified: NV center cross-relaxation signal in nanodiamonds
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Demonstration of microwave-free all-optical cross-relaxation magnetometry to observe Meissner effect and measure penetration field in superconductors.
hypotheses.notes: Core claim of the study: viability of the method to observe Meissner physics without microwaves.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The cross-relaxation feature of NV centers in nanodiamonds exhibits a temperature-dependent contrast and linewidth, with contrast increasing with temperature while linewidth remains roughly constant over 5–294 K.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Relates temperature to measurable NV-ND cross-relaxation parameters (contrast and FWHM).
hypotheses.predicted_direction: contrast increases with temperature; linewidth remains roughly constant
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Cross-relaxation parameters extracted via Lorentzian fits across 5–294 K.
hypotheses.notes: Characterization of temperature dependence used to optimize measurements near Tc.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The temperature dependence of the cross-relaxation feature can be modeled with a Lorentzian function to determine parameters such as FWHM and contrast.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Assumes Lorentzian form applies to the cross-relaxation feature as a function of temperature to extract parameters.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Lorentzian fitting used to derive signal parameters across temperatures.
hypotheses.notes: Relies on a modeling assumption to quantify the cross-relaxation signal.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Tc of YBa2Cu3O7−δ can be determined from the peaks in the derivative of the lock-in output of the modulated cross-relaxation fluorescence; two distinct peaks are observed due to oxygen inhomogeneity.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Derivatives of the modulated signal are used as a proxy to locate the superconducting transition; observed split is attributed to sample inhomogeneity.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Two peaks at 87.5 K and 88.2 K; peak centers taken as Tc; related to oxygen inhomogeneity.
hypotheses.notes: Direct measurement approach to estimate Tc using optical signals; sample inhomogeneity noted as cause of dual peaks.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Near the edge of the YBCO film, the local magnetic field is amplified relative to the center due to flux focusing, causing earlier onset of flux penetration as temperature decreases.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Edge geometry and flux focusing alter local field experienced by NV centers, modifying penetration behavior.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: H_edge < H_center (penetration occurs at lower edge field)
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Center vs edge measurements show reduced threshold at edge (e.g., ~0.5 mT vs 3.64 mT at center at 83 K).
hypotheses.notes: Accounts for edge-enhanced field effects and vortex entry behavior observed in the data.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Microwave-free all-optical NV-ND magnetometry provides a less invasive and easier-to-implement alternative to microwave-based NV magnetometry for probing superconductors.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Claims comparative advantages in invasiveness and ease of implementation for the microwave-free approach.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: microwave-free method offers better invasiveness and ease of implementation
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Argues for reduced perturbation and simpler implementation versus ODMR/microwave approaches.
hypotheses.notes: Justifies methodological choice and potential advantages over standard NV-based approaches.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The widefield NV-ND approach enables imaging of superconducting properties over a field of view, and can be extended to study vortex dynamics and complex geometries.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Extends the demonstrated localized measurements to spatial imaging, enabling broader investigations.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Projection to imaging superconducting properties over a field of view and applicability to vortices and complex geometries.
hypotheses.notes: Forward-looking claim about generalization and applicability beyond the current measurements.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Agglomeration of nanodiamonds reduces magnetic signal amplitude and diminishes spatial resolution; suppressing ND agglomeration and achieving uniform ND distribution maximizes sensitivity.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Posits a cause-effect relation between ND agglomeration and measurement quality.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: increased agglomeration lowers amplitude and degrades resolution
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Emphasizes ND dispersion control to maximize measurement sensitivity.
hypotheses.notes: Important experimental design consideration for optimizing NV-ND sensing.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The magnetic field of a single perpendicular vortex in the YBCO thin film can be approximated by the monopole model, with Bz(r=0,h) ≈ Φ0/(2π(h+z0))^2.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Provides a theoretical description used to interpret Bz measured by NV centers at height h.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Monopole model assumptions for near-surface vortex fields in a thin film.
hypotheses.notes: Standard modeling assumption used to relate measured signals to vortex fields.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The spatial gradient of the magnetic field from a vortex decays with height as |∇B| ∼ (h+z0)^-3.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Specifies how the field gradient scales with sensor-to-sample distance in the monopole picture.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Gradient scaling derived from monopole-model field distribution.
hypotheses.notes: Used to interpret sensitivity to distance and geometry.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Salt-and-pepper deposition of nanodiamonds reduces agglomeration and yields more uniform ND distribution, improving sensitivity.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Relates a deposition method to ND distribution and ultimately to sensing sensitivity.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: improved sensitivity with salt-and-pepper deposition
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Design choice to optimize ND distribution and measurement sensitivity.
hypotheses.notes: Design-related hypothesis about ND dispersion improving performance.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Two distinct Tc peaks observed at 87.5 K and 88.2 K arise from oxygen inhomogeneity in the YBCO film.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Connects the observed split in Tc to sample inhomogeneity in oxygen content.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Two peaks at 87.5 K and 88.2 K attributed to oxygen distribution.
hypotheses.notes: Explains why Tc appears as two close transitions in the derivative signal.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: NV-ND cross-relaxation magnetometry can image vortices and critical phenomena in superconductors with complex geometries.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Extends demonstrated measurements to spatial imaging and more intricate geometries.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Generalization to vortex imaging and complex geometries beyond the tested sample.
hypotheses.notes: Forward-looking claim about applicability to broader superconducting systems.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The sensor-to-surface distance h is determined by ND size; smaller ND yields shorter h and improved sensitivity.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Connects ND physical size to proximity to the sample and to sensing sensitivity.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: smaller ND size reduces h and increases sensitivity
hypotheses.specific_type_details: ND size sets standoff and thus affects detected field strength and resolution.
hypotheses.notes: Assists experimental design decisions regarding ND size.

processing_notes: The hypotheses above are distilled from the Introduction, Experimental Technique, Results, and Discussion sections. They include explicit methodological claims (implementation and comparative/performance hypotheses), as well as implicit mechanistic and generalization assumptions (modeling, edge effects, ND dispersion, and geometry). Some items are direct testable claims (e.g., Tc and Hc1 detection), while others are forward-looking or design-oriented (generalization to imaging, ND deposition). All hypotheses are treated as non-duplicative and one per entry; related ideas (e.g., edge effects vs center behavior) are kept in separate items to reflect distinct claims.

paper_title: Dipole-quadrupole model and multipole analysis of resonant membrane metasurfaces

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The Dipole-Quadrupole Model (DQM) can accurately describe the reflectance and transmittance spectra of membrane metasurfaces under arbitrary angles of incidence.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors develop and validate a semi-analytical DQM to analyze resonant spectral features calculated numerically for irradiation at arbitrary angles, and they compare DQM results with full numerical simulations showing very good agreement.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Model validation/assessment of DQM against full numerical results for oblique incidence
hypotheses.notes: DQM is presented as a general tool for oblique incidence; its accuracy is validated numerically (Sec. 2–4, Fig. 4–6).
hypotheses.evaluation_details: DQM results agree with full numerical simulations across incidence angles

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: In membrane metasurfaces, electric and magnetic quadrupole moments must be included (in addition to dipole moments) to correctly describe resonant features, especially when the unit cell approaches or exceeds the wavelength scale.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors state that quadrupole moments are necessary to study membrane metasurfaces, where l/λ ≥ 1 or the material occupies the entire unit cell, and that CDM alone is insufficient to explain observed spectral features.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Including quadrupole moments improves the accuracy of spectral descriptions compared to dipole-only models
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Necessity of EQ and MQ for accurate modeling of membrane metasurfaces
hypotheses.notes: CDM is insufficient for membrane metasurfaces; quadrupoles are emphasized in Sec. 2 and related discussions.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Quadrupole contributions are shown to be essential in spectral decompositions (e.g., Fig. 4–5).

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: There exists an optimal unit cell (UC1) that yields the best agreement between DQM and full numerics and provides faster convergence; other UCs yield poorer matches due to edge concentration thereby enhancing higher-order multipoles.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Comparative analysis across four symmetric unit cells shows UC1 best matches full numerics and converges faster with fewer multipoles; UC2–UC4 exhibit differing multipole content and resonance behavior.
variables_identified: unit cell configurations UC1, UC2, UC3, UC4
hypotheses.predicted_direction: UC1 provides closer agreement to full numerical results than UC2–UC4
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Optimal unit-cell choice for dipole-quadrupole analysis of symmetric membrane metasurfaces
hypotheses.notes: UC1 concentrates matter in the central part of the cell, reducing higher-order multipoles and improving convergence (Sec. 3.1).
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Figure 2 and related discussion demonstrate the UC1 superiority.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: An asymmetric unit cell excites additional out-of-plane dipole moment pz and in-plane quadrupole moments Qxx, Qyy and Mxy, leading to changes in spectral features compared to symmetric cells.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The paper shows that asymmetry activates extra multipoles (pz, Qxx, Qyy, Mxy) and alters resonance positions; this is linked to the asymmetric field distribution within the unit cell.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Asymmetric UC excites additional multipoles and shifts/reshapes resonances
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Impact of unit-cell asymmetry on multipole excitations and spectra
hypotheses.notes: Fig. 3 demonstrates the excitation of pz and Qxx/Qyy/Mxy in the asymmetric unit cell and their spectral impact.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Asymmetry-induced multipole excitations are discussed in Sec. 3.2 and Fig. 3.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Fano resonances in membrane metasurfaces are of a hybrid type arising from interference between dipole and quadrupole moments; their zeros (anapole) correspond to suppressed radiation and are linked to near-field enhancement.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The analysis shows that Fano features are due to resonant dipole and quadrupole contributions, with zeros corresponding to anapole states and associated near-field enhancement.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Mechanism and interference of multipole contributions leading to anti-Fano (anapole) features
hypotheses.notes: Fig. 5 and Fig. 7 discuss odd/even multipole separation and the anapole condition in the reflection spectrum.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Anti-Fano analysis and even/odd decomposition are presented in Sec. 5.1.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Some resonances in TM polarization are almost angle-independent over a wide range of incidence angles because in-plane ED (px) and out-of-plane MQ (Myz) are coupled and in phase, causing the resonance to resist angular shift while narrowing with angle.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The angular dependence analysis shows that the TM resonance around 500 nm is governed by the in-plane ED and out-of-plane MQ that stay in phase as angle changes, leading to small spectral shifts and sharper resonances with angle.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Resonance position remains nearly constant with θ; resonance narrows as θ increases
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Angle-insensitive TM resonance due to ED-MQ coupling
hypotheses.notes: Section 5.2 discusses an incidence-angle independent resonance and attributes it to ED and MQ coupling (Fig. 8).
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Fig. 4 and Fig. 8 illustrate the near-constant spectral position with θ for TM/TE cases.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Bianisotropic membrane metasurfaces exhibit direction-dependent near-field properties and multipole content, even though reciprocity ensures that total reflectance/transmittance is independent of excitation direction.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors show that top vs bottom excitations yield different multipole contributions and near-field distributions due to bianisotropy, while reciprocity preserves far-field spectra.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Multipole content and near-field distributions differ with excitation direction due to bianisotropic coupling
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Direction-dependent near-field behavior in conical/partially perforated membranes
hypotheses.notes: Fig. 9 discusses differences between top and bottom excitations due to bianisotropic coupling.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Differences in multipole contributions and near-field patterns are shown in Sec. 5.3.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Quasi-bound states in the continuum (quasi-BIC) can be realized in symmetric membrane metasurfaces under oblique incidence, and their formation is governed by specific multipole interplays (e.g., pz, Mxy, Qxz, Myz).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The study demonstrates quasi-BIC under oblique incidence in symmetric unit cells, with the resonance arising from coupled multipoles and high-Q transmission features.
variables_identified: multipole set (pz, Mxy, Qxz, Myz, etc.)
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Quasi-BIC occurs at specific oblique angles and wavelengths and is tunable by incidence
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Quasi-BIC realization in membranes with elliptical holes (Sec. 5.4 and Fig. 10)
hypotheses.notes: Sec. 5.4 discusses quasi-BIC under oblique incidence in several membrane geometries, including elliptical holes.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Figure 10 and related text illustrate quasi-BIC conditions under oblique illumination.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The Dipole-Quadrupole Model (DQM) is applicable to non-centrosymmetric unit cells (e.g., conical holes and surface voids) and can capture their far-field spectral features.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors explicitly extend the method to non-centrosymmetric UCs and show good agreement with full numerics for conical holes and related geometries.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Applicability of DQM to non-centrosymmetric membrane metasurfaces
hypotheses.notes: Section 5.3 discusses bianisotropic membranes including conical holes and partially perforated cases.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Demonstrated via Fig. 9 and related discussion.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The spectral features of membrane metasurfaces, including lattice Kerker effects and anti-Fano (anapole) states, can be explained and predicted by the interference between odd and even multipole subsets within the DQM framework.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: By dividing r into odd and even multipole subsystems, the authors show how lattice Kerker suppression and anapole conditions arise and how they shape the reflectance spectrum.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Anti-Fano lattice Kerker and anapole resonances explained via odd/even multipole interference (Sec. 5.1)
hypotheses.notes: Fig. 7 provides the odd/even decomposition and the associated phase relations for anti-Fano and Kerker phenomena.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Sec. 5.1 discusses the anti-Fano mechanism and associated near-field enhancements.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: DQM remains valid in a diffractionless spectral range, i.e., where only zero-order diffraction contributes to the far field; higher-order diffraction is neglected as a modeling assumption.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The model explicitly accounts for zero-order diffraction and assumes higher-order diffractions are negligible in the spectral region considered.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Diffraction-limited applicability of DQM
hypotheses.notes: The paper notes that the method is valid in a diffractionless spectral range where only the specular (zero-order) contributes.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Sec. 2 and Sec. 4 discuss zero-order diffraction and its dominance in the considered regime.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The DQM framework provides a practical procedure to extract multipole moments from a numerically calculated field distribution within a unit cell to reconstruct the reflectance and transmittance spectra.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors outline a six-step procedure (Sec. 2.4) to obtain dipole and quadrupole moments from numerical field distributions and to reuse them in analytical expressions for r and t.
variables_identified: electric field distribution in central cell
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Methodology for extracting multipoles from numerical data to synthesize spectra
hypotheses.notes: Sec. 2.4 lists a practical workflow for applying DQM to real metasurfaces.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: The six-step procedure is described explicitly in Sec. 2.4.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The field enhancement inside the holes and at the surface of the membrane can be significantly increased through design optimization (e.g., thickness, hole diameter, and period), enabling enhanced sensing and nonlinear effects.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors report substantial near-field enhancements (e.g., ~50× inside holes and ~70× at the surface) and discuss the potential for field amplification through optimization.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Field enhancement as a design target for sensing/nonlinear optics
hypotheses.notes: Fig. 8(d1-d3) and accompanying text quantify field enhancements and emphasize design optimization.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Section 5.2 discusses field enhancement and Fig. 8 shows quantitative values.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Elliptical-hole membranes demonstrating quasi symmetry-protected BIC under oblique incidence can be tuned to the same resonance wavelength by geometry (e.g., tilt) or by illumination angle, offering a simple mechanism to switch resonances.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The study reports quasi-BIC behavior in membranes with elliptical holes, showing that tilt and oblique incidence can realize quasi-BIC at similar wavelengths and can be used for tunability.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Quasi-BIC resonance can be achieved at a given wavelength by adjusting tilt or incidence angle, enabling tunability of the resonance
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Quasi-BIC in elliptical-hole membranes via oblique incidence (Sec. 5.4, Fig. 10)
hypotheses.notes: Sec. 5.4 discusses quasi-BIC for tilted elliptical holes and parallel configurations.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Fig. 10 and associated text illustrate quasi-BIC behavior under oblique incidence.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The Dipole-Quadrupole Model (DQM) can be extended beyond membrane metasurfaces to other perforated metasurfaces, including bianisotropic configurations such as conical and partially perforated holes (and paired elliptical holes).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors explicitly state that their results can be applied to other perforated metasurfaces, including bianisotropic membrane metasurfaces with various hole geometries.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: DQM generalizes to other perforated geometries with consistent spectral predictions
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Transferability of DQM to non-membrane perforated metasurfaces and BMMs
hypotheses.notes: Conclusion mentions extending results to conical/partially perforated and paired elliptical holes (Sec. 6).
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Sec. 6 explicitly discusses applicability to other perforated metasurfaces.

processing_notes: The hypotheses above are extracted from the Introduction, Results, Discussion, and Conclusions, including explicit claims and implicit assumptions about model validity, unit-cell optimization, symmetry/asymmetry effects, resonance mechanisms (Fano/anapole, Kerker, quasi-BIC), polarization/angle dependencies, bianisotropy, and generalizability to other geometries. Duplicates were removed by collapsing identical claims across sections (e.g., model validity, unit-cell choice, and symmetry effects).

paper_title: Proof of the exact diffusion constant via first passage time in quasi-periodic potentials

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The effective diffusion constant can still be described by the Lifson and Jackson (LJ) formula D* = D/(⟨exp(βU)⟩⟨exp(−βU)⟩), where the average is redefined as ⟨exp(βU)⟩ = lim_{L→∞} (1/L) ∫_0^L exp(βU(x)) dx.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Explicitly states that the LJ formula applies with a redefined (large-interval) average in quasi-periodic potentials.
hypotheses.notes: Proposes an extension of the LJ formula to quasi-periodic potentials via a large-interval average.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Mean first passage time (MFPT) analysis can be used to determine the diffusion constant, via D* = lim_{L→∞} L^2/(2τ(0)).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: States a direct relation between MFPT and the diffusion constant in the large-L limit.
hypotheses.notes: Defines D* in terms of MFPT under absorbing boundaries at ±L.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The MFPT equation De^{−Φ(x)} ∂/∂x [e^{Φ(x)} ∂τ(x)/∂x] = −1 with τ(±L) = 0 is valid for the first-order Langevin equation with time-dependent potentials, without requiring U(x) to be periodic.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: States a general MFPT equation applicable to time-dependent potentials beyond periodic U(x).
hypotheses.notes: Extends MFPT framework beyond strictly periodic potentials.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: For a periodic potential Φ(x) = U cos(x) with period a = 2π, the MFPT-based derivation recovers the Lifson–Jackson formula for the diffusion constant.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Claims that the periodic-case MFPT solution yields the standard LJ result as a consistency check.
hypotheses.notes: Validates the LJ formula in the well-known periodic case using MFPT and Jacobi–Anger expansion.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: For a quasi-periodic potential with two incommensurate periods, Φ(x) = Ua cos(2πx/a) + Ub cos(2πx/b) with a/b irrational, the diffusion constant satisfies D* = D ⟨exp(Φ)⟩⟨exp(−Φ)⟩, and in the large-x limit ⟨exp(Φ)⟩ → I0(Ua) I0(Ub), so D* = D I0(Ua)^2 I0(Ub)^2.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: States the generalized LJ form for a two-frequency quasi-periodic potential and identifies the large-scale averages with Bessel I0 values.
hypotheses.notes: Extends LJ-type diffusion to a two-incommensurate-frequency potential via MFPT; yields a product of Bessel I0 factors.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: For a general potential with N incommensurate frequencies, Φ(x) = Σ_{i=1}^N Ui cos(2πx/ai) with pairwise irrational ai, the diffusion constant obeys D* = D / ∏_{i=1}^N I0(Ui)^2.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Extends the two-frequency result to N incommensurate terms via Jacobi–Anger expansion and factorization of averages.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Generalization to multi-frequency quasi-periodic potentials
hypotheses.notes: Represents a broad generalization of the LJ-type relation to N incommensurate components.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Cross terms from interference between different periods do not persist in the large-L limit (i.e., interference terms vanish as L → ∞).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Claims that interference between different periods disappears in the large-interval limit, allowing factorization of averages.
hypotheses.notes: Justifies the decoupling (factorization) of averages in the incommensurate case.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: A finite well-defined limit exists for the averages ⟨exp(±Φ(x))⟩, i.e., lim_{L→∞} (1/L) ∫_0^L exp(±Φ(x)) dx is finite.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: States the essential condition for the LJ extension to hold in quasi-periodic potentials.
hypotheses.notes: Condition for the existence of a well-defined D* in general potentials.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: D* is always decreased with increasing incommensurability of the periods (i.e., with larger incommensurate content), since |I0(U)| > 1 for U ≠ 0.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Serves as a qualitative consequence of the general LJ-type result in the presence of incommensurate components.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increasing incommensurate content decreases D*
hypotheses.notes: Relates diffusion strength to the size of the incommensurate components via I0.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The results can be generalized to much more general potentials and even higher dimensions, provided the limit ⟨exp(±Φ(x))⟩ exists in the same sense.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: States broad applicability beyond one-dimensional quasi-periodic potentials.
hypotheses.notes: Claims broad generalizability of the LJ-type diffusion relation.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The quasi-periodic potential U(x) can be approximated by a periodic function with arbitrary accuracy by choosing a sufficiently large period L, so that the LJ formula can be applied again.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Uses an approximation argument to connect quasi-periodic potentials to periodic ones in the large-L limit.
hypotheses.notes: Bridges quasi-periodic and periodic treatments via large-L approximation.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The MFPT-based framework implies a Gaussian-like form for the probability distribution in time, p(x,t|x0) ≈ A exp(−Φ(x)) (1/√(4π D* t)) exp(−x^2/(4 D* t)) (up to normalization).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: States a specific approximate form for p(x,t|x0) consistent with the MFPT framework and LJ-type diffusion.
hypotheses.notes: Connects MFPT derivation to an approximate Gaussian-like form for the propagator.

processing_notes: This output extracts and classifies the hypotheses (explicit and implicit) present in the paper. Each hypothesis is mapped to the taxonomy axes (epistemic type, structural type, predictive type, etc.) and linked to the specific equations/claims in the text. Duplicate statements refer to the same underlying claim and are consolidated into a single hypothesis per item. Confidence scores reflect how directly the text asserts the claim as a testable or definitional proposition. If a claim is primarily methodological (e.g., MFPT as the defining route to D*), it is treated as descriptive of the method and its consequences rather than a causal or predictive claim requiring an experiment.

paper_title: Fluidity and morphological stability of an amorphous thin film with radiation-induced defect kinetics

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Inclusion of radiation-induced defect kinetics in a free-surface continuum model of an irradiated amorphous thin film will lead to emergence of new morphological phenomena, such as instabilities or qualitative changes in viscous surface relaxation, compared to models with constant η⁻¹.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The study explicitly motivates coupling defect kinetics to the continuum viscous-thin-film model and asks whether new phenomena or qualitative changes in relaxation emerge when defect kinetics are included (versus a constant mean η⁻¹).
variables_identified: free-surface continuum model / viscous thin film
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Inclusion of defect kinetics will produce new morphological instabilities or qualitatively different surface-relaxation behavior
hypotheses.notes: Explicitly posed as a core research question about the impact of defect kinetics on morphology and relaxation.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The depth-averaged ion-enhanced fluidity hη⁻¹i scales with ion flux f as √f for fixed ion energy and irradiation angle, reflecting heating-driven defect annealing effects on fluidity.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The results report a √f scaling of the depth-averaged fluidity under controlled energy and angle, aligning with prior work.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: hη⁻¹i increases with the square root of f
hypotheses.notes: Directly stated in Results: Section 4.2; serves as a testable scaling law.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The depth-averaged fluidity η⁻¹(θ) follows approximately a p cos(θ) dependence (flux-diluted cos-like dependence) rather than a pure cos(θ) dependence, for given flux and energy.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The results indicate an angle dependence close to p cos(θ) rather than cos(θ), suggesting a flux-diluted modification of the angular scaling.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: η⁻¹ decreases with θ following a scaled cos(θ) form: ∝ p cos(θ)
hypotheses.notes: Described in Results: Fig. 3; observed near cos(θ) with a flux- and energy-dependent scale factor.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Under temperature-controlled conditions, the energy dependence of the mean fluidity is η⁻¹ ∝ E¹/⁴ (i.e., scales as the fourth root of energy).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors report an E¹/⁴ scaling for η⁻¹ when temperature is controlled, consistent with proposed fluidity scaling theories.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: η⁻¹ ∝ E¹/⁴
hypotheses.notes: Explicitly stated in Results: Fig. 3; energy dependence under thermal control.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Thermally enhanced defect annealing can lead to a loss of fluidity as the irradiation flux f and energy E are increased, even at temperatures typical of irradiation.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The Discussion notes that heating can anneal defects, reducing fluidity and thus impacting pattern formation.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: increased f or E reduces η⁻¹ due to thermally enhanced recombination
hypotheses.notes: Discussed as a key thermal effect in Results/Discussion: heating can reduce fluidity through defect annealing.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: In the long-wave (small-k) limit, the linear growth rate from the defect-kinetics–coupled model, Σ_PM, agrees with Orchard's formula for a uniform η⁻¹ (Σ_Orchard).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The paper explicitly compares Σ_PM with Σ_Orchard and notes broad agreement in the long-wave limit.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: as k → 0, Σ_PM → Σ_Orchard; deviations occur at higher k
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Comparison of linear stability growth rates between defect-kinetics–coupled model and Orchard’s uniform η⁻¹ result
hypotheses.notes: Direct numerical comparison shown in Figures 1–2; long-wave agreement is emphasized.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: In the limit DI/DV → 0 (self-diffusion of interstitials negligible relative to vacancies), CI0 is given by CI0 = [f YI P0(z)] / [4πλ CV0 DV].
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Derived in the DI/DV → 0 simplification (Appendix) as part of the steady-state analysis.
hypotheses.notes: Limiting form used to simplify steady-state defect equations.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The steady state of the coupled defect-kinetics–viscous-film system is governed entirely by the defect fields (CV0, CI0); other fields are slaved to these defect variables.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The linearization notes state that the steady state is determined by the defect fields and that, e.g., u0 = 0 follows from this structure.
hypotheses.notes: Stated in Linearization details: steady state is governed by defect fields.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The local viscosity η is given by 1/η = 1/η* + CV ηI⁻¹ + CV ηV⁻¹, i.e., the defect contributions add linearly to a small baseline fluidity.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Equation (7) defines η as a sum of baseline and defect-contribution terms; this is the closure used in the model.
hypotheses.notes: Fundamental constitutive relation used to couple defect kinetics to fluidity.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The model’s linear-stability predictions (Σ_PM) are broadly consistent with established theory and experimental trends for ion-induced surface relaxation, particularly in the long-wavelength regime (low k).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The paper argues that Σ_PM is broadly consistent with Orchard’s long-wave result and aligns with known experimental trends under certain conditions.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Comparison of linear stability growth rates with Orchard’s results and with/without defect inhomogeneity
hypotheses.notes: Supports the usefulness of the defect-kinetics–coupled model for predictive patterning, with caveats at higher k.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Model predictions will be able to reproduce or inform experimental observations of ion-induced patterning in silicon and related semiconductors, provided Qr, DV0, DI0, and ε_em are chosen plausibly and temperature effects are accounted for.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors emphasize that, with reasonable parameter choices, the model yields predictions in the ballpark of experimental observations and can guide fitting across fluxes and energies.
hypotheses.notes: Bridges modeling results to potential experimental validation; treats as a general expectation.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The simplifications made (neglecting noble-gas implantation, sputtering removal of defects, and phase-change at the amorphous–crystalline interface) do not overturn the qualitative conclusions about defect-kinetics–driven fluidity and linear stability in the parameter regimes studied.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors explicitly acknowledge simplifications and discuss qualitative robustness; this implies an implicit hypothesis about robustness of qualitative trends.
variables_identified: simplifications (no noble gas implantation, no sputter removal, no phase-change)
hypotheses.notes: Qualitative robustness claim; used to justify first-step modeling.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Amorphous thin films irradiated at off-normal angles (θ > 0) can be modeled in a translating frame with a downward translation speed V(θ) that accounts for ongoing sputtering and interface motion.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Given boundary conditions and translating reference frame described in the Model section, the framework assumes a translation velocity V(θ) tied to sputter yield.
hypotheses.notes: Modeling framework uses a translating frame to account for erosion; not a test of a hypothesis per se.

processing_notes: The paper motivates a coupled defect-kinetics–viscous-thin-film model and reports several testable predictions about (i) whether defect kinetics qualitatively alter morphology and relaxation, (ii) how depth-averaged fluidity η⁻¹ scales with flux, angle, and energy (with specific exponents under temperature control), and (iii) how linear stability compares to Orchard’s constant η⁻¹ result in the long-wavelength limit. Hypotheses include explicit scaling laws, model-comparison claims, and limiting-case relations derived in the analytical sections. Some items are explicit model assumptions rather than testable predictions; these were annotated accordingly. Confidence scores reflect how clearly each item is stated as a testable claim in the paper and whether it is treated as a result (confirmatory) or an open question (exploratory).

paper_title: Defect-driven incoherent skin localization

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Anderson localization is therefore fragile under dephasing; even strongly disordered lattices yield uniform asymptotic probability distribution Pf ∝ (1, 1, ..., 1)^T.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Implies that dephasing causes the destruction of Anderson localization, producing a uniform long-time distribution regardless of disorder.
hypotheses.notes: Describes the qualitative change in localization behavior under incoherent dynamics in symmetric lattices.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Text states that for fast dephasing, Anderson localization is fragile and that strongly disordered lattices yield a uniform asymptotic distribution Pf ∝ (1,1,...,1)^T; derives β1=1 and βj<1 under dephasing.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: A single lossy defect leads to a localized eigenmode at the defect site and, under dephasing, the long-term probability distribution Pf ∝ |v1⟩ predominantly occupies the largest segment L ≡ max(q − 1, N − q).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: A lossy defect creates a non-Hermitian perturbation that yields a defect-localized eigenmode; under fast dephasing the asymptotic distribution concentrates in the largest lattice segment adjacent to the defect.
variables_identified: single imaginary defect at site q (εn = iV δn,q)
largest segment length L = max(q−1, N−q)
hypotheses.predicted_direction: localization toward the larger lattice segment (edge on the side with more sites from the defect)
hypotheses.notes: Describes how a lossy defect shapes the asymptotic distribution under incoherent dynamics.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Eq. (8) gives βdef for the defect; Pf ∝ |v1⟩ predominantly occupies the largest segment as shown in Fig. 2.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Asymptotic localization occurs at the larger edge if M < 2 max{EL, ER} (forming an edge-well state).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Relative spacing between two defects and the edges determines where the dominant mode resides according to a hard-wall approximation.
variables_identified: inter-defect region length M = q2 − q1 − 1
edge lengths EL = q1 − 1, ER = N − q2
hypotheses.predicted_direction: localization at the larger edge (edge-well state)
hypotheses.notes: Characterizes how two defects partition the lattice and where the dominant mode localizes.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Eq. (10) and associated discussion show edge localization when M < 2ER.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Asymptotic localization occurs in the inter-defect region if M > 2 max{EL, ER} (forming a bulk-well state).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: When inter-defect spacing is large, the dominant mode resides between defects rather than at an edge.
variables_identified: inter-defect region length M = q2 − q1 − 1
edge lengths EL = q1 − 1, ER = N − q2
hypotheses.predicted_direction: localization in inter-defect (bulk-well) region
hypotheses.notes: Specifies a bulk-well state formed between defects when inter-defect separation is large.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Eq. (10) and discussion describe M > 2 max{EL, ER} leading to inter-defect localization; Fig. 2 bottom illustrates bulk-well behavior.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: For r defects, the dominant eigenmode is nonzero in the region (edge or bulk segment) determined by Mmax ≡ max1≤k≤r−1 Mk = qj+1 − qj − 1 and EL/ER, as given in Eq. (11).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Generalizes the two-defect results to multiple defects, linking defect geometry to the support of the dominant mode.
variables_identified: r lossy defects at sites q1,...,qr
hypotheses.predicted_direction: dominant mode localized in edge or bulk segment according to Eq. (11)
hypotheses.notes: Extends the defect-driven localization picture to multiple defects.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Eq. (11) provides the region where v1 is nonzero; Fig. 3 demonstrates edge- and bulk-localization behavior for multiple defects.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: In a lattice with four identical lossy defects at qi = {3, 10, 18, 26} under dephasing l = 0.01, the eigenmode |v1⟩ forms a right-edge state and the averaged probability density shifts toward the right edge through directional jumps, demonstrating a pronounced dynamical incoherent skin effect.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Strategically placed defects combined with fast dephasing produce directed edge localization and measurable edge-skewed dynamics.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: localization toward the right edge with directional jumps
hypotheses.notes: Demonstrates defect-engineered dynamical incoherent skin effect with multiple defects.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Fig. 3 (top row) shows |v1⟩ and the evolution of P(z) with drift toward the right edge and defect locations marked.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: In Hatano–Nelson lattices under dephasing, the incoherent propagator exhibits non-Hermitian skin localization with Pf ∝ (e^{-2h}, e^{-4h}, ..., e^{-2hN})^T; the right eigenmode g_R1 confirms NHSE in the incoherent regime.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Non-reciprocal hopping (h>0) plus dephasing drives asymmetric edge localization; right/left eigenmodes relate via a similarity transformation, yielding the predicted edge-skewed distribution.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: edge-localized distribution toward one boundary (left for increasing h in the presented setup)
hypotheses.notes: Connects Hatano–Nelson non-Hermiticity to INCOHERENT skin effect under dephasing.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Fig. 3(c) shows g_R1 and Pf ∝ (e^{-2h}, e^{-4h}, ..., e^{-2hN})^T; discussion explains the NHSE in the incoherent regime.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: There exists a threshold coupling asymmetry h_c such that, for fixed defect strength V, increasing h drives a transition from defect-driven incoherent skin effect toward a coupling-induced skin effect; the threshold h_c increases with V.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: In the presence of both defects and coupling asymmetry, the system shows a transition from defect-dominated localization to coupling-dominated localization as h grows; the critical value depends on V.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: transition from edge-localization at defects to left-edge or more extended localization as h crosses h_c
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Tests the relative dominance of defect-driven vs coupling-driven skin effects as h varies
hypotheses.notes: Describes an interaction/competition between two localization mechanisms and a regime boundary.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Fig. 4 shows ⟨n⟩f and Δn_f as functions of h and V; text describes a threshold where defect-driven localization yields to coupling-driven localization.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Dephasing can be used to engineer a dynamical incoherent non-Hermitian skin effect without relying on asymmetric couplings; strategically engineered configurations of lossy defects plus fast dephasing yield directional edge localization and are robust to moderate disorder.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Demonstrates a route to skin effects by combining defects with dephasing rather than relying on intrinsic nonreciprocity.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: edge localization toward a boundary determined by defect layout
hypotheses.notes: Highlights dephasing as a controllable resource for localizing waves in non-Hermitian lattices.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Conclusion states a novel route to dynamical incoherent skin effect without asymmetric couplings; defect configurations plus fast dephasing enable directional jumps to an edge.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The reported incoherent skin effect is robust to disorder: since the coexistence of real disorder leaves S unchanged up to O(l^2), the incoherent skin effect persists at any level of disorder.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Asserts robustness of the effect to real (on-site) disorder because the incoherent propagator is unchanged to leading order in l.
hypotheses.notes: States robustness of the defect-driven incoherent skin effect to disorder.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: The manuscript notes that S is unchanged up to O(l^2) in the presence of real disorder, ensuring robustness of the effect.

processing_notes: The hypotheses listed above are drawn from explicit and implicit claims across the paper (Introduction, Model, Results, and Conclusions). Several items are framed as predictive mechanisms or comparative outcomes (defect-driven vs coupling-driven skin effects). Each hypothesis includes the factual quote where possible, plus a concise justification, identified variables, and the evaluation status based on the authors' results and figures (e.g., Fig. 2, Fig. 3, Fig. 4).

paper_title: Hydration Free Energies of Linear Alkanes: Evaluating and Correcting Classical Force Field Predictions with Different Water Models

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: All tested water models systematically overestimate the hydration free energies of linear alkanes when Lorentz-Berthelot mixing rules are used.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The paper states that all tested water models overestimate the hydration free energies for linear alkanes, indicating a systematic bias across water models.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: ∆Ghyd predicted by TraPPE-UA with any tested water model will be higher than experimental/group-contribution values
hypotheses.notes: Baseline descriptive claim that motivates subsequent calibration of interaction parameters.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Four-site water models (TIP4P/2005 and OPC) yield hydration free energies closer to experimental/group-contribution values for linear alkanes than three-site models (SPC/E and OPC3).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The results show larger deviations for 3-point models compared with 4-point models across the alkane series.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Four-site models produce smaller deviations than three-site models.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Comparison of error magnitudes between 3-site and 4-site water models in predicting ∆Ghyd.
hypotheses.notes: Supports the claim that water model geometry (site count) affects accuracy for non-polar solutes.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Using cavity free energies, the alkane-water Lennard-Jones well-depth parameter ϵ must be increased by approximately 5% relative to the Lorentz–Berthelot value to reproduce experimental hydration free energies.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The methodology shows that updating ϵ by about 5% brings simulated ∆Ghyd in line with experimental/group-contribution data.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increase ϵ by ~5% relative to Lorentz-Berthelot to reproduce experimental ∆Ghyd
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Calibration of ϵ using cavity formation energy
hypotheses.notes: Key calibration strategy linking cavity energetics to interfacial interactions.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The HH-alkane model (a reparameterized TraPPE-UA force field) with TIP4P/2005 reproduces experimental hydration free energies up to eicosane.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The results demonstrate excellent agreement between HH-alkane/TIP4P/2005 and experimental/group-contribution data up to C20.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Hydration free energies match experimental/group-contribution values up to C20
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Validation up to C20
hypotheses.notes: Demonstrates transferability of calibration to larger linear alkanes within the tested range.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: GAFF+SPC/E overestimates ∆Ghyd by roughly 1 to 1.6 kJ/mol across the studied alkanes.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: GAFF+SPC/E results are reported as consistently higher than experimental/group-contribution values.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: GAFF+SPC/E yields larger (more positive) ∆Ghyd than experimental
hypotheses.specific_type_details: GAFF vs TraPPE-UA in hydration predictions with SPC/E
hypotheses.notes: Quantifies a systematic bias for GAFF+SPC/E relative to TraPPE-UA benchmarks.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: GAFF+TIP4P/2005 tends to overestimate ∆Ghyd for small alkanes (≤ C5) but underestimates it for larger alkanes.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The results show size-dependent deviations for GAFF+TIP4P/2005.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Overestimates ∆Ghyd for small alkanes; underestimates for large alkanes
hypotheses.specific_type_details: GAFF vs TraPPE-UA comparison across alkane sizes
hypotheses.notes: Highlights limits of GAFF with TIP4P/2005 across the alkane series.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: GAFF all-atom alkane model yields hydration free energies closer to experimental/group-contribution values than TraPPE-UA with TIP4P/2005 across the alkane series.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The paper notes GAFF produces smaller deviations than TraPPE-UA in several comparisons.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: GAFF+TIP4P/2005 yields smaller deviation than TraPPE-UA+TIP4P/2005
hypotheses.specific_type_details: GAFF vs TraPPE-UA performance across alkanes
hypotheses.notes: Positioning GAFF as relatively more accurate than TraPPE-UA in this study.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Shifting the Lennard-Jones potential by its value at the spherical cutoff leads to systematic deviations in hydration free energy estimates.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The study reports that shifted potentials increase deviation from experimental/group-contribution values.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Potential shift increases deviation from experimental values
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Effect of shifting LJ potential on hydration free energies
hypotheses.notes: Demonstrates a methodological pitfall in using shifted potentials.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Tail corrections added to the shifted potential recover results similar to the unshifted potential, though this agreement can be fortuitous.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The paper discusses that tail corrections can bring shifted-potential results back toward unshifted results, but the match is often coincidental.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Tail corrections will restore agreement with unshifted potentials for ∆Ghyd
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Assessment of tail corrections on shift-induced deviations
hypotheses.notes: Highlights limitations of tail corrections in fully correcting shift-related biases.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: For the alkane–water systems studied, g(r) ≈ 1 for r > σ, justifying the approximation g(r) = 1 in equation 6.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Radial distribution functions shown in Figure 5 are close to 1 beyond a weak first peak, supporting the assumption.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Assumption used in cavity-based energy decomposition
hypotheses.notes: A modeling assumption that underpins the energy decomposition in the study.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Unshifted Lennard-Jones potentials yield hydration free energies closer to experimental/group-contribution values than shifted potentials.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The results indicate that shifting the LJ potential worsens agreement with experiments, i.e., unshifted is better.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Unshifted LJ yields ∆Ghyd closer to experimental values than shifted LJ
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Comparison of shifted vs unshifted LJ in hydration calculations
hypotheses.notes: Supported by the observed deviations when using shifted potentials.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: OPC and OPC3 do not improve predictions for non-polar solutes.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The paper notes that OPC and OPC3 do not improve predictions for non-polar solutes, despite their design for bulk electrostatics.
hypotheses.notes: Identifies limitations of OPC/OPC3 for hydrophobic solutes.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Cavity-formation free energies can be used to calibrate alkane–water Lennard-Jones parameters to reproduce hydration free energies.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The study leverages cavity-formation energies as the basis for updating ϵ to match ∆Ghyd with experiments.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Calibrating ϵ using cavity-formation energy will reproduce experimental ∆Ghyd
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Calibration workflow using cavity energies
hypotheses.notes: Central methodological step enabling improved predictions for non-polar solutes.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: GAFF yields closer deviations than TraPPE-UA, placing GAFF as more accurate for hydration free energies.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The paper states GAFF is closer to experimental/group-contribution values than TraPPE-UA in several comparisons.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: GAFF provides smaller deviations than TraPPE-UA in ∆Ghyd
hypotheses.specific_type_details: GAFF vs TraPPE-UA performance across alkanes
hypotheses.notes: Positions GAFF as relatively more accurate within the presented comparisons.

processing_notes: Comprehensive extraction of hypotheses from the Hydration Free Energies of Linear Alkanes paper. Includes explicit hypotheses about water-model performance, parameter calibration via cavity energies, validation of HH-alkane, GAFF comparisons, and methodological notes on shifted vs unshifted Lennard-Jones potentials. Duplicates were avoided; hypotheses are labeled with epistemic type, structure, and testability to support structured synthesis.

paper_title: Roles of Electrically Excited Magnons in Unidirectional Magnetoresistance of Metallic Magnetic Bilayers

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Nonequilibrium magnons, indirectly excited by the electric field, can suppress UMR by absorbing spin angular momentum from conduction electrons.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: States a mechanism by which nonequilibrium magnons reduce the unidirectional magnetoresistance via angular-momentum transfer from electrons to magnons.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Nonequilibrium magnons suppress UMR
hypotheses.notes: Explicit mechanism stated in abstract linking magnon excitations to reduced UMR.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The magnitude of UMR ζUMR arises from the combination of current-induced spin accumulation in the FM layer and the spin asymmetry of mobility, such that ζUMR ∝ Pν δns.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Directly ties two ingredients (δns and Pν) to the nonlinear UMR response via a product relation.
variables_identified: current-induced spin accumulation in the FM layer (δns)
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Nonzero UMR requires both δns ≠ 0 and Pν ≠ 0; ζUMR ∝ Pν δns
hypotheses.notes: The paper explicitly states two ingredients and a product form for ζUMR.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Electron–magnon interactions transfer angular momentum between electron and magnon subsystems, which reduces the electronic spin accumulation in the FM and thereby reduces UMR.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Describes how interconversion and cross-diffusion drain electron spin accumulation, lowering UMR.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Stronger electron–magnon coupling reduces δns and lowers UMR
hypotheses.notes: Describes cross-diffusion and interconversion as a mechanism for reducing UMR.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: UMR decreases with increasing exchange coupling Jsd; stronger electron–magnon interaction transfers more spin angular momentum from conduction electrons into magnons.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: States a direct causal link between Jsd and UMR through spin-angular-momentum transfer to magnons.
variables_identified: spin angular momentum transfer to magnons
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increasing Jsd decreases UMR
hypotheses.notes: Directly reported result showing suppression of UMR with stronger electron–magnon coupling.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: In the intermediate Jsd regime, the UMR is smaller for larger magnon thermal relaxation time τth, since faster magnon thermalization (smaller τth) allows more electron spin accumulation to contribute to UMR.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Links magnon thermalization dynamics to the available electron spin accumulation that drives UMR.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Smaller τth (faster magnon thermalization) increases UMR; larger τth decreases UMR
hypotheses.notes: Based on reported trends in Fig. 4 and accompanying discussion.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: In the weak-Jsd limit, the UMR approaches a constant value set by spin-dependent elastic scattering, and in the strong-Jsd limit the UMR becomes independent of τth.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Describes limiting behaviors of the coupled system as Jsd → 0 or large.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Weak Jsd: UMR tends to a constant; Strong Jsd: UMR independent of τth
hypotheses.notes: Stated convergence behavior in the text (limits of Jsd and τth).

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The magnon momentum-relaxation time τm does not affect UMR (curves are insensitive to τm) in the studied parameter range.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Reports observed insensitivity of UMR to τm in the inset of Fig. 4.
hypotheses.notes: Empirical observation within the model; not a causal claim about τm itself.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: At the NM|FM interface, conservation of total spin angular momentum requires that the spin current injected from the NM be partitioned into both electron and magnon spin currents on the FM side, js,z(0−) = js,z(0+) + jm,z(0+).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Derived from the generalized boundary conditions governing interfacial spin transfer and interconversion.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: A portion of NM spin current is converted into FM electron and magnon spin currents at the interface.
hypotheses.notes: Directly quoted boundary condition illustrating interfacial spin transfer and conversion.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The interfacial magnon current is proportional to the spin Hall angle θsh, leading to a linear scaling of the UMR coefficient with θsh.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Stated boundary-theory result: interfacial magnon current ∝ θsh and thus ζUMR ∝ θsh.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increasing θsh increases ζUMR linearly
hypotheses.notes: Explicit claim linking θsh to linear UMR scaling via interfacial magnon currents.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Magnon contributions to UMR produce distinct experimental fingerprints in the thickness, magnetic-field, and temperature dependencies of UMR, enabling experimental identification of magnonic contributions.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Claims that magnonic effects imprint characteristic, testable patterns in key control parameters.
hypotheses.notes: Stated as experimental fingerprints to identify magnon involvement.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: ζUMR exhibits a peak as a function of FM thickness dF, at a characteristic length set by the 'dressed' electron spin diffusion length λ+s (i.e., dF ≈ λ+s).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The peak arises from the interplay of diffusion and cross-diffusion in the coupled electron–magnon system.
variables_identified: dressed electron spin diffusion length λ+s
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Peak in ζUMR at dF ≈ λ+s
hypotheses.notes: Described in the thickness dependence discussion and Fig. 6 of the paper.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The peak position in ζUMR(dF) shifts toward smaller FM thickness with increasing temperature because the effective diffusion length λ+s decreases as temperature rises.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Directly tied to the temperature dependence of λ+s via enhanced thermal magnon scattering.
variables_identified: dressed electron spin diffusion length λ+s
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Peak moves to smaller dF as T increases
hypotheses.notes: Predicted shift of the thickness-UMR peak with temperature due to λ+s(T).

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Magnons can play an active role (constructive for UMR) by modifying Pν itself through electron–magnon scattering, producing an Ex-dependent contribution to Pν and thereby to UMR.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Speculates that magnon dynamics can feed back into spin-mobility asymmetry and the nonlinear response.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Active magnon contribution can enhance or modify UMR via Ex-dependent Pν
hypotheses.notes: Discussed as a possible extension beyond the passive role established in the current framework.

processing_notes: All hypotheses were distilled from the paper sections (Introduction, Results/Discussion, and Conclusions) and quotes were used where possible. Duplicates were avoided; each hypothesis is unique and mapped to the authors’ explicit or implied testable claims about magnon–electron coupling and its influence on unidirectional magnetoresistance in FM|NM bilayers.

paper_title: Uniformity Bias in Ground-State Sampling Induced by Replica Alignment in Quantum Monte Carlo for Quantum Annealing

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: QMC tends to produce uniform ground-state probabilities, unlike QA’s biased distribution.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The Introduction states that PQMC sampling yields uniform ground-state probabilities whereas QA exhibits biased (unfair) sampling.
variables_identified: PQMC ground-state distribution across degenerate ground states
QA ground-state distribution across the same degenerate ground states
hypotheses.notes: Explicit comparison between PQMC and QA ground-state sampling fairness; used as a testable claim about sampling fairness.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: PQMC shown to approach uniform sampling more closely than QA; discussed as a fundamental difference in ground-state sampling fairness.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The origin of this bias is the alignment of replicas along the Trotter axis.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors identify replica alignment along the Trotter axis as the mechanism that suppresses kink configurations and drives uniform sampling.
variables_identified: replica alignment along the Trotter axis
hypotheses.notes: Central mechanistic claim linking replica correlations to the observed bias.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Logical and empirical linkage shown between replica alignment and reduced kink statistics leading to uniform sampling.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The relative weight with respect to the kink-free configuration is v(K)/v(0) = exp (−2βJ⋆K).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Derivation of how kink configurations are energetically penalized relative to the kink-free state.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Each additional kink is exponentially suppressed by exp(−2βJ⋆K)
hypotheses.notes: Explicit formula used to explain suppression of kink configurations and hence replica alignment.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Equation (12) provides the weight ratio; used to rationalize the suppression of kink-containing configurations.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Two mechanisms contribute to this alignment: an energetic suppression of kink configurations caused by ferromagnetic coupling between replicas, and an entropic reduction due to the limited number of admissible kink positions at smaller Trotter numbers.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The paper explicitly enumerates energetic and entropic contributions as drivers of replica alignment.
hypotheses.notes: Combines energy and entropy mechanisms as joint causes of replica alignment.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Discussed in the text and illustrated with equations and figures (e.g., impact of J⋆ and M on kink suppression).

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The choice of transition rule in QMC, such as the Metropolis or heat-bath update, affects the rate of convergence to the stationary distribution and leads to differences in the degree of uniformity bias.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The Results discuss differences in convergence and bias depending on Metropolis vs heat-bath updates.
hypotheses.notes: Empirically observed influence of transition rules on bias and convergence.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Figure 5 shows different error landscapes under MP vs HB, indicating rule-dependent bias/convergence.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The heat-bath method achieves its minimum error at larger M and τ than the Metropolis method.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Directly reported in the Results section comparing MP and HB.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: HB minimizes error at larger M and larger τ than MP
hypotheses.notes: Observed rule-dependent optimization landscape for simulation error.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: HB shows minimum error at higher M, τ compared with MP as reported in Fig.5.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Continuous-time QMC (M → ∞) can improve the simulation accuracy. As shown, the alignment bias induced by discretization scales as a power of β/M and therefore vanishes in the continuous-time limit.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The Discussion argues continuous-time QMC removes Trotter discretization bias and aligns more with QA.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Bias vanishes as M → ∞
hypotheses.notes: Direct claim that removing Trotter discretization improves fidelity to QA dynamics.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Text states that discretization bias scales with β/M and vanishes in the continuous-time limit; continuous-time QMC proposed as free of Trotter errors.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Increasing the Trotter number toward the continuous-time limit can reduce the uniformity bias, and alternative transition rules may help design QMC schemes that either better emulate QA or intentionally promote uniform sampling when desired.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Discussion posits that both a higher M (toward continuous time) and different transition rules could reduce bias or tailor sampling.
hypotheses.notes: Proposes methodological avenues to mitigate or control the bias.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The M-dependence of the expected number of kink positions per site E[K]/N increases almost linearly with M (quantified by q(s, M)), i.e., an entropic effect drives the M dependence of kink statistics.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The paper derives and reports E[K] = NM q(s, M) and shows linear growth with M attributed to entropy.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: E[K]/N increases linearly with M
hypotheses.notes: Links entropic contribution to M-dependent kink statistics via E[K] and q(s, M).
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Shown in Figure 4 and equation (13); exact curve lies below equilibrium due to finite annealing (freeze-out) effects.

processing_notes: The paper investigates hypotheses about (a) how well PQMC reproduces QA ground-state sampling fairness, (b) the mechanism behind any observed uniformity bias, (c) how discretization (Trotter number) and transition rules influence bias, and (d) how continuous-time limits and alternative update schemes could mitigate or exploit this bias. I extracted explicit claims and mechanistic inferences that function as testable hypotheses and labeled each with a classification along the provided taxonomy. Duplicated concepts (e.g., replica alignment as core mechanism) are consolidated into distinct hypotheses to avoid redundancy.

paper_title: Behavior of passive polymeric tracers of different topologies in a dilute bath of active Brownian particles

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: One of the key observations is that polymer exhibit faster dynamics compared to passive colloidal particles at high activity, for the same particle density, in both linear and star polymer topologies.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Compares dynamic behavior of polymer tracers to passive colloids under the same bath density and elevated activity, implying a systematic relationship between tracer topology and mobility.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Polymers exhibit faster dynamics than passive colloids at high Pe
hypotheses.notes: Explicit comparative claim used to motivate topology-dependent dynamics in active baths.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: beyond a threshold value of the active force, a 'folded' conformation emerges for the star polymer with three arms, such that two arms are paired while the third remains at a distance.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Asserts that increasing activity directly induces a specific conformational rearrangement (arm pairing) in the star polymer.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increasing Pe leads to arm pairing (two arms pair, third separates)
hypotheses.notes: Directly linked to observed conformational shift under high activity.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: arm-pairing of semiflexible polymers occurs at lower activity levels compared to flexible ones.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Rigid (semiflexible) arms promote asymmetry and pairing more readily under activity, shifting the threshold Pe for pairing.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Semiflexible star polymers pair at lower Pe than flexible stars
hypotheses.notes: Premise tested via comparison of flexible vs semiflexible star polymers.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The pairing of the arms, together with the accumulation of active particles, drives prolonged directed motion. This is evident from the increased mean squared displacement (MSD), the positive temporal velocity autocorrelation function (VACF), and the enhanced persistence time with increasing activity.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Links arm pairing and ABP accumulation to enhanced, directed center-of-mass motion as activity grows.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Higher Pe increases MSD, VACF, and persistence time
hypotheses.notes: Centers on mechanism (packing/accumulation) driving persistent propulsion in the star.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: At high Pe, RAi−Aj and θAi−Aj distributions become bimodal, with a significant population at small arm-arm separations and small arm-arm angles, indicative of a paired-arm configuration.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Observed changes in the joint distributions reflect a structural rearrangement into paired-arm states under strong activity.
hypotheses.notes: Evidence of paired-arm conformations through changes in RAi−Aj and θAi−Aj distributions.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: the energy profile indicates that conformations with smaller separations around RAi−Aj = 1.0 are less stable than those with larger separations; at Pe = 50, there is stabilization of conformations with smaller distance around RAi−Aj ≈ 3, supporting arm pairing at high activity.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Activity-induced changes in the effective energy landscape bias arm separations toward paired configurations.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Higher Pe stabilizes intermediate/smaller Ra values compatible with pairing
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Tests whether the active-bath induced energy landscape generalizes to arm–arm interactions
hypotheses.notes: Direct link between activity, effective interactions, and arm pairing.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: At Pe = 0, the flexible star polymer has compact, coiled conformations, resulting in smaller ⟨Rg⟩ values.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Equilibrium-like conformation of a flexible star is compact relative to linear topology at zero activity.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Star has smaller Rg than linear at Pe = 0
hypotheses.notes: Baseline structural difference of topologies in the absence of activity.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: As activity increases, the difference between the distributions of Rg for star and linear polymers diminishes, and at high activity with Pe = 40 the distributions cover almost the same range of Rg.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Activity reduces topology-driven differences in extension, leading to similar conformations.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Difference in Rg decreases; distributions converge
hypotheses.notes: Links activity to convergence in conformational extension between topologies.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: At high activity, the star polymer adopts a conformation in which two arms pair while the third remains extended—an arrangement driven by the asymmetric accumulation of active particles.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Directly describes a conformation observed under strong ABP activity and its driving force (curvature-related accumulation).
hypotheses.notes: Structural consequence of high activity linked to ABP accumulation in curved regions.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: the convergence of the dynamics of star and linear polymers at high activity (Pe large) implies that topology becomes less influential for long-time transport properties under strong activity.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Observed dynamic convergence suggests topology’s role diminishes in the high-activity regime for long-time scales.
