hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The pseudo-spin length conservation implies that the pairing amplitude and the occupation of each mode are constrained by the relation |Δk|^2 = nkσ (1 − nkσ).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Conservation of the per-mode pseudospin length ζk in the NH limit enforces a constraint relating pairing amplitudes, occupations, and their dynamics.
hypotheses.notes: Equation (69) and the surrounding discussion establish this per-mode constraint via pseudo-spin conservation.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: In the non-Hermitian limit, the system reaches a non-equilibrium steady state akin to a negative temperature state, thus skipping the infinite temperature steady-state reached in the presence of finite contribution of the quantum jumps.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: NH dynamics prevents relaxation to the infinite-temperature steady state observed with finite quantum jumps and instead leads to a negative-temperature-like steady state with population inversion.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: population inversion / negative-temperature-like steady state in the NH limit
hypotheses.specific_type_details: non-equilibrium steady state with negative temperature characteristics
hypotheses.notes: Explicit statement in the text: the NH limit drives the system toward a negative-temperature-like steady state.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The non-Hermitian limit acts as a Non-Hermitian Zeno (NHZ) effect, where the density plateau in the quasi-steady state increases as a function of the dissipation rate Γ.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: NH limit plus dissipation leads to a plateau whose height grows with Γ, interpreted as an NHZ effect.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: plateau density increases with the dissipation rate Γ
hypotheses.notes: Described as NHZ in the depletion dynamics with pair losses section.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: In the equally balanced case Γ = P the density remains constant in time n(t) = 1.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Balance between losses and pumps enforces particle-hole symmetry, freezing the density at unit filling.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: n(t) = 1 at all times
hypotheses.notes: Explicitly stated in the driven-dissipative BCS section: Γ = P preserves particle-hole symmetry so that n(t) = 1.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The driven-dissipative case with NH dynamics drives the system towards a highly non-equilibrium steady state with population inversion (i.e., beyond the infinite-temperature state reached with finite jumps).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The NH dynamics qualitatively changes the steady state under balanced pumps and losses, leading to population inversion rather than the infinite-temperature state.
variables_identified: nkσ and ∆k (mode occupations and pairing amplitudes)
hypotheses.predicted_direction: non-equilibrium steady state with population inversion
hypotheses.notes: Section V.C discusses how NH dynamics lead to a non-equilibrium steady state with population inversion in driven-dissipative BCS.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The Gaussianity of the variational state allows to express the trace Tr(ρ_aux L1[ρ0]) in terms of an effective Hartree-Fock single-particle Liouvillian (LHF[ρ0]).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: In the Gaussian-state ansatz, contractions reduce the many-body trace to a Hartree–Fock-like single-particle Liouvillian description.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: the dynamics can be captured by an effective LHF[ρ0] in the Gaussian variational framework
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Appendix A derives LHF[ρ0] and its use in the action
hypotheses.notes: Gaussian-state variational calculation shows the trace reduces to LHF under the α = 1 case and beyond.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: In the NH limit α = 0 the variational dynamics can be equivalently expressed as a non-Hermitian extension of the Dirac-Frenkel variational principle (NH-DFVP).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The NH limit recasts the variational principle into NH-DFVP, linking the standard Dirac–Frenkel approach to non-Hermitian evolution.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: NH-DFVP correctly describes NH-limit variational dynamics
hypotheses.notes: Section III.A explicitly states this equivalence for α = 0.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The equality Γ = P (balanced two-body losses and pumps) preserves particle-hole symmetry so that the density remains constant in time (n(t) = 1).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Particle-hole symmetry under equal gain and loss rates fixes the density at unit filling for all times.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: n(t) stays at 1 for all t
hypotheses.notes: Explicitly stated in Sec. V.A and Sec. IV discussion of balanced pumps/losses.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The average pseudo-spin length ζ = (1/N) Σk ζk is conserved in the NH limit (α = 0), which hinders decay of the pairing amplitudes and modifies the long-time dynamics relative to Lindblad dynamics.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Conservation of per-mode pseudo-spin length implies constraints on the evolution of pairing and occupations, altering long-time decay behavior.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: NH limit preserves ζ leading to altered long-time decay compared to Lindblad
hypotheses.notes: Sections with Fig. 3 and related discussion establish pseudo-spin conservation in NH limit.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: In the purely Gaussian variational treatment, the normalization of the state is accounted for by the variational principle, and the equations of motion reduce to the connected contractions that match the exact DMVP/NADFVP structure in the studied limits.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Normalization terms cancel/disappear in the connected contractions, aligning the variational dynamics with the DMVP structure.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: variational equations faithfully reproduce DMVP structure under Gaussian ansatz
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Appendix B/C discussion of normalization and contractions
hypotheses.notes: Methodological consistency between Gaussian variational approach and DMVP/NH-DFVP is demonstrated.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The DMVP (density matrix variational principle) can be consistently extended to the hybrid case (α ≠ 1) by including state normalization in the action, yielding δS/δρ_aux = 0 with a properly renormalized dissipator.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The DMVP extension to α ≠ 1 is constructed to incorporate the normalization, ensuring a consistent variational framework for hybrid dynamics.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: DMVP extends to hybrid Liouvillians (α ≠ 1) with normalization accounted for
hypotheses.notes: Section III discusses extending DMVP to α ≠ 1 and the role of normalization.

processing_notes: The paper develops time-dependent variational principles for hybrid non-unitary (Lindblad, non-Hermitian no-jump, and hybrid α-parameterized) dynamics and applies them to driven-dissipative BCS superconductors. Hypotheses include methodological claims about the variational principles themselves (DMVP, NH-DFVP, and normalization), as well as physics-driven hypotheses about NH limits, pseudo-spin conservation, NHZ effects, and non-equilibrium steady states (including negative-temperature-like states and population inversion). Each hypothesis is identified in the text (explicitly or as a result) and classified along epistemic, structural, predictive, functional, temporal axes, with listed variables, predicted directions, and a confidence assessment. Citations and exact phrasing are paraphrased where necessary for compact presentation; quotes incorporated are faithful to the surrounding statements in the document. If a hypothesis is primarily methodological (e.g., about the form of the variational principle or Gaussian trace reduction), it is labeled as a methodological/implementation hypothesis with details in the notes. The output avoids duplication by listing each distinct claim only once.

paper_title: Local-Antisymmetric Flat Band and Coexisting Correlated stripe charge orders in WSe2-Modulated Twisted Bilayer Graphene

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The three distinct types of atomic stacking configurations within its superlattice unit cell cause a variation in local on-site potential that modulates the flat bands of the adjacent MATBG, transforming them from hole-side asymmetric to electron-side asymmetric within a single AA-stacked region.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Stacking-config-dependent local potentials are proposed to shift the MATBG flat bands in opposite directions, creating a controlled particle–hole asymmetry within AA regions.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: A-type preserves near-symmetric flat bands; B-type lowers the flat-band energy; X-type raises the flat-band energy, creating hole/electron-side asymmetry
hypotheses.notes: Links registry-driven energy shifts to the three stacking configurations; testable by STM/STS across AA regions.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The significant modulation of flat-band symmetry by WSe2 interfacial coupling enables the unprecedented coexistence of orthogonal stripe charge orders in the MATBG AA region.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The interfacial modulation breaks symmetry in a way that permits two stripe-charge orders along perpendicular directions to coexist, a regime not expected under pure Coulomb repulsion.
hypotheses.notes: Proposes a novel correlated state regime; aligns with observed coexistence in STM maps.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The graphene/WSe2 heterostructure with a large relative twist angle exhibits three distinctly separated atomic stacking patterns in real space (A-type, B-type, and X-type), and their localized spatial extent and inter-configuration distances vary with twist angle, providing varying particle–hole asymmetry of flat bands under different configurations.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Different registries spatially separate and shift the flat-band levels, producing registry-dependent particle–hole asymmetry that depends on θg/w.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Registry-induced energy shifts vary with twist angle; A-type near-symmetric, B-type energy lowered, X-type energy raised
hypotheses.specific_type_details: registry-dependent modulation of flat bands
hypotheses.notes: Directly ties registry types to registry-dependent energy shifts as a function of twist angle.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: At smaller twist angles (θg/w ≈ 6°), each stacking configuration spreads over large spatial domains, effectively suppressing the modulation of MATBG flat bands, whereas at around θg/w ≈ 17° the stacking configurations remain spatially separated, enabling stronger registry-dependent modulation.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: observations show domain growth at ~6°, reducing modulation, while 17° shows clearly separated registries enabling modulation.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Smaller θg/w leads to larger registry domains and suppressed modulation; larger θg/w (~17°) preserves registry separation and modulation
hypotheses.notes: Connects twist-angle to registry-domain size and modulation strength observed in S1 vs S2.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Heterostrain induces anisotropic moiré patterns and elliptical AA-stacked regions, breaking C3 symmetry to C2, which is evidenced by anisotropic LDOS and stripe-like patterns, indicating correlated-order states in the partially filled flat bands.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Experimentally observed anisotropy in moiré pattern and LDOS correlates with heterostrain and symmetry breaking, not solely with strain.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increasing heterostrain enhances LDOS anisotropy and C2 symmetry breaking; reducing strain recovers C3
hypotheses.notes: Links strain to symmetry breaking and correlated-state signatures in STM/STS data.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Gaussian fits identify three spectral features P1, P2, and P3, with P2 and P3 corresponding to the van Hove singularities of the nearly flat conduction and valence MATBG bands, respectively, while P1 corresponds to the band edge of a high-energy remote band.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Directly interprets observed peaks in dI/dV spectra in terms of known band features.
variables_identified: P2 corresponds to VHS of conduction band
P3 corresponds to VHS of valence band
P1 corresponds to remote band edge
hypotheses.notes: Maps observed STS peaks to specific band features; supports interpretation of spectral data.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Across AA regions, the energy separation ∆E between P2 and P3 shows spatial variation, from ~16 meV at sites L and R to ~26 meV at site M, indicating Coulomb-interaction–enhanced peak separation when the chemical potential lies between the two flat bands.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Observed spatial gradient in peak separation consistent with interaction-driven broadening and splitting.
variables_identified: sites L, M, R within AA region
hypotheses.notes: Links spatial variation of peak splitting to Coulomb interactions in partially filled flat bands.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The application of a perpendicular magnetic field (10 T) to the non-strain-released S1 sample leads to the emergence of three distinct step-like, spatially distributed flat-band features, indicating registry-specific flat bands become further spatially separated under magnetic field control.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Magnetic field tuning reveals additional registry-resolved band structure features and enhanced separation
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Applying magnetic field increases registry-specific band separation
hypotheses.notes: Supports the idea that inter-registry separation can be tuned by B-field independent of strain.

processing_notes: The hypotheses are drawn from explicit and implicit claims across the paper’s sections (Introduction, Results, Discussion). They include causal claims about how graphene/WSe2 interfacial registry and heterostrain modulate MATBG flat bands, and the consequent emergence and control of correlated stripe orders. Several hypotheses pertain to angle- and strain-tuning of registry effects, spectral peak assignments (P1–P3) in STS data, and magnetic-field responses. Duplicates were avoided by consolidating closely related statements into single hypotheses where appropriate. Each item includes the exact hypothesis text (quoted where possible from the paper’s described mechanisms), classification axes, involved variables, and a conservative confidence score. If a reader wants a stricter, paper-specific extraction (e.g., to separate sub-hypotheses within a single item), I can split these into finer-grained entries upon request.

paper_title: Open Quantum Dynamics Theory for Coulomb Potentials: Hierarchical Equations of Motion for Atomic Orbitals (AO-HEOM)

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: AO-HEOM provides numerically "exact" hierarchical equations of motion for atomic orbitals (AO-HEOM) that enable a non-perturbative and non-Markovian treatment of system-bath interactions at finite temperatures.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors state that they derive numerically 'exact' hierarchical equations of motion for atomic orbitals (AO-HEOM) enabling a non-perturbative and non-Markovian treatment, implying an exact dynamical description within the model.
hypotheses.notes: Key methodological claim about the method's claimed exactness and capability; used to validate via spectra.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Conventional approaches—including the Lindblad master equation (LME), Markovian-Redfield equation (MRE), quantum Fokker–Planck equations (QFPE), and analytically exact solutions derived from the Caldeira–Leggett (CL) model—fail to reproduce discretized transition peaks characteristic of a rotationally invariant system.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The paper argues that applying standard, symmetry-breaking baths (e.g., CL with non-rotationally invariant baths) yields failure to reproduce discrete rotational spectral peaks, highlighting a limitation of those models.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Conventional approaches fail to reproduce discretized rotational peaks
hypotheses.notes: Motivates the need for a rotationally invariant bath and AO-HEOM development.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The 3D-RISB model preserves rotational symmetry in the total system-bath Hamiltonian, enabling discretized spectral features (rotationally invariant transitions) that are absent in non-rotationally symmetric baths.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The model is explicitly constructed to be three-dimensionally rotationally invariant, in contrast to standard baths, which should recover discrete spectral features associated with rotational symmetry.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: 3D-RISB yields discretized spectral peaks corresponding to rotational transitions
hypotheses.notes: Presents 3D-RISB as the symmetry-preserving framework to capture quantum rotational features.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Bath entanglement is essential; neglecting bath entanglement leads to positivity violations in standard open-quantum-model predictions (e.g., Lindblad master equation and Markovian Redfield equation).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The paper emphasizes that neglecting bath-bath correlations (bath entanglement) yields unphysical results such as negative populations, illustrating a causal link between bath entanglement and positivity.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Negativity/positivity violations occur when bath entanglement is neglected
hypotheses.notes: Links a fundamental quantum feature (bath entanglement) to the validity of common Markovian approaches.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: AO-HEOM formalism is capable of treating Coulomb-potential systems in a non-perturbative manner, including gauge fields.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors claim that AO-HEOM can handle non-perturbative system-bath coupling and can incorporate gauge fields, extending beyond perturbative treatments.
hypotheses.notes: Articulates methodological capability of AO-HEOM beyond perturbative regimes and into gauge-field contexts.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: When the system-bath coupling is strong, Lyman and Balmer transitions dominate and the spectral peaks broaden due to fluctuations.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The results show that strong SB coupling enhances fluctuations, broadening peaks and making Lyman/Balmer transitions prominent.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Stronger SB coupling broadens peaks and emphasizes Lyman/Balmer transitions
hypotheses.notes: Connects coupling strength and temperature to observable spectral changes.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: As temperature decreases or the system-bath coupling weakens, Paschen and Brackett peaks appear (transitions from highly excited states).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The study reports the emergence of Paschen and Brackett series under lower temperature and weaker SB coupling, consistent with reduced thermal fluctuations.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Paschen and Brackett peaks appear as temperature decreases or SB coupling weakens
hypotheses.notes: Describes spectral changes complementary to the strong-coupling case.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Using a non-rotationally symmetric bath within the Caldeira–Leggett (CL) framework yields classical behavior with no quantum transition characteristics observed.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors report that CL with a non-rotationally symmetric bath produces featureless, semiclassical spectra lacking quantum transition signatures.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: CL model yields classical behavior with no quantum features
hypotheses.notes: Illustrates limitation of non-symmetric baths in reproducing quantum spectral features.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The AO-HEOM results are converged with the chosen basis size (55 energy eigenstates) and hierarchy depth (Nα = 2); increasing the basis yields only minor shifts in peak positions.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Appendix B reports convergence tests showing stabilization of spectral profiles as basis set expands.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Spectral profile stabilizes with larger basis
hypotheses.notes: Convergence claim supported by Appendix B results.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Isotropic bath assumptions (γx = γy = γz and ηx = ηy = ηz) produce symmetric spectral behavior, while introducing anisotropy (difference among directions) can modify spectral features.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The paper notes the isotropic case and discusses how anisotropy could be introduced, implying potential changes in spectra if anisotropy is present.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Anisotropy changes spectral features compared to the isotropic case
hypotheses.notes: Acknowledges possible anisotropy and its potential spectral consequences; not exhaustively tested in this work.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: AO-HEOM can be extended to multi-electron systems defined in Fock space in future work.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors indicate that extending AO-HEOM to multi-electron Fock-space systems is a future challenge, implying generalization potential.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: AO-HEOM can be extended to multi-electron systems
hypotheses.specific_type_details: extension to multi-electron Fock space
hypotheses.notes: Proposes generalization pathway rather than a tested result in this work.

processing_notes: Identified explicit hypotheses and many implicit expectations across sections (theoretical foundations, symmetry considerations, methodological claims, and empirical spectral predictions). Duplication was avoided by treating closely related claims as separate hypotheses only when they represent distinct testable propositions (e.g., spectral features under varying SB coupling and temperature).

paper_title: Tunable multi-photon correlations from a coherently driven quantum dot

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: by adjusting the mixing ratio and phase one can achieve full tunability of the second-order correlation, ranging from anti-bunching to bunching
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Explicit claim that modifying mixing ratio fmix and relative phase ϕ changes g(2) from antibunching to bunching, i.e., a causal effect of mixing on photon statistics
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increasing fmix or adjusting ϕ can move g(2)(τ) from antibunching to bunching
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Control of photon statistics via linear optical mixing of QE emission with a coherent field
hypotheses.notes: This is the central tunability claim stated explicitly in the abstract/introduction

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Most importantly, this part is the only contribution to g(2) cross,co at τ = 0, meaning the bunching is made possible only by the detection of laser photons.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Claims that the observed τ = 0 bunching in cross-co is due solely to a specific term (laser-photon detection) in the mixed signal
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Bunching at τ = 0 arises when laser photons are detected alongside QE photons; removing laser photons reduces or eliminates the τ = 0 bunching
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Cross-co correlation decomposition showing B-term dominates τ = 0 bunching
hypotheses.notes: Grounded in the decomposition of G(2) cross,co into A+B+C and the identification of term B as responsible for τ=0 bunching

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: g(2)co,co(0) can become as large as g(2)co,co(0) reaches values of 20 in theory (and up to even higher in experiment depending on noise and normalization effects).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: As a result of interference between laser and QE signals at both detectors, the co-co second-order correlation at zero delay can be dramatically enhanced due to constructive interference and normalization effects
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Under suitable fmix and ϕ, g(2)co,co(0) can exhibit strong bunching (up to ~20 or more in theory)
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Interference at both detectors leading to large g(2)co,co(0) values
hypotheses.notes: Quoted in the discussion of cross- and co-co correlations; explicitly states large values and dependence on interference terms

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: For ϕ = 0 only antibunching behavior is found, almost independent of the driving strength Ω0. With increasing laser mixing factor fmix, the depth of the dip becomes more shallow, but stays below 1.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Phase control combined with mixing determines whether the correlation is antibunched; fmix modulates the depth but does not cross into bunching at ϕ=0
hypotheses.predicted_direction: ϕ = 0 yields antibunching; increasing fmix only shallowly reduces the antibunching depth
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Phase-dependent control of cross-co g(2)
hypotheses.notes: Directly quoted behavior observed in Fig. 5 and accompanying text

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: For ϕ = π, bunching behavior is achieved for strong enough laser mixing factor fmix. The largest bunching occurs for fmix = 1, where the interference between the different terms is strongest.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Phase-controlled interference between laser and QE components can switch g(2) from antibunching to bunching; the maximum occurs at fmix=1 and ϕ=π
hypotheses.predicted_direction: ϕ = π and larger fmix produce stronger bunching, with the strongest at fmix = 1
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Phase-controlled interference leading to bunching
hypotheses.notes: Quoted statements explicitly describe anti-bunching for ϕ=0 and bunching for ϕ=π, including the fmix dependence

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The nth order coherence including mixing at all detectors is G(n)(t, τ = 0) = ⟨(s†)^n(t) s^n(t)⟩. Expanding this expression leads to G(n)(t, τ = 0) = |β|^{2n} + n^2 |β|^{2(n−1)} ⟨σ†(t)σ(t)⟩ + 2n |β|^{2n−1} |⟨σ(t)⟩| cos ϕ.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Provides a concrete, testable relation between the mixed field amplitude β, the QE coherence ⟨σ⟩, and the nth-order correlation at zero delay; predicts laser photons are necessary for τ=0 events
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increasing β and appropriate phase cos(ϕ) will modify G(n)(t,0) in a predictable, laser-assisted way
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Mathematical form for mixed-field nth-order coherence
hypotheses.notes: Directly derived in the paper (Eq. 10) and used to argue laser photons are necessary at τ=0 for all orders

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: We stress that the normalization plays a very decisive role in the strength of the bunching.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Highlights a methodological/interpretive factor (normalization) that can dramatically alter the observed g(2) values
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Normalization affects the magnitude of observed bunching
hypotheses.notes: Explicitly stated in the discussion of Fig. 4–5 analyses; links to why g(2)(0) can be large even if underlying processes are modest

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: For ϕ = 0 anti-bunching persists almost independently of Ω0, whereas for ϕ = π strong bunching is possible at sufficient fmix; the largest bunching occurs at fmix = 1.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Directly ties phase, mixing, and driving strength to the observed (anti-)bunching behavior; includes a quantitative maximal condition at fmix=1
hypotheses.predicted_direction: ϕ = 0 yields antibunching; ϕ = π yields bunching with increasing fmix, maximal at fmix = 1
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Phase-dependent control of antibunching/bunching with mixing
hypotheses.notes: Quoted in the discussion of Fig. 5 and related text

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: In panels (a,b) without laser mixing, the prominent feature is antibunching along the τ axes and diagonal; with fmix = 1 and ϕ = π (mixing), strong diagonal and center bunching appears.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Claims that turning on laser mixing qualitatively changes the observed g(3) pattern, demonstrating the causal role of mixing in higher-order correlations
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Laser mixing (fmix>0, ϕ=π) changes g(3) from antibunching to diagonal/center bunching
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Higher-order (g(3)) statistics under laser mixing
hypotheses.notes: Described in Fig. 6 and accompanying discussion of g(3) with/without mixing

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The cross-co correlation and the co-co correlation can be decomposed into multiple contributing parts (A, B, C, D, E; and Ã, B~, C~, D~, E~ for the co-co case) and the observed bunching can be traced to specific terms (e.g., term B for cross-co, and interference terms for co-co).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Provides a mechanistic account of how different components (A, B, C, D, E) contribute to g(2) in the presence of mixing, linking theory to observed data
variables_identified: G(2) cross,co terms A, B, C
G(2) co,co terms A~, B~, C~, D~, E~
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Different terms contribute with distinct τ dependencies; specific terms (e.g., B) dominate τ=0 bunching in cross-co, and interference terms govern co-co behavior
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Term-by-term decomposition of mixed-field correlations
hypotheses.notes: Based on the detailed breakdown around Eqs. (6)–(9) and associated figures

processing_notes: The paper presents explicit, testable predictions about how mixing a coherent laser with resonance fluorescence from a quantum dot controls second- and higher-order photon correlations. Explicit hypotheses are embedded in the abstract, results and discussion, often phrased as tunability or phase/mixing dependent behavior (e.g., antibunching vs bunching, large g(2)(0) due to interference, and higher-order coherence dependence). Each hypothesis above is drawn directly from quoted statements or clearly testable claims in the text (e.g., explicit phase dependencies, maximal mixing conditions, and nth-order coherence expressions). The classifications map these statements onto the Andrey Ustyuzhanin taxonomy (causal/associative, simple/complex, etc.). If any item should be treated as exploratory or not strictly tested in this paper, it can be re-labeled as 'not_evaluated' with updated evidence.

paper_title: Time domain braiding of anyons revealed through a nonequilibrium fluctuation dissipation theorem

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The time-domain braiding relation ⟨A† H0(t) AH0(0)⟩ = e^{-2i θ sign(t)} ⟨AH0(0) A† H0(t)⟩ holds (Eq. 6), i.e., the two correlators are linked by a braiding phase θ in the time domain.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: This relation encodes how the anyonic braiding phase θ imprints itself as a phase factor in time-domain correlators; θ is the parameter governing the braiding.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: X→(t) = e^{-2i θ sign(t)} X←(t), i.e., the forward correlator is the backward correlator multiplied by a phase depending on θ
hypotheses.notes: Foundational input (braiding constraint) for UNEPT-based transport; central to subsequent FDTs.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The DC backscattering current is given by Itun(ωdc) = 2 e* Re[XR(ωdc)].
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Derives directly from the braiding link via the retarded correlator XR; expresses how the current is determined by a single response function XR.
hypotheses.notes: Eq. (7) is a direct, testable consequence of the braiding link for DC transport.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The DC backscattering noise is related to XR by Stun(ωdc) = -2 e*^2 cot θ Im[XR(ωdc)].
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: From the braiding link and the structure of X_R, the noise acquires θ-dependent imaginary-part contributions.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Stun scales with cot θ times the imaginary part of XR
hypotheses.notes: Eq. (8) provides a central braiding FDT linking noise to the phase θ.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Differential DC noise and differential DC conductance satisfy Ḡ_tun(ωdc) = ∂ Itun(ωdc)/∂ ωdc and ∂ S̄_tun(ωdc)/∂ ωdc = - (2 e*/π) ωdc cot θ P.V. ∫_0^∞ dω' [ Ḡ_tun(ωdc=ω') / (ωdc^2 - ω'^2) ].
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: A braiding-mediated FDT in the DC regime; provides a route to extract θ from transport data via KK-type relations.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: θ can be extracted from the relation between differential noise and differential conductance
hypotheses.notes: Method 1 (DC noise via DC conductance) uses KK-type integral to access θ; depends on known e*.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The AC current phase shift ϕ_ω satisfies tan ϕ_ω = [B_tun,ω] / [G_tun,ω], and is related to θ via Eq. (18): tan ϕ_ω = - tan θ · [S̄_tun(ωdc=ω) − S̄_tun(ωdc=0)] / [ e* ¯Itun(ωdc=ω) ].
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Connects an experimentally measurable AC phase to the braiding phase through a universal relation.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Measuring ϕ_ω and the DC-noise difference yields θ (up to modulo π)
hypotheses.notes: Eq. (18) enables a direct, calibration-robust route to θ from mixed DC/AC measurements.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: In the quantum (ω ≫ ωth) regime and for δ > 1/2, the dephasing relation φ_ω ≃ - θ (mod π) holds (Eq. (23)).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Quantum regime analysis shows a direct, simple mapping between dephasing and the braiding phase when δ > 1/2.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: phase shift φ_ω is approximately the negative of θ modulo π
hypotheses.notes: Eq. (23) asserts a simple identity in the quantum regime for δ > 1/2.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: For δ > 1/2, δ = 1 − φ_ω/π (Eq. 24), enabling direct determination of δ from the measured AC phase shift.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Relates scaling dimension δ to the measurable AC phase shift in the quantum regime.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: δ decreases as φ_ω increases (modulo π), allowing δ to be read off from φ_ω
hypotheses.notes: Provides a practical route to read δ from measured phase shifts in the quantum regime.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: In a thermalized Tomonaga–Luttinger liquid (TLL) with δ = θ/π > 1/2, the quantum-regime phase shift ϕ_ω obeys the TLL-predicted form given in Eq. (20) (involving Γ(δ) and related functions), enabling δ to be inferred from ϕ_ω.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Specializes the braiding FDT to a thermalized TLL and shows a δ-dependent functional form for ϕ_ω.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: ϕ_ω encodes δ through the TLL expression; thus δ can be extracted from ϕ_ω
hypotheses.notes: Eq. (20) provides a δ-dependent functional form in the quantum regime for a thermalized TLL.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: In the quantum regime, φ_ω ≃ - θ mod π lifts the indeterminacy of θ modulo π inherent in many current-only braiding probes, when δ > 1/2 (through δ = θ/π and related relations).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The TLL relation between δ and θ resolves the θ mod π ambiguity for δ > 1/2, offering a unique determination of θ from δ.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Choosing δ = θ/π mod π resolves θ up to multiples of π via φ_ω
hypotheses.notes: Addresses the θ mod π indeterminacy via TLL scaling in the quantum regime.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The phase-shift-based extraction of θ is robust against certain nonuniversal renormalizations, particularly for measurements of chiral currents near the QPC, provided ω ≪ v/L (Appendix D).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Renormalization cancellations are enabled in specific measurement geometries and frequency windows; deviations occur if these conditions are not met.
hypotheses.notes: Renormalization cancellation discussed in Appendix D; restricted to ω ≪ v/L to preserve cancellation.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: A single quantum point contact (QPC) is the minimal setup required to probe the braiding phase θ in time-domain transport.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors argue that a single QPC suffices to access θ and that more complex interferometric or collider geometries are not strictly necessary for θ extraction.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: θ can be extracted from transport measurements with a single QPC
hypotheses.notes: Stated as one of the key practical advantages of the proposed scheme.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The time-domain braiding framework extends to general filling factors ν_C (beyond Laughlin states) provided a single quasiparticle species dominates, and to anyon-collider geometries.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The framework is stated to apply to a broader class of ν_C under the single-species assumption; the authors discuss this as a generalization.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Generalization to ν_C and collider geometries under single-species dominance
hypotheses.notes: Claims broad applicability of the method beyond Laughlin states under the single-species dominance assumption.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: In the time-domain braiding picture, the induction of a two-point braiding loop by A is a sufficient phenomenological encoding of braiding statistics for transport observables, even when the operator-level braid relations are not strictly guaranteed.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Distinguishes the phenomenological braiding link used in UNEPT from operator-level algebra; asserts usefulness for transport observables.
hypotheses.notes: Caveat: the braiding link is a weaker condition than operator-level braiding relations.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: In the thermalized TLL regime, θ and δ are related by θ = π δ mod π, so the quantum dephasing behavior and δ can be inferred from measured phase shifts (and vice versa).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Connects braiding phase to scaling dimension via the TLL mapping; provides a route to determine δ from θ and measured observables.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Relation between θ and δ in thermalized TLL
hypotheses.notes: Recognizes indeterminacy modulo π and uses the TLL relation to constrain δ.

processing_notes: The paper presents a coherent set of theoretical (nonequilibrium) fluctuation–dissipation relations that encode the anyonic braiding phase θ in time-domain transport observables. The hypotheses above extract explicit equations presented as central results (Eq. 6, 7, 8, 11–12, 17–18, 19–24) and related conceptual claims (single-QPC minimal setup, generalization to ν_C, renormalization cancellation under certain conditions). All items are treated as testable predictions within the UNEPT framework; no experimental data is analyzed in the provided text, hence all evaluation statuses remain 'not_evaluated'.

paper_title: Flux confinement-deconfinement transition of dimer-loop models on three-dimensional bipartite lattices

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: There are two distinct Coulomb phases separated by a phase transition at a nonzero finite critical fugacity w_c on both lattices (cubic and diamond) in the fully-packed dimer–loop model; the w> w_c phase has short loops while the w< w_c phase is dominated by large loops with universal long‑loop properties.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Explicitly states a phase boundary in the model controlled by the fugacity w; the paper identifies a continuous transition at a finite w_c separating two Coulomb phases.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increasing w beyond w_c drives a transition from the long-loop (extended-loop) Coulomb phase to the short-loop Coulomb phase.
hypotheses.notes: Core result established in Sec. IV A and Fig. 7–9; two Coulomb phases separated by a finite-w transition.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Evidence from Binder cumulants Q2, Pfrac, and finite-size scaling collapses at w_c on both lattices (Figs. 7–9), with ν≈0.63.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Both Coulomb phases can be described by a continuum Gaussian theory for the coarse-grained divergence-free polarization field, Seff = (K/2) ∫ d^3x P^2 with P = ∇×A (i.e., a lattice/Coulomb description with dipolar correlations).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Stated as the effective-field-theory description for long-wavelength physics of the dimer–loop model in both phases.
hypotheses.notes: Discussed in Sec. II A and Sec. IV E as the coarse-grained description across phases.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Coarse-grained action Seff and lattice version Slat are presented as unifying descriptions for both phases (Sec. II A, IV E).

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: In the w< w_c (long-loop) phase half-integer fluxes proliferate, whereas in the w> w_c (short-loop) phase half-integer fluxes are confined to integer values (for periodic boundary conditions).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Direct observation from flux distribution analyses showing non-integer fluxes in the long-loop phase and integer fluxes in the short-loop phase.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Half-integer fluxes proliferate for w< w_c and are confined to integers for w> w_c.
hypotheses.notes: Figure 9 and related discussion support distinct flux-sector behavior across the transition.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: P_frac(w,L) crosses and tends to 0 for w>w_c (Fig. 9).

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Half-integer test charges q=±1/2 are deconfined in the w< w_c phase but confined in the w> w_c phase.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Topological distinction of flux and charge sectors across the transition; deconfinement in one phase and confinement in the other implied by flux properties.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Deconfinement of half-integer charges in w< w_c; confinement in w> w_c.
hypotheses.notes: C^(1/2)_v(r) behaves differently in the two phases (Fig. 18–19).
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Half-vortex correlator saturates to nonzero constant at large r for w<w_c and decays for w>w_c (Sec. IV G).

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: At the critical fugacity w_c, the loop-length distribution exhibits universal scaling with exponents θ_c ≈ 1.73(2) and τ_c ≈ 2.75(2), with the largest loops scaling as s_max ∼ L^{θ_c} and P_crit_link(s,L) ∼ s^{-τ_c} for s ≪ L^{θ_c}.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Finite-size scaling analysis around the critical point yields universal exponents θ_c and τ_c and a scaling form for P_crit_link(s,L).
hypotheses.notes: Exponents θ_c ≈ 1.73(2), τ_c ≈ 2.75(2) and scaling form Eq. (14) supported by Fig. 11 and Fig. 12.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Scaling collapse and exponents reported in Sec. IV C and Fig. 11–12.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: In the long-loop phase, the loop-length distribution Plink(s,L) for s ≫ s0(w) but s ≪ L^2 follows a Brownian-motion–like decay ∝ s^{-3/2}, and for L^2 ≪ s ≪ fL^3 it follows a Poisson-Dirichlet form with Θ = 1/2; the fractional fraction f(w) characterizes the long-loop phase.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Observed form of Plink(s,L) across different s regimes; connection to Brownian motion and Poisson-Dirichlet descriptions for large loops.
hypotheses.notes: Discussed in Sec. IV B and Fig. 10; universal regime with Poisson-Dirichlet behavior in the extended-loop regime.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Plink(s,L) data collapse to Eq. (11) and (12); PD(Θ=1/2) with f(w) in Fig. 10.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Binder cumulants Q2 and the fractional flux probability Pfrac cross at w_c and obey a finite-size scaling form Q2(w,L)=F_Q(c1 ¯δw L^{1/ν}) and Pfrac(w,L)=F_P(c2 ¯δw L^{1/ν}) with ν≈0.63, consistent with a continuous transition in three dimensions.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Binder-crossing and data collapse provide evidence for a continuous phase transition and a universal correlation-length exponent.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Binder cumulants and Pfrac cross at a single w_c; scaling collapses validate ν≈0.63.
hypotheses.notes: Discussion around Figs. 8–9 and Eq. (10).
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Crossing at wc and scaling collapse with ν≈0.63 (Sec. IV A).

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The correlation-length exponent ν for the flux-confinement transition in this 3D dimer–loop model is very close to the 3D Ising value, suggesting Ising-like criticality in ν, though hyperscaling may be violated in this system.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: ν ≈ 0.63 is close to the 3D Ising value; hyperscaling appears violated for α, prompting further interpretation.
hypotheses.notes: Discussed in Sec. IV F and Discussion; ν aligns with 3D Ising, α/ν does not align with hyperscaling.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: ν≈0.63; α/ν≈0.25; hyperscaling question raised (Sec. IV F).

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The critical flux distribution at wc is not captured by a single Gaussian; instead, different Gaussian behaviors with the same stiffness κ but different prefactors Cm(L) appear for distinct flux sectors Sm (diamond) or Sm (cubic), reflecting a sector-structured Gaussian description at criticality.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Empirical observation that flux distributions segregate into multiple Gaussians with sector-dependent prefactors at criticality (Fig. 15).
variables_identified: Sm sectors (S1,S2,S3 on diamond; S1–S4 on cubic)
hypotheses.notes: Section IV E discusses sector-dependent Gaussians; Fig. 15–16 illustrate the multi-Gaussian structure.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Gaussian behavior split into multiple sectors with sector-dependent prefactors (Fig. 15).

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The long-loop (w< w_c) phase is robust to small nonzero fugacity f_{1/2} for half-integer vortices, but f_{1/2} acts as a relevant perturbation in that phase, while in the short-loop (w> w_c) phase f_{1/2} is marginally relevant, causing a very slow crossover; f_{1} (unit charges) is a relevant perturbation in the short-loop phase.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: RG reasoning: half-integer defects are relevant in the long-loop phase and marginally relevant in the short-loop phase; unit charges are relevant in the short-loop phase.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Small f_{1/2} destabilizes the long-loop phase (relevant); in the short-loop phase, f_{1/2} is marginally relevant and f1 is relevant.
hypotheses.notes: Discussed in Sec. IV G and Fig. 21–23; RG interpretation of perturbations.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Stability analyses with f_{1/2} and f1 in Sec. IV G; percolation-based arguments in Fig. 21–23.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The unit-charge defects (f1) are relevant perturbations in the short-loop phase, consistent with the relation that the w> w_c phase is unstable to unit-charge defects.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Discussion that unit-charges are a relevant perturbation in the short-loop phase, contributing to instability at f1>0.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Nonzero unit-charge fugacity destabilizes the short-loop phase.
hypotheses.notes: Part of the discussion on defect perturbations (Sec. IV G).
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Argued that f1 is relevant in the short-loop phase; f1/2 is marginally relevant in the same regime.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: A unit-vortex correlation Ce^(1)_v(r) behaves differently from the half-vortex correlator Ce^(1/2)_v(r) and is largely governed by the depleted-lattice percolation structure, with Ce^(1)_v(r) decaying or saturating depending on the percolation state of the depleted lattice.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The Ce^(1)_v(r) correlator is not straightforwardly interpretable as an effective potential due to depleted-lattice percolation constraints; percolation thresholds influence its large-r behavior.
hypotheses.notes: Discussed in Sec. IV G with percolation-based interpretation of Ce^(1)_v(r).
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Ce^(1)_v(r) behavior tied to depleted-lattice percolation thresholds (Fig. 19–20).

processing_notes: The paper presents a coherent set of testable hypotheses about a flux confinement–deconfinement transition in 3D bipartite dimer–loop models, their Gaussian field description, critical scaling, defect perturbations, and flux-sector structure. The hypotheses above are distilled from explicit statements, scaling relations, and experimental (numerical) evidence provided in the figures and text.

paper_title: Quantification of Electrolyte Degradation in Lithium-ion Batteries with Neutron Imaging Techniques

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: There are two stages of electrolyte inventory loss during aging—Excessive EI loss (ExEIL) and pore-drying EI loss (PDEIL)—separated by a full saturation/dry-out threshold at 3.18 g Ah⁻¹.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Quantitative standard curves from neutron imaging identify two distinct EI-loss stages (ExEIL and PDEIL) and a clear saturation/dry-out threshold at 3.18 g Ah⁻¹.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: two-stage EI loss with a saturation threshold
hypotheses.notes: Central EI-dynamics claim with a defined transition between two stages.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: High initial EI (electrolyte inventory) cells exhibit uniform SEI growth and reduced degradation, whereas low initial EI cells show uneven SEI formation, accelerating capacity loss during aging.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Empirical observations show distinct SEI growth patterns and degradation rates between high-EI and low-EI groups, implying EI directly influences SEI behavior and aging.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: High EI → uniform SEI growth and slower degradation; Low EI → uneven SEI growth and faster degradation
hypotheses.specific_type_details: EI level modulates SEI growth pattern and degradation trajectory
hypotheses.notes: Direct comparison of EI groups supports EI-dependent SEI behavior and aging.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Neutron transmission below the fully infiltrated reference value is caused by hydrogen enrichment within the solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Operando cyclic aging and NI data indicate that reduced transmission correlates with hydrogen enrichment in SEI, not with gas or liquid phase changes alone.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increased SEI hydrogen enrichment decreases neutron transmission
hypotheses.specific_type_details: SEI hydrogen enrichment dominates NI signal changes
hypotheses.notes: Mechanistic link between SEI chemistry and NI signal observed operando.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The SEI signal can be quantitatively decoupled from the EI signal during aging when PDEIL does not occur (ExEIL-dominated regime).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Authors argue that during ExEIL (no PDEIL), SEI-related NI signals can be separated from EI-related signals for quantitative interpretation.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: quantitative decoupling of SEI signal during ExEIL
hypotheses.notes: Methodological claim about separability of signals under ExEIL conditions.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: High EI cells show uniform SEI growth, while low EI cells exhibit non-uniform SEI growth, leading to distinct aging trajectories and degradation rates.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Direct NI/TOF-SIMS/SEM evidence links EI level to spatial uniformity of SEI and consequent degradation behavior.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: High EI → uniform SEI and slower degradation; Low EI → non-uniform SEI and faster degradation
hypotheses.specific_type_details: EI-dependent SEI uniformity and aging
hypotheses.notes: Central SEI morphology/aging claim supported by multi-modal data.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Pore-drying electrolyte inventory loss (PDEIL) causes pore drying in electrode regions, which increases local current density and thickens both organic and inorganic SEI layers, accelerating capacity fade in aging (notably in Stage II).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: PDEIL is associated with measurable pore drying, regionally increased current density, and thicker SEI layers, matching accelerated capacity fading in low-EI aging.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: PDEIL → increased current density and thicker SEI → faster capacity fade
hypotheses.specific_type_details: PDEIL-driven degradation mechanism
hypotheses.notes: Links PDEIL to mechanistic SEI evolution and aging dynamics.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Vinyl carbonate (VC) additive content at the beginning of life (BoL) influences early aging by reducing SEI-related side reactions; higher VC content correlates with slower early aging in high-EI cells.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Post-mortem analyses show higher VC content in high-EI cells at BoL and correspondingly slower early aging due to altered SEI chemistry.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Higher VC at BoL → slower early aging
hypotheses.specific_type_details: VC effects on early SEI formation and aging
hypotheses.notes: Based on post-mortem compositional data; potential causal interpretation.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Total lithium nuclei within the solid phase of the electrode region are conserved during aging, i.e., LI_active_initial = LI_active_aged + LI_inactive_aged (LLI is conserved).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors present a conservation relationship linking active/inactive lithium and LLI, supported by operando NI observations.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: conservation of lithium nuclei in the electrode solid phase
hypotheses.notes: A foundational balance equation used to interpret Ni/SEI data.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Operando neutron imaging can track electrolyte motion into and out of the electrode region during cycling, a process linked to electrode expansion/contraction.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Operando NI data show periodic transmission changes correlated with voltage, interpreted as electrolyte moving with electrode volume changes during cycling.
variables_identified: electrolyte motion into/out of electrode region
hypotheses.specific_type_details: SEI/EL movement tracked by operando NI during cycling
hypotheses.notes: Describes a capability of operando NI to capture electrolyte dynamics during cycling.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The SEI layer comprises a bilayer structure with an organic outer layer and an inorganic inner layer; TOF-SIMS fragment sputtering and reach to stability tracks thickness distributions that correlate with NI-observed SEI signals.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: TOF-SIMS thickness proxies (tstable for organic/inorganic fragments) align with NI SEI signals, supporting a bilayer SEI model.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: bilayer SEI correspondence between TOF-SIMS and NI
hypotheses.notes: Mechanistic SEI architecture hypothesis supported by multi-modal data.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The quantitative EI standard curves obtained from NI are valid across aged cells and agree with differential weight measurements, enabling non-destructive EI quantification.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: EI values from NI-derived standard curves match destructive differential weight quantification, supporting NI-based EI quantification.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: validation of NI standard curves against weight-based EI
hypotheses.notes: Method-validation hypothesis for NI quantification approach.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The dominant degradation mode in these LFP/graphite pouch cells under the tested aging conditions is Lithium Inventory loss (LLI).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: LLI trends track with the 1C-capacity fade, indicating LLI is the principal degradation mode under the study conditions.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: dominant degradation mode
hypotheses.notes: Identifies the primary degradation mechanism in this experimental setting.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The larger pore size of graphite particles in the negative electrode (NE) makes them more susceptible to dry-out, as evidenced by the pronounced LAMNE increase and PDEIL indicators in the low-EI group.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Observations link NE pore size to PDEIL susceptibility and increased LAMNE under aging, suggesting geometry-driven dry-out vulnerability.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Larger NE pore size → greater PDEIL susceptibility and larger LAMNE
hypotheses.specific_type_details: pore geometry influences PDEIL/LAMNE
hypotheses.notes: Mechanistic link between particle-scale porosity and aging behavior.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Gas-phase formation has negligible impact on neutron transmission and does not drive EI signal changes, which supports interpreting NI data primarily via liquid/solid-phase processes and SEI evolution.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Control analyses and reasoning in the paper argue gas-phase changes are sparse and would not explain observed transmission trends.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: gas-phase contribution negligible in NI interpretation
hypotheses.notes: Reasoning about confounding factors in NI interpretation.

processing_notes: All hypotheses have been extracted from explicit statements and implicit claims throughout the paper (Introduction, Methods, Results, and Discussion/Conclusion). Where a claim functions as a methodological assertion (e.g., NI-based quantification validity, signal decoupling), it is treated as a hypothesis about measurement validity or transferability. Duplicative or highly overlapping statements (e.g., multiple facets of EI uniformity vs. SEI) were consolidated into single, non-redundant hypotheses to avoid duplication in the output.

paper_title: Two-Dimensional Na2LiAlP2 crystal for high-performance field-effect transistors

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The device can easily achieve the required on-state current of 900 μA/μm under low operating voltages of 0.1 V and 0.2 V.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: States a performance threshold that the device is claimed to meet under specified operating voltages.
variables_identified: low operating voltages (0.1 V and 0.2 V)
hypotheses.predicted_direction: ION ≥ 900 μA/μm at VDD = 0.1–0.2 V
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Performance threshold benchmarking against IRDS/ITRS HP requirement
hypotheses.notes: Direct device-performance claim tied to standard thresholds

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: A Na2LiAlP2 n-type MOSFET with a gate length of 7.9 nm achieves an ON-state current of 1.51×10^4 μA/μm.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Reports a specific simulation result for a device at Lg = 7.9 nm.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: ION ≈ 1.51×10^4 μA/μm for Lg = 7.9 nm
hypotheses.specific_type_details: N-type MOSFET at 7.9 nm
hypotheses.notes: Specific device-case result used to benchmark performance

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: When the channel length is reduced to just 5.7 nm, the device's ON-state current soars to 1.62×10^4 μA/μm (HP), far exceeding the 0.9×10^3 μA/μm required by the ITRS.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Reports a short-channel length result showing a large increase in ION relative to the ITRS threshold.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: ION increases to ≈ 1.62×10^4 μA/μm when Lg = 5.7 nm
hypotheses.specific_type_details: HP device at 5.7 nm
hypotheses.notes: Demonstrates strong short-channel performance against HP standard

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The transport performance of Na2LiAlP2 MOSFETs along the a-direction consistently outperforms that along the b-direction.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Observed directional anisotropy in ION, PDP, and SS favoring the a-direction.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: a-direction yields better performance than b-direction
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Direction-dependent performance
hypotheses.notes: Adds an anisotropy dimension to device design considerations

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: When VDD ≤ 0.5 V, the saturation current (Isat) only experiences a slight decline, and the minimum subthreshold swing (SSmin) is as low as 30.33 mV/dec at 0.1 V VDD.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Reports voltage-dependent behavior showing robustness of performance at low voltage.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Isat remains high while SSmin remains ≤ 30.33 mV/dec at low VDD
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Low-voltage HP performance
hypotheses.notes: Demonstrates low-voltage viability for HP operation

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Na2LiAlP2 MOSFET with a 5.7 nm gate length outperforms other 2D materials in terms of both ON-state current and SS at similar gate lengths.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Direct comparison against several other 2D materials shows superior Ion and SS.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Na2LiAlP2 > other materials in ION and SS at 5.7 nm
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Direct material comparison at 5.7 nm
hypotheses.notes: Supports material advantage claim for high-performance sub-10 nm MOSFETs

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The local density of states (LDOS) analysis shows that the effective barrier height in the channel decreases as the gate-source voltage increases (OFF → ON) from 1.0 eV to 0.4 eV (LP) and from 0.8 eV to 0.1 eV (HP).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Mechanistic link between VGS and barrier height demonstrated by LDOS results.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increasing VGS lowers Φ (OFF to ON)
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Gate-controlled barrier modulation
hypotheses.notes: Explains gate-control mechanism at the microscopic level

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The Na2LiAlP2 MOSFETs exhibit subthreshold swings below the Boltzmann limit of 60 mV/dec for sub-10 nm gate lengths, depending on direction and gate length.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Empirical observation that SS values are below 60 mV/dec for several configurations.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: SS < 60 mV/dec for certain Lg and directions
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Surpassing Boltzmann limit in sub-10 nm devices
hypotheses.notes: Demonstrates steep-slope potential in 2D MOSFETs

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Underlap structure, if implemented, can further mitigate short-channel effects and significantly enhance the device performance of Na2LiAlP2 MOSFETs.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Cited as a known approach in prior work to suppress short-channel effects.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Underlap → improved device performance via reduced short-channel effects
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Design modification to MOSFET structure
hypotheses.notes: Forward-looking claim about potential improvements

processing_notes: All hypotheses have been extracted from explicit statements and closely implied claims about device performance, directional anisotropy, voltage/geometry dependencies, and comparative material performance. Duplicates were avoided by consolidating repeated performance claims into a single hypothesis per testable claim.

paper_title: Quantum Spin Singlet and Classical Néel-Ordered Ground States in MoX3 (X = I, Br) Spin-3/2 Dimerized Antiferromagnetic Chain Crystals

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: MoI3 and MoBr3 have classical Néel-type long-range antiferromagnetic order at low temperature, stabilized by weak interchain coupling, which undergoes a transition around TN ≈ 40 K into a phase dominated by single-chain physics with a gapped quantum spin singlet ground state featuring a large singlet–triplet gap Δ.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Evidence from susceptibility and specific heat shows an AFM cusp/kink near 40 K indicative of a Néel transition, while higher-temperature behavior is consistent with 1D spin-chain physics and a sizable spin gap, implying a dimensional crossover governed by interchain coupling.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increasing interchain coupling J3 raises TN, promoting 3D order; stronger J3 enlarges the temperature range where Néel order is observed
hypotheses.notes: Directly ties experimental signatures (AFM cusp/kink, specific heat) to a 1D–3D crossover controlled by interchain coupling; describes coexistence of Néel order and 1D spin-singlet behavior.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Above the Néel transition, MoI3 and MoBr3 behave as spin-3/2 dimerized one-dimensional chains with a gapped spin-singlet ground state, yielding singlet–triplet gaps of Δ ≈ 21 meV for MoI3 and Δ ≈ 25 meV for MoBr3.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The gap originates from dimerization in S = 3/2 spin chains; susceptibility fits with a 1D dimerized model (Eq. 1) yield Δ values that agree with experiment.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Δ takes the values 21 meV (MoI3) and 25 meV (MoBr3) in the 1D regime; Δ is governed by δ and J1 in the dimerized chain
hypotheses.notes: Fits to the 1D susceptibility model yield the reported gaps; supports the presence of a dimerized spin-3/2 chain regime above TN.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The Néel temperature TN is controlled by the weak interchain coupling J3; Monte Carlo simulations show TN increases with J3, identifying J3 as the key tuning parameter for the quasi-1D to bulk-like magnetic crossover.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Monte Carlo results using DFT-derived exchange constants indicate TN rises as J3 is strengthened; systematic variation of J3 demonstrates the monotonic increase of TN, establishing J3 as the dominant lever for dimensional crossover.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: TN increases when J3 is increased; doubling J3 raises TN by substantial amounts (e.g., MoI3: 35 K → 52 K; MoBr3: 26 K → 43 K)
hypotheses.notes: Direct link between interchain coupling strength and the 3D ordering temperature; demonstrates the dimensional crossover mechanism.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The experimental magnetic susceptibility data are not compatible with an S = 1 uniform spin chain; only an S = 3/2 chain with DFT-derived exchange constants can reproduce the observed susceptibility and the measured spin gaps.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Across parametric fits, curves of constant Δ intersect the S = 3/2 parametric DFT curves, while the S = 1 curve lies far from them; this indicates the experimental data favor S = 3/2 over S = 1 for MoI3 and MoBr3.
hypotheses.notes: The S = 3/2 scenario provides a consistent explanation; the S = 1 scenario cannot reproduce the data within the DFT-parameter space explored.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The singlet–triplet gap Δ in the S = 3/2 chain scales with dimerization δ such that Δ decreases as δ increases, with physically relevant MoI3/MoBr3 values (δ ≲ 0.2) yielding a finite gap.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: DMRG/ED results show Δ(δ) decreases monotonically with increasing δ; polynomial fits in δ reproduce the observed gaps in the physically relevant regime (δ ≲ 0.2).
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Δ decreases as δ increases (gap shrinks with reduced dimerization) in the physically relevant region
hypotheses.notes: Connection between bond alternation and the 1D spin gap; supports the dimerized-1D picture for MoI3/MoBr3.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: There exists a topological transition in the S = 3/2 dimerized chain as a function of δ, with the spin gap closing near δ ≈ 0.59, marking a transition from a Haldane-like topological phase to a trivial dimerized phase.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: DMRG/ED analyses show the gap closes at δ ≈ 0.59 and reopens, signaling a topological transition consistent with known spin-chain phase diagrams for bond-altered S = 3/2 systems.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Gap closes (Δ → 0) around δ ≈ 0.59, indicating a phase transition
hypotheses.notes: Theoretical/topological interpretation of the δ-tuned transition in S = 3/2 chains; highlights a multicritical point with δ ≈ 0.59.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: DFT-derived exchange constants, mapped to a spin-3/2 dimerized chain and with U tuned to reproduce the experimental Δ, recover the observed Δ and the corresponding J1 and δ values for MoI3 (U ≈ 0.6 eV; J1 ≈ 28.1 meV; δ ≈ 0.0996; J3 ≈ 0.385 meV; J4 ≈ 0.064 meV) and MoBr3 (U ≈ 1.2 eV; J1 ≈ 37.4 meV; δ ≈ 0.130; J3 ≈ 0.193 meV; J4 ≈ 0.0551 meV).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Intersections of constant-Δ curves with DFT-derived parametric curves identify U values that reproduce the experimental Δ; ED/DMRG with these parameters reproduce the observed Δ, validating the DFT-derived exchange picture for S = 3/2 chains.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Using DFT-derived couplings with U = 0.6 eV (MoI3) or 1.2 eV (MoBr3) reproduces the experimental Δ and yields consistent J1, δ values
hypotheses.notes: Bridges ab initio parameters with many-body results; supports S = 3/2 description and the specific U values that reconcile theory with experiment.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: A magnetic transition near 78 K in MoBr3 observed in specific-heat measurements is intrinsic to MoBr3 (not an artifact of the grease or mounting), consistent with a magnetic transition separate from the 40 K Néel-like feature.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Control measurements of the adhesive grease show no magnetic response; the 78 K feature appears in MoBr3 and is not an instrumental artifact, indicating an intrinsic magnetic response.
variables_identified: MoBr3 specific heat feature at 78 K
hypotheses.notes: Supports intrinsic magnetic behavior in MoBr3; auxiliary measurement checks rule out sample-mount artifact.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The broad maximum observed in magnetic susceptibility at T ≈ Δ is a characteristic signature of a quantum spin-chain with a spin gap, corresponding to thermally populated triplet states above the spin gap.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Thermally activated behavior above the gap produces a broad susceptibility maximum; the peak location aligns with the extracted Δ values and is consistent with dimerized 1D spin-chain physics.
hypotheses.notes: connects the thermodynamic susceptibility signature to the presence of a spin gap in the 1D regime.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The Monte Carlo simulations using DFT-derived exchange constants reproduce the observed Néel temperatures, supporting the interpretation that interchain coupling drives the Néel ordering in MoI3 and MoBr3.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: MC results yield TN values (≈35 K for MoI3 and ≈26 K for MoBr3) that align with experimental observations when interchain coupling is included, validating the proposed magnetic model.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Increasing interchain coupling raises TN; MC fits reproduce the experimental trend
hypotheses.notes: Links ab initio parameters to finite-temperature ordering via MC, establishing interchain coupling as a control knob for dimensional crossover.

processing_notes: The paper investigates MoI3 and MoBr3 as quasi-1D spin-3/2 dimerized chains with a low-temperature classical Néel order stabilized by weak interchain coupling, and a high-temperature regime where 1D spin-chain physics dominates with a sizable singlet-triplet spin gap. We identified hypotheses (explicit and implicit) that span (i) the existence and nature of the Néel ground state and its TN, (ii) the presence and magnitude of the 1D spin gap Δ in the dimerized chain regime, (iii) the dependence of TN and Δ on interchain and intrachain exchange parameters, (iv) the necessity of S = 3/2 over S = 1 (or other) to explain the data, and (v) the topological transitions associated with dimerization. Each hypothesis was classified on epistemic type, structural complexity, predictive direction, temporal framing, and whether it concerns implementation/transferability, with a confidence estimate and concise justification. Duplicates across sections were avoided by treating each distinct claim (e.g., Néel ordering, spin gap, interchain coupling as the tuning parameter, spin value, and DFT-based validation) as separate hypotheses. If you want, I can tighten the quotes for each hypothesis_text to exact verbatim phrasing from the paper or expand the justification for each classification.

paper_title: Modeling Epidemics on Multiplex Networks: Epidemic Threshold and Basic Reproduction Number

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The epidemic threshold in the two-layer multiplex DBMF model occurs at ρ = 1 (equivalently, at τ ≈ 1).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Crossing the threshold ρ > 1 leads to epidemic growth in outbreak indicators Imax and R∞; the authors state that ρ = 1 marks the epidemic threshold and discuss equivalence with τ ≈ 1.
variables_identified: ρ (spectral radius / R0 in multiplex model)
hypotheses.predicted_direction: If ρ > 1, an epidemic can spread and outbreak indicators increase; if ρ ≤ 1, the epidemic dies out.
hypotheses.notes: Explicitly discussed as the epidemic threshold; tested via numerical results (Fig. 2).
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Numerical integration shows Imax and R∞ grow for ρ > 1; ρ = 1 marks the threshold; τ is discussed as an equivalent/approximate threshold.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: R0 for the multiplex model can be well approximated by the quantity τ defined in Eq. (24), i.e., R0 ≈ τ.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors introduce τ as a simpler, transparent approximation to the exact spectral-radius-based R0 and argue it captures the same qualitative behavior.
hypotheses.notes: τ is presented as a simpler, interpretable extension that mirrors R0 behavior; Eq. (24) gives the explicit additive form.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Fig. 3 shows outbreak indicators vs τ behaving similarly to ρ; Eq. (24) defines τ as the approximation to R0.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Imax and R∞ depend primarily on ρ (or τ) and collapse onto a single trend when plotted against ρ (or τ) across different network scenarios.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The results show that, regardless of the fixed parameters, curves of Imax and R∞ versus ρ (and versus τ) align and follow a single trend.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: As ρ (or τ) increases, Imax and R∞ increase monotonically following the same qualitative shape across scenarios.
hypotheses.notes: Observed collapse across several distribution types (Poisson–Poisson, Geometric–Geometric); not perfect for Poisson–Geom.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Figure 2 demonstrates collapse with ρ; Figure 3 shows similar behavior with τ; Figure 5 shows breakdown for Poisson–Geom.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: In the agent-based multiplex simulations, the average number of secondary infections generated in early epidemic generations equals τ (i.e., τ equals the early-generation reproduction number).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors demonstrate that the ratio of infections across generations (third over second) in simulations matches the τ value, aligning with the interpretation of R0.
variables_identified: average number of secondary infections in early generations
hypotheses.notes: Agent-based results (Fig. 6) validate τ as the early-epidemic reproduction measure.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Simulations with N = 10^4, 100 realizations show the third/second generation ratio tracks τ across parameter changes.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: τ acts as a threshold indicator for epidemic spread, with τ ≈ 1 marking onset; τ > 1 leads to outbreak, τ < 1 leads to die-out; and τ ≥ ρ (i.e., τ is a conservative threshold relative to ρ).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The results indicate a threshold behavior at τ ≈ 1, and the authors explicitly note that τ is a conservative threshold since τ ≥ ρ (τ < 1 implies ρ < 1).
hypotheses.predicted_direction: τ ≥ 1 implies potential epidemic spread; τ < 1 implies no sustained spread; τ is a conservative proxy for ρ.
hypotheses.notes: Stated explicitly in the discussion and conclusions as the threshold interpretation and τ–ρ relation.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Fig. 3 shows growth around τ ≈ 1; conclusions emphasize τ as a conservative threshold.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: For networks with low degree variance, R0 ≃ τ (i.e., the exact reproduction number is well approximated by the τ approximation).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The determinant in the two-layer R0 expression becomes small when degree variance is low, making R0 ≈ τ (τ^2 dominating the determinant).
hypotheses.notes: Derived from Eq. (21) and the discussion on low-variance networks.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: The text states that with low degree variance, the determinant is much smaller than τ^2, so R0 ≃ τ.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: When the determinant term in the two-layer R0 expression is negligible, R0 is approximately the sum of the layer-specific reproduction numbers, i.e., R0 ≃ τ = (β1/γ)[⟨k1^2⟩ − ⟨k1⟩]/⟨k1⟩ + (β2/γ)[⟨k2^2⟩ − ⟨k2⟩]/⟨k2⟩.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors show that in the regime where the determinant is negligible, R0 reduces to the sum of the two layers' contributions, i.e., R0 ≃ τ.
hypotheses.notes: Eq. (24) and accompanying discussion describe the additive limit when the determinant is negligible.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: The paper states that when the determinant is non-depreciable, ρ < τ, and when negligible, R0 ≃ τ, equal to the sum of layer contributions.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The τ-based predictions generalize across two-layer configurations (e.g., Poisson–Poisson and Geometric–Geometric), but may not fully collapse for mixed distributions (Poisson–Geom).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The results show clear collapse for Poisson–Poisson and Geometric–Geometric cases, but not for Poisson–Geom, indicating limits to universal τ-based predictability.
hypotheses.notes: Observations reported in Fig. 5; the authors discuss limitations in the Poisson–Geom case.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Fig. 5 shows non-collapse in the Poisson–Geom scenario; Figures 3 and 4 show collapses for the other pairs.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The generalized DBMF/NGM approach provides a robust framework for generalizing R0 to multiplex networks, offering more realistic epidemic forecasts than single-layer homogeneous models.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The authors argue that incorporating layered connectivity yields a robust generalization of R0 and improves realism for forecasting and intervention design.
hypotheses.notes: Conclusion emphasizes methodological contribution and potential practical impact.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: Authors state that R0 generalizes to multiplex networks and informs forecasting and intervention planning.

processing_notes: The paper presents a theoretical/mathematical generalization of the basic reproduction number to multiplex networks, coupled with numerical and agent-based validations. Hypotheses were inferred from explicit threshold claims (ρ = 1, τ ≈ 1), the proposed τ approximation to R0, threshold behavior, and the empirical validation of τ in agent-based simulations. Some hypotheses are conditional on network distribution (e.g., collapse across layers) and are explicitly discussed (e.g., Poisson–Geom deviations). All hypotheses listed are unique (no duplicates).

paper_title: Electric Polarization-Driven Modulation of Fe Adatoms on Ferroelectric $α$-In$_2$Se$_3$

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: There exist two competing adsorption sites for Fe adatoms (B and C) on α-In2Se3, and their relative stability depends on adatom concentration; switching the electric polarization of α-In2Se3 can reverse the preferred site (B vs C) depending on polarization direction and concentration.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The paper reports that the B site is more favorable for upward polarization, whereas the C site consistently yields the lowest adsorption energy for downward polarization across all considered concentrations; at high adatom concentrations, upward polarization promotes adsorption at the B site, while downward polarization favors the C site.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: Upward polarization → B site favored; downward polarization → C site favored; at high concentration, B-up and C-down become preferred respectively.
hypotheses.notes: Explicit energy comparisons show polarization-direction dependent site preference; concentration modulates this effect.
hypotheses.evaluation_details: DFT+U energy calculations across 2×2 to 6×6 supercells show B favored under UP, C favored under DOWN; high-concentration regime (up: B; down: C).
